Vaccines available include: Moderna, Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson    Brussels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210501094622/https://coronavirus.brussels/centres-de-vaccination-covid-planning/  Wallonia: https://web.archive.org/web/20210501100145/https://www.wallonie.be/fr/actualites/covid-19-strategie-de-vaccination    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501094528/https://www.qvax.be/region/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419094227/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210417125037/https://observablehq.com/@tf-vaccination/belvax
notes_C5: Restrictions on public transports are eased from 19th April . https://archive.vn/5Edum

name: Benin
notes_H1: Government posters on best practice regarding hygiene. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200511035054/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/529/coronavirus-point-des-mesures-prises-par-le-gouvernement/
notes_H2: Testing is available if needed.  -----------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407090808/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405183535/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411013810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407091212/https://www.gouv.bj/coronavirus/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206024425/https://sgg.gouv.bj/cm/2020-12-23/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330180620/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/1228/lutte-contre-pandemie-coronavirus--covid-19-campagne-nationale-vaccination-officiellement-lancee/
notes_C7: Per US Embassy, there are no restrictions on internal movement within the country of Benin. https://web.archive.org/web/20201108165803/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/
notes_H6: Face coverings are required outside the home at all times. Fines imposed for non-compliance. https://web.archive.org/web/20201108165803/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/
notes_E2: Per IMF site there continues to be support for companies both formally and informally.  Currently there are established avenues to gain access to financial help for micro, small and medium enterprises.  There is a public guarantee plan and credit lines for refinancing measures as well.    -------------------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411013810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Per the Benin Government site the Council has agreed to resume sports and cultural activities in accordance with barrier measures.    -----------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407090808/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405183535/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411013810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407091212/https://www.gouv.bj/coronavirus/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206024425/https://sgg.gouv.bj/cm/2020-12-23/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330180620/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/1228/lutte-contre-pandemie-coronavirus--covid-19-campagne-nationale-vaccination-officiellement-lancee/
notes_C6: There is no data indicating that people are required to stay at home   see here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425102753/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425102931/https://www.gouv.bj/actualites/coronavirus--covid-19-/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425103047/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus
notes_C8: All land borders remain closed and travel into Benin is restricted, however the US embassy indicates that US citizens are in fact allowed to travel into Benin from one of the two international airports that remain open. These airports appear to be the only way possible to gain entry into Benin.     See here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425102753/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425102931/https://www.gouv.bj/actualites/coronavirus--covid-19-/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425103047/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus
notes_C2: Per references below I was unable to find any data that would support the closure of workplaces as long as social distancing and mask wearing are strictly followed.    -----------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407090808/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405183535/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411013810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407091212/https://www.gouv.bj/coronavirus/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206024425/https://sgg.gouv.bj/cm/2020-12-23/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330180620/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/1228/lutte-contre-pandemie-coronavirus--covid-19-campagne-nationale-vaccination-officiellement-lancee/
notes_C4: All gatherings are allowed even Religious Events, however they are all limited to less than 50 people.  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210221170557/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210221170510/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  Unable to Archive  - https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/  - https://www.gouv.bj/actualites/coronavirus--covid-19-/
notes_H3: Included below are the links and information regarding the digital tracking that is used for making appointments along with traveling - Assuming contact tracing is comprehensive.  -------------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320180921/https://centresurveillancesanitaire.bj/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407091212/https://www.gouv.bj/coronavirus/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206024425/https://sgg.gouv.bj/cm/2020-12-23/
notes_E1: Per IMF site there is continued support for vulnerable households through cash transfers, electricity & water bills subsidies.  There is a public guarantee plan and credit lines for refinancing measures as well.    -------------------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411013810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: UK Gov Site, US Embassy, IMF and Benin Government site all reference that schools are all open.    -----------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407090808/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405183535/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411013810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407091212/https://www.gouv.bj/coronavirus/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206024425/https://sgg.gouv.bj/cm/2020-12-23/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330180620/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/1228/lutte-contre-pandemie-coronavirus--covid-19-campagne-nationale-vaccination-officiellement-lancee/
notes_H7: As of the 29th of March, Benin has a vaccine policy with 78 vaccination centres around the country.    The health minister urges health workers, people over the age of 60 and people living with co-morbidities such as diabetes, asthma, arterial hypertension, sickle cell disease, etc to immediately go out and receive the vaccine.     see here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407094158/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/1228/
notes_C5: According to the UK government website, public transport is reduced to 50% capacity.   See here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405183535/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus

name: Burkina Faso
notes_H1: Video on official government website providing advice to public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200511105917/https://www.sante.gov.bf/detail?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=165&cHash=553848326e0511204c14d95bf6870bb8
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is free in Burkina Faso. All centres performing COVID-19 diagnostic are contracted by the government. See: https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ (web archive unavailable, accessed 21st September 2020)
notes_C7: It looks like the Government of Burkina Faso cancelled the curfew which was in effect throughout the country, except for the provinces that are under state of emergency (the East and Sahel regions, Kossi and Sourou provinces in Boucle de Mouhoun, Kenedougou province in Hauts Bassins, Louroum province in the North, and Koulpelogo province in the Center-East region).  ----------------------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000808/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210321171516/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/burkina-faso/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210321171620/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H6: Mask wearing is obligatory through out the country.  ----------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418054857/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210417161056/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404172709/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/burkina-faso/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213224046/https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/destinations/africa/burkina-faso
notes_E2: There appears to be many programs to support workers.... Several measures have been taken under the revised budget, including: (i) lowering import duties and VAT for hygiene and healthcare goods and services critical to tackle COVID-19, and for tourism businesses; (ii) lowering other selected tax rates; (iii) delaying tax payments, and waiving late payment fines and penalties; (iv) suspending government fees charged on informal sector operators for rent, security and parking in urban markets; (v) lowering the licensing fee for companies in the transportation and tourism sectors; (vi) suspending on-site tax inspection operations; (vii) Donating food and providing assistance to households and local small businesses; (viii) supporting the water and electricity bills, including through cancelation, of the most vulnerable social groups; and (ix) securing adequate stocks of consumer products and strengthening surveillance of prices.  -----------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000808/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210321171516/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/burkina-faso/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210321171620/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C6: Burkina Faso has lifted stay at home orders, according to a travel advisory issued on the 6th of August 2020 (this seems like a national measure, so coded as 0). See: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories/burkina-faso-travel-advisory.html (accessed 21st September 2020, web archive unavailable, travel advisory issued August 6 2020)
notes_C8: The Ouagadougou and Bobo airports returned to normal operations on August 1, 2020.  All land borders remain closed.  Burkina Faso COVD-19 Pandemic Crisis management Committee met on 04/01 to review current guidelines in place.    ----------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404172705/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404172709/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/burkina-faso/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404144644/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404172807/https://www.gouvernement.gov.bf/informations/actualites/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=522&cHash=00653664cebb25b57994f7e99c981303
notes_C2: Bars, Maquis, theatres, restaurants, gaming, cafés are allowed to reopen with the application of social distancing measures and sanitary precautions including wearing face masks, using single use dishes and providing soap and water for handwashing https://web.archive.org/web/20200517203948/https://www.sig.gov.bf/actualites/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=414&cHash=dadef64399ce076c2f18a9ea7bbe917e
notes_C4: Per the US Embassy site there are no restrictions site is sited to have been updated on November 27th.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201213211405/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: "The government continues to provide daily communiqués giving case counts and contact tracing information.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315010729/https://www.sig.gov.bf/actualites/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=1053&cHash=b69007f1367dd9b68e014dbd398fb88c    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315010904/https://www.sig.gov.bf/infos-covid-19?tx_news_pi1%5B%40widget_0%5D%5BcurrentPage%5D=2&cHash=c31a07bcbc80964992bfc1fb90ee42bf"
notes_E1: While there is data that indicates there is a budget to support, it does not indicate the level of income support for individual workers. It appears to be more aimed at businesses.     The IMF has updates on fiscal, monetary, and macro financial policy that aims to help those struggling due to the pandemic. It is valid from April 2 2021 and this includes a partial guarantee fund, which the government expects to leverage to help the financial sector inject fresh credit into the economy during 2020-2021 in support of private businesses in hard-hit sectors.    see more here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409163906/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: No change
notes_C5: Measures have been set up to limit infection on public transport,  This Tuesday, May 5, 2020 marks the resumption of passenger-passenger transport activities throughout the territory. At the Gare de l'Est where we were on this first day of resumption of activities, the crowds are not so much there.  The Executive Board of the High Council of Transporters of Burkina Faso (HCT-BF) informs the Burkinabè population that, due to the quarantine measure still in force, the resumption of passenger-passenger transport activities, initially scheduled for Monday, May 4 is postponed to Tuesday, May 5 throughout the territory.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200503184151/https://www.sig.gov.bf/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=379&cHash=763a0815f061dfeac65be6af7a1bd80c  https://web.archive.org/web/20200511104331/https://www.burkina24.com/2020/05/05/reprise-des-activites-de-transport-a-ouagadougou-constat-a-la-gare-de-lest/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200511104428/https://www.burkina24.com/2020/05/04/covid-19-au-burkina-faso-reprise-des-activites-de-transport-de-passagers-voyageurs-annoncee-pour-le-5-mai/

name: Bangladesh
notes_H1: While the originally linked press release (https://www.iedcr.gov.bd/index.php/component/content/article/11-others/227-pressrelease) is no longer available, this photo from GettyImages shows Bangladeshi students wearing facemasks on January 29, indicating that a public health campaign was in place. https://web.archive.org/web/20200604225455/https://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/bangladeshi-students-wear-masks-for-protection-against-news-photo/1197376807#/web/20200604225455mp_/https://www.gettyimages.co.uk/  There is also this leaflet from unicef that seems to be from early February; https://web.archive.org/web/20200604225319/https://www.unicef.org/bangladesh/media/3506/file/Coronavirus_leaflet_Bangla.pdf (linked in an article dated February 8: https://web.archive.org/web/20200604225903/https://www.unicef.org/bangladesh/en/stories/coronavirus-disease-covid). Hence 2G is maintained as coding.
notes_H2: "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Bangladesh?  Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  The Government of Bangladesh has provided a list of recommended COVID-19 testing facilities for international passengers here. Those wishing to get tested will have to pay for their own COVID-19 test."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210215095331/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Is a curfew in place? Only from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes.  Residents should remain in their homes from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. except for emergencies or for essential needs, such as shopping for food and medicine.  Residents are advised to work from home if possible.  Public transportation is suspended to include passenger trains.  No travel is allowed from district to district.  Domestic flights are suspended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182252/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: The Government of Bangladesh has made wearing masks and social distancing mandatory when outside the home. Public administrators in Khulna Division have instituted a fine of TK 4,000 for those not adhering to this order.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182252/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: 4 April – Waiver on Credit Card: The banks are instructed not to deduct any fees/charges/interest against late payment of credit card bill from 15 March 2020 to 31 May 2020. In addition to the already formulated regulations on March 19, this raises to the level of a broad contract relief, hence upgraded to 2. https://web.archive.org/web/20200604203924/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/bangladesh-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
notes_C3: No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182252/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: The Government of Bangladesh announced a countrywide lockdown to limit the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic starting from April 5, 2021. The Government of Bangladesh has implemented further measures to limit the spread of COVID-19, including extending the general holiday period to May 5.  Bangladesh government offices and private sector organizations will largely be closed until at least May 5, and the government has advised everyone to stay home during this period. A daily curfew is in effect from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m.  Hospitals, pharmacies, and food stores remain open. Public transportation and banking services remain limited.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182252/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Temporary closure of land border with India for 14 days from 26 April onwards. https://web.archive.org/web/20210426214002/https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2021/04/25/bangladesh-seals-border-with-india-to-check-covid-19-spread
notes_C2: Residents are advised to work from home if possible. The Government of Bangladesh has implemented further measures to limit the spread of COVID-19, including extending the general holiday period to May 5.  Bangladesh government offices and private sector organizations will largely be closed until at least May 5, and the government has advised everyone to stay home during this period.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182252/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  A maximum of five people is allowed for daily prayer at every mosque, and a maximum of 10 people are allowed for Friday prayer.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182252/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: https://web.archive.org/web/2020*/https://www.who.int/bangladesh/news/detail/06-09-2020-who-strengthens-covid-19-contact-tracing-to-break-the-chain-of-transmission
notes_E1: Since there is no evidence for any ongoing support other than the one time cash payment announced on April 14, downgraded to 0 after one month
notes_H8: No significant updates particular to the elderly people. However, please note: Is a curfew in place? Only from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes.  Residents should remain in their homes from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. except for emergencies or for essential needs, such as shopping for food and medicine.  Residents are advised to work from home if possible.  Public transportation is suspended to include passenger trains.  No travel is allowed from district to district.  Domestic flights are suspended.  International flights remain operational.  No indoor dining services are allowed.  Delivery food service options are available.  Grocery stores and pharmacies may remain open.  Residents can shop in bazaars only when necessary.  Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes, and recreation centers are closed.  No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  A maximum of five people is allowed for daily prayer at every mosque, and a maximum of 10 people are allowed for Friday prayer.  All tourist locations are closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182252/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/searo/bangladesh/covid-19-who-bangladesh-situation-reports/who-ban-covid-19-sitrep-04.pdf?sfvrsn=69b6d931_8
notes_H7: "Vaccination is now open for people above 40 years old which was initially 55 years"  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412184456/https://www.thedailystar.net/opinion/macro-mirror/news/impressive-start-covid-vaccination-bangladesh-2044789
notes_C5: Public transportation is suspended to include passenger trains. Is public transportation operating? No. The recent lockdown is from April 5 – April 11. Public transportation will not be available during this time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182252/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Bulgaria
notes_H1: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs recommends that the Bulgarians refrain from attending public events, avoid crowded places, and comply with safety measures such as wearing a protective medical mask, maintaining personal hygiene, and avoiding direct contact with strangers. Since the PM also addressed the public on the same day and because of the previous presence of a hotline, I rate this as 2G for being the starting point of the public information campaign stage; https://web.archive.org/web/20200503234833/https://www.bnt.bg/en/a/foreign-ministry-with-recommendations-on-italy-and-china-travel-over-coronavirus
notes_H2: Currently, no specified policy even though testing is taking place. 30th March: Bulgaria has ordered 600,000 PCR tests and 400,000 rapid tests for mass testing.
notes_C7: The restrictions on intercity travel in Bulgaria end at midnight, Health Minister Kiril Ananiev said on May 5.    source: https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/05/05/covid-19-in-bulgaria-may-5-intercity-travel-restrictions-scrapped-as-of-wednesday/
notes_E2: As of 22 December, the loan repayment moratorium remains in effect.    Borrowers are able to negotiate with lenders until 31 March 2021 to delay payments of both interest and the principal for nine months. Those who have already had six months of loan repayment holidays can negotiate three additional months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210418/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/972
notes_C3: Most events are allowed when using no more than 50% of the capacity of the premises in which they are held, subject to physical distance of 1.5 m and wearing face masks by all participants.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426185832/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki
notes_C6: All open-air activities permitted, with indoor activities in malls, cafes, etc. allowed on 1 June 2020. Source: https://coronavirus.bg/bg/391
notes_C8: https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/bulgaria-imposes-stricter-restrictions-entry-bans-for-several-third-countries/
notes_C2: Cinemas, theaters, museums, galleries, libraries and circus performances will be open to visitors from April 1, with an occupancy of no more than 30% of the capacity of the premises. The same condition applies to classes in dance, creative and musical arts.    Cinemas, theaters, museums, galleries, libraries and circus performances will be open to visitors from April 1, with an occupancy of no more than 30% of the capacity of the premises. The same condition applies to classes in dance, creative and musical arts.    From April 1, visits to fitness centers, gyms and clubs and swimming pools and complexes are allowed, using no more than 30% of their capacity and observing a physical distance of at least 1.5 m.    From April 1 to April 12, stores with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, offering non-food items, are allowed to work with customers only in the open areas adjacent to the store.    Visits to restaurants and entertainment are allowed only in their open areas (terraces, gardens, etc.), with limited working hours from 6.00 to 23.00. Exceptions are discos, bar clubs, piano bars, variety bars and nightclubs, which remain closed until the end of April.    https://archive.vn/TICBP
notes_C4: Group celebrations with the presence of more than 15 people indoors and outdoor (including weddings, balls, baptisms) are not allowed.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210317062836/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: Bulgaria seeks passengers from Amsterdam flight after 3 test positive for Covid-19  web/20200604222325/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/04/29/bulgaria-seeks-passengers-from-amsterdam-flight-after-3-test-positive-for-covid-19/
notes_E1: On 23 December, the 60/40 measure in support of business and workers was extended until September 2021    "Eligible applicants for the measure are employers from the sectors of passenger and urban transport, passenger land transport, hotels, restaurants. Self-employed persons with activity in the same sectors, as well as freelancers and sole traders are also entitled to assistance in this line," said the Minister of Labor and Social Policy Denitsa Sacheva.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205533/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1039    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205415/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1069
notes_H8: As of 22 March, visits to hospital facilities are prohibited, except for visits to patients in the terminal stage.     Only people age 65 or older are allowed to shop in grocery stores between 08:30 and 10:30.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210330030000/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki
notes_C1: The health minister issued an order for anti-epidemic measures on April 1st. From Monday, April 5, kindergartens and nurseries to resume their work. After the end of the spring vacation of the students, from April 12, the attendance of the children from 1st to 12th grade will be resumed, and the schedule will be announced within the next week. Also from April 12, group activities and activities are allowed in the centers for support of personal development and the centers for special educational support.    https://archive.vn/TICBP
notes_H7: On Saturday, 20th of February, began a mass-vaccination campaign, as Bulgarian Prime Minister Boiko Borrisov announced. “Green corridors” were created, where any Bulgarian resident could line up for the vaccine.   Link: https://archive.fo/wip/P1ZWv

name: Bahrain
notes_H1: A multilingual national campaign to combat the novel Covel Cornonavirus (COVID-19)  has been launched in the Kingdom of Bahrain to enhance public awareness and beef up prevention measures.    Health Minister Faeqa bint Saed Al-Saleh announced the plan in lined with the directives of His Royal Highness Prince Salman bin Hamad Al-Khalifa, Crown Prince, Deputy Supreme Commander and First Deputy Premier.    The wide-ranging campaign would be channeled through the social media, the press, Radio Bahrain and TV, the health centres, labour camps and in cooperation with the Labour and Social Development Minister and the Labour Market Regulatory Authority (LMRA). https://web.archive.org/web/20200607213428/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/3805
notes_H2: Dr. Al Manea emphasized that the Ministry of Health has recently begun random medical tests, via mobile testing units, across the Kingdom. Dr. Al Manea further extended gratitude to all the authorities collaborating with the Ministry of Health to contain the spread of COVID-19, and in particular the Ministry of Interior, represented by the General Directorate of Civil Defence, who have disinfected various areas and provided awareness campaigns across the Kingdom. Since this presupposes general availability, upgraded to 3; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607234542/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4068
notes_C7: Movement Restrictions   Is a curfew in place? No   Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No   https://web.archive.org/web/20210309002539/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Mandatory to wear a mask in all public places.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503191555/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: No change per Ministry of Finance and National Economy Website & Central Bank website after Sep 20 note.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200919083650/https://www.mofne.gov.bh/  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.cbb.gov.bh/
notes_C3: Any public or private event held at home, and private locations, with more than 30 individuals, is prohibited    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406032849/https://healthalert.gov.bh/en/article/the-national-medical-taskforce-for-combating-the-coronavirus-covid-19-11-03-2021
notes_C6: No curfew or stay at home order in place:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210209225447/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bahrain/coronavirus#:~:text=Gatherings%20of%20over%205%20people,January%20to%2020%20February%202021.
notes_C8: Eligible travelers arriving in the country must self-isolate and then undergo three polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests over a period of 10 days. Travelers must take a PCR test on arrival, with those remaining in Bahrain taking another such test on the fifth and 10th day of their stay. All tests are at the traveler's expense. Travelers must also self-isolate until the individual receives a negative test result.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406043137/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/460332/bahrain-several-covid-19-related-restrictions-remain-in-place-as-of-march-25-update-23
notes_C2: Some businesses reopen, but: ·  Movie theatres are to remain closed  ·  All commercial sports gymnasiums, fitness studios, swimming pools and recreational activities are to remain closed   ·  The activities of all restaurants, tourist facilities and places for serving food and beverages are to remain limited to external orders and delivery services  ·  Shisha Cafes are to remain closed. Services offered by these cafes are to remain limited to takeout and delivery of food and beverages only  ·  Salons are to remain closed  ·  All non-essential medical services provided by private health clinics are to remain suspended.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607234941/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4101
notes_C4: Any social gathering or private event held at home, and private locations, with more than 30 individuals is prohibited.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423134448/https://healthalert.gov.bh/en/article/the-national-medical-taskforce-for-combating-the-coronavirus-covid-19-11-03-2021
notes_H3: Bahrain records first case and starts extensive contact tracing as per press release. Bahrain later issues database of all positive cases and lists the contact tracing undertaken, usually up to the point "all known contacts traced"; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607220703/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/3753; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607220901/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/ContactsTracing
notes_E1: Under the leadership of HM the King and under the direction of HRH the Crown Prince, the ministers announced an eight-point economic package that commits the government to: 1. Referring a draft law concerning paying the salaries of all private sector employees for three months from April 2020 from the unemployment fund, following constitutional procedures and in line with the Social Insurance Law.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607231055/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/3969
notes_C1: Following the recommendations presented to the Government Executive Committee, the National Medical Taskforce for Combating the Coronavirus (COVID-19) today announced a number of decisions to be implemented starting from Sunday, 14 March 2021, as follows:    •                     The resumption of in-person learning at public and private schools, higher education institutions, public and private universities, kindergartens licensed by the Ministry of Education, public rehabilitation centres affiliated with the Ministry of Labour and Social Development, nurseries, private training centres and institutes licensed by the Ministry of Labour and Social Development. In-person learning is optional and will be at the discretion of parents or guardians.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322142644/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4670
notes_H7: Dr. Al Manea noted that the Kingdom’s vaccine uptake plan is evolving, but remains focussed on reaching vulnerable citizens at greatest risk of developing complications from COVID-19, including those over 70 and those with underlying conditions or with a BMI of 25 and above.  Al Salman urged everyone to register for vaccination by visiting https://healthalert.gov.bh/en/ including pregnant women and breastfeeding mothers who are able to be vaccinated safely.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322150229/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4673
notes_C5: Is public transportation operating? Yes     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402235157/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Bahamas
notes_H1: The government’s ‘Covid Bahamas’ website, dedicated to publishing up to date Covid-19 information, was first updated on the 27th February. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201116173746/https://covid19.gov.bs/bahamas-covid-dashboard-27-february-2020/
notes_H2: The Ministry of Health COVID-19 Frequently Asked Questions and Answers document published on the 4th March declared testing capacity: “If cases of COVID-19 are confirmed in The Bahamas, is the country prepared? Yes. The Ministry of Health has developed and distributed the Novel Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Plan to healthcare facilities and stakeholders. Meetings to discuss the plan with multiple agencies are ongoing. Personal Protective Equipment and laboratory testing is available, quarantine/isolation sites are continually being identified. The Ministry of Health will keep the public updated.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201110124205/https://www.bahamas.gov.bs/wps/wcm/connect/6c416b87-180f-48ef-b034-a8dad4097822/FAQ+COVID-19+Revised+04.03+%281%29.pdf?MOD=AJPERES
notes_C7: or visitors staying four (4) nights and five (5) days or longer, on Day 5 of the visit, a COVID-19 Rapid Antigen Test must be taken by any individual who enters The Bahamas or who travels inter-island from New Providence, Grand Bahama, Harbour Island or Eleuthera and the results must be submitted to the Ministry of Health online via the health travel website.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419204909/https://bs.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic) (No.2) Order, 2020.” made by the Prime Minister on the 22nd July states:  “(4) A person is not required to wear a face mask while —  (a) exercising but is required to have a face mask visibly in his possession and easily accessible;  (b) on a beach but must wear a face mask when approaching and after exiting the beach.”   These are new exceptions to the face mask wearing requirements which were already in place:  “(1) Every person who leaves his residence shall, while away from his residence wear a face mask, which fits securely to his face, covering his nose and mouth.  (2) Any person who is found not wearing a face mask in accordance with this order commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of two hundred dollars or to a term of one month imprisonment or to both such fine and imprisonment or to both such fine and imprisonment”  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201116124705/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/EmergencyPowersCovid19PandemicNo.2-Order-2020-Final.pdf
notes_E2: As of April 2, The Central Bank of The Bahamas (CBOB) has arranged with domestic banks and credit unions to provide a 3-month deferral against repayments on credit facilities for businesses and households that were negatively impacted by the pandemic. Some financial institutions announced credit support extending well beyond the 3-month period.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210406201349/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic) (Lockdown) Order, 2020”, made on August 4th, applies to all Islands of The Bahamas. It “shall expire at 5:00 am on Wednesday the 19th day of August, 2020” on all islands, except for the island of Grand Bahama because “this order shall cease to apply to Grand Bahama at 5:00 am on Friday the 7th day of August, 2020”. This includes the required closure of all non-essential workplaces. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102195629/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Emergency-Powers-Covid-19-Pandemic-Lockdown-Order-2020.pdf  Also, from the 10th of August the “Order shall cease to apply to islands of Inagua, Mayaguana, Crooked Island, Acklins, Long Cay, Long Island, Chub Cay, Rum Cay, and Ragged Island”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102200158/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/EMERGENCY..ORDER_..NO_.3.pdf
notes_C6: On the August 9th, EYEWITNESS NEWS, reported that  “Prime Minister Dr Hubert Minnis today announced lockdown and curfew measures will be lifted for eight islands tomorrow [August 10th].  Normal commercial activity, including church services, beaches and parks will resume on those islands at 5am on Monday.  These include: Mayaguana, Inagua, Crooked Island, Acklins, Long Cay, Long Island, Rum Cay, and Ragged Island.  “The lockdown and curfew has been lifted for these islands because health officials have not recorded any specific COVID-19 activity on these locations for at least two weeks,” he said.” Source: https://archive.vn/vUnt2
notes_C8: International commercial flights are available  Travelers must obtain a negative COVID-19 RT-PCR (swab) test taken no more than five days prior to the date of arrival  Children aged ten and under are not required to take a test  Travelers have to apply for a Bahamas Travel Health Visa at travel.gov.bs  As part of the Travel Health Visa application, travelers are required to opt-in for COVID-19 health insurance that covers them for the duration of their stay in The Bahamas  Travel Ban on Haiti extended until 14 May  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419205038/https://intelyse.com/coronavirus-travel-restrictions/
notes_C2: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic)(No. 6) Order, 2020” was made on September 10th.  Non-essential workplaces are now permitted to open on Second Schedule islands except   “(a) a casino, bar, discotheque, cinema, museum, library, historical society and other cultural or entertainment facility;  (b) a regatta, festival, fair, play, performance art and other cultural or entertainment event;  (c) the occasional sale of prepared meals commonly known as a cook out, steak out or souse out;  (d) a spa;  (e) a gym; and  (f) a craft or straw market vendor, and a jet ski operator.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102203048/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Emergency-Powers-Covid-19-Pandemic-No.-6-Order-2020.pdf
notes_C4: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic) (Lockdown) Order, 2020”, made on August 4th, applies to all Islands of The Bahamas. It “shall expire at 5:00 am on Wednesday the 19th day of August, 2020” on all islands, except for the island of Grand Bahama because “this order shall cease to apply to Grand Bahama at 5:00 am on Friday the 7th day of August, 2020”.  “No person, except an essential worker for a business or establishment specified in paragraph (2), shall leave his place of residence for any purpose whatsoever, other than for —  (a) the purpose of seeking urgent medical care at a hospital specified in paragraph (2); or  (b) travel to secure groceries, gas, pharmaceuticals, water or to any businesses or undertakings permitted to open in order 5; or  (c) any activity permitted by this Order.”  Permitted activities don’t include private gatherings. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102195629/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Emergency-Powers-Covid-19-Pandemic-Lockdown-Order-2020.pdf  Also, from the 10th of August the “Order shall cease to apply to islands of Inagua, Mayaguana, Crooked Island, Acklins, Long Cay, Long Island, Chub Cay, Rum Cay, and Ragged Island”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102200158/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/EMERGENCY..ORDER_..NO_.3.pdf
notes_H3: On the 18th March, there was a “Communication on COVID-19” “by Dr. the Hon Duane E. L. Sands, M.P., Minister of Health.” “Mr. Speaker, the National Reference Laboratory confirmed a positive result in the late hours of 14th March, 2020.” “Many health professionals and other Bahamians are working very hard, often long hours, to limit the spread of COVID-19. The Ministry’s Surveillance Unit has aggressively undertaken contact tracing activities for this case.” “This first case triggered the operationalization of our Health Disaster Plan, and the full activation of the Health Emergency Operation Centre (EOC)”, which includes testing “suspected cases and close contacts of confirmed cases”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123180533/https://www.ub.edu.bs/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Communication-to-Parliament-COVID-19-in-The-Bahamas.pdf
notes_E1: As of April 2, B$145 million for income support has been issued for job loss workers and self-employed.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210406201349/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H8: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19)(No. 2) Order, 2020…shall come into force at 9:00 a.m. on the 24th March, 2020 and shall expire at 9:00 a.m. on the 31st March.  “A curfew is imposed every day for twenty-four hours except as provided herein or as may be approved by the Commissioner of Police.”  “Every non-essential establishment, or business shall remain closed except for the following —  (a) wholesale or retail grocery stores and Farmers’ Markets from 6:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., the first two shopping hours to be reserved for seniors, disabled persons and essential workers”  This policy protects the elderly because it limits their potential exposure to Covid-19 while carrying out essential activities.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102182750/https://opm.gov.bs/emergency-powers-covid-19-no-2-order-2020/
notes_C1: Higher education institutions are open while primary and secondary schools remain closed.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210406195611/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H7: Groups eligible for vaccine:   • Healthcare workers;  • Persons 60 years of age and older;  • Uniformed branches (RBDF, RBPF, COVID Ambassadors, BDOCS, Customs and Immigration);  • Teachers and staff of schools;  • Hospitality workers (hotel and resort employees, public transportation workers, Lynden Pindling International Airport (LPIA), Nassau Airport Development (NAD) Co., Nassau Cruise Port (NCP), straw market, port and beach vendors and tour operators);  • Students and athletes studying or competing abroad, coaches and other support;   • Home-bound physically disabled residents.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210413134049/https://opm.gov.bs/more-priority-groups-and-vaccination-centers-added-to-covid-19-vaccine-roll-out/  Vaccine: Oxford-AstraZeneca  http://web.archive.org/web/20210406200544/https://bs.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: “Emergency Powers (Covid 19 Pandemic)(No. 6) Order, 2020.”  “Part V - Miscellaneous”  “This part shall apply to the islands specified in First Schedule and the Second Schedule.  50. Public transportation.  A —  (a) taxi service; or  (b) private and public bus service may operate, provided that such service shall be operated at fifty percent occupancy,   subject to guidelines issued by the Ministry of Tourism and approved by the Ministry of Health.”   The First and Second Schedules can be found on page 29 and page 30.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210102203048/https://higgsjohnson.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Emergency-Powers-Covid-19-Pandemic-No.-6-Order-2020.pdf

name: Bosnia and Herzegovina
notes_H1: Ministry of Health has a public information site, with the first report published on January 31st. https://web.archive.org/web/20200416231119/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/
notes_H2: 'Three Chinese citizens were admitted to the Sarajevo University Medical Centre and are being tested for the coronavirus, the head of the Centre, Sebija Izetbegovic, said at a press conference on Tuesday [25th February]'.       http://web.archive.org/web/20200416103146/https://balkaneu.com/several-suspicious-but-not-confirmed-cases-of-coronavirus-in-bih/
notes_C7: “Movement Restrictions: Is a curfew in place? No. Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200829101240/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: As of March 29, 2020, the Federation began requiring all persons on the street or in public areas to cover their mouth and nose with a mask or scarf; in the RS, all persons must also wear gloves in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201002061401/https://www.osac.gov/Country/BosniaHerzegovina/Content/Detail/Report/735ec25f-20ef-4ff9-bb52-1858fa23ff5b
notes_E2: Banking Agencies have announced a six-month loan repayment moratorium for restructuring credit arrangements for individuals and legal entities which are found to have aggravated circumstances for loans repayments due to COVID-19. Banking Agencies have instructed banks to track clients and exposure portfolios affected by COVID-19. Banks are also instructed to consider additional customer relief, including reviewing current fees for services and avoiding charging fees to handle exposure modifications. All banks were ordered not to pay dividends or bonuses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109060549/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:   Public gatherings of more than 30 people outdoors and indoors are prohibited. Parliament's sittings are excluded from this. Exceptionally, no more than 70 people may be present in theatres and cinemas. Organizers are obliged to register all planned events with the cantonal Ministry of Health. Competition activities for sports clubs and athletes may only take place without an audience.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Republika Srpska:   All public gatherings with more than 50 people are prohibited.  All private gatherings (weddings, baptisms and birthday parties, family meetings, etc.) with more than 10 people are prohibited.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Brcko District: On 3 November, public gatherings in closed spaces were banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102174538/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/bosniaandherzegovina/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section    (22 Nov) religious gatherings (funerals, holidays) as well as weddings limited to 30 persons.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/
notes_C6: Since 11/11/2020, an exit lock is in place from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina,   Since 22/11/2020, an exit lock is in place in the Brcko district from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m.  No specific stay-at-home policy in Republika Srpska and Canton of Sarajevo.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_C8: US Citizens and British Nationals, including those with residence in Bosnia and Herzegovina, need a negative COVID-19 (PCR) test result that is not older than 48 hours. Some groups are exempt from this rule, including: diplomats accredited to and resident in Bosnia and Herzegovina, EUFOR/NATO staff, freight drivers and crew, and foreigners in transit to their country of residence. Changes to restrictions may be introduced at short notice. You should comply with any screening measures put in place by the authorities. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200921174139/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bosnia-and-herzegovina/entry-requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829101240/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/save/https://blog.wego.com/covid19-travel-restrictions-by-destination-country/
notes_C2: Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:  Night clubs and discos will remain closed until further notice. Restaurants are allowed to remain open until 11 p.m. All services must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them. From 5.11.2020, all legal persons, i.e. companies, in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina are obliged to set flexible working hours in the work processes they perform and, where possible, to introduce teleworking.     Republika Srpska  All legal entities, i.e. companies, and public administration are invited to organise the work as a teleworking wherever possible. Opening hours for catering establishments are from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., with live music prohibited. A minimum of 10 m2 of space must be available for each table with a maximum of 4 people. The opening hours of gambling operators (casinos, vending machines and similar ones) must be reduced to 10 p.m. The so-called "drugstores" (small grocery stores), which are usually open 24H, are only allowed to sell counters after 10 p.m. All shops and businesses must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them.    Brko District  From 7.12.2020, opening hours of catering establishments, fitness centres, gambling operators, sports schools are limited to 7 p.m.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_C4: Private gatherings restricted to max. 10 people. Up to 25 people for funerals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210416085142/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_E1: The RS also announced that the government will pay minimum salaries for all employees in these sectors in April (KM 53 million, 0.16 percent of GDP) and is planning to increase the transfers to unemployment funds (KM 25 million, 0.08 percent of GDP). The FBiH plans to subsidize contributions and taxes and pay minimum wages for all employees of the companies impacted by COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109060549/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H8: Sarajevo Canton:  Ban on visiting nursing homes in Sarajevo Canton due to the increased number of infected persons in Sarajevo and suspicion of infection of one of the employees of the nursing home in Sarajevo.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/
notes_C1: Cannot find a specific policy of school closure in any entities of the country  The new school year 2020/2021 in BiH started with combined teaching programmes (classroom teaching and online classes). Teaching is conducted in smaller groups of pupils, with shorter  classes and respect of strict sanitary rules (wearing masks is obligatory for teaching staff, and  recommended for pupils.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201024193117/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf
notes_H7: Officially vaccines to be delivered via Covax. Enough has been ordered for 20% of the population, but limited supplies have arrived.   Vaccine donations from Serbia (of Sputnik and AZ vaccines) have been offered to key health workers and people over 65 (Rep. Srpska) and over 75 (Federation Bonsnia & Hergegovina) (Groups: A, B, C)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423075603/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_C5: According to OECD, in the FBiH the public transportation became operational again, meaning that public transport is now running across the whole country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200528100802/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf

name: Belarus
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health is launching a campaign "New Year - Home Holiday" aimed at holding safe New Year holidays.  The purpose of the pre-holiday campaign is to convince the public of the need to comply with safety measures during the COVID-19 pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228095550/https://www.belta.by/society/view/minzdrav-zapuskaet-aktsiju-novyj-god-domashnij-prazdnik-421644-2020/
notes_H2: more than 65,000 COVID-19 tests are currently available
notes_H6: On 5 November, Mogilev became the first city in Belarus to introduce compulsory use of facial masks in public places.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210143542/https://news.tut.by/society/706859.html    On 5 November, Mogilev became the first city in Belarus to introduce compulsory use of facial masks in public places.    On 9 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Gomel Region.    According to the 11 November Ministry of Health decree, PCR-based tests were no longer conducted for first-level contacts with an asymptomatic infection course.    On 12 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Minsk. As of date, besides Minsk, Gomel Region and Mogilev, such measure was reported to had been employed in Babruisk, Asipovichy, Klichev, Krichev, Chavusy District, Cherykaw District, Polotsk District and Novopolotsk.    On 16 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Vitebsk Region.    On 18 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Brest Region.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210143604/https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Belarus
notes_C3: No change in policy. http://web.archive.org/web/20210307164817/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belarus/coronavirus
notes_C8: Travellers from Greenlane countries are permitted to enter Belarus subject to a 10 day quarantine.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502220159/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belarus/entry-requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502220211/https://trutrip.co/covidentrycheck/travel-restrictions/europe/belarus
notes_H3: 1st and 2nd level contacts being traced.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200517231426/https://news.tut.by/society/679921.html
notes_H8: No new specific measures to protect the elderly announced on either the official governemental website or Belarus' specific Covid portal:    http://web.archive.org/web/20210127110835/http://stopcovid.belta.by/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210127111017/https://www.belarus.by/en/    (old links of previous entry)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210120120122/http://stopcovid.belta.by/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210120120128/https://www.belarus.by/en
notes_C1: "On Monday (20th), [the president] allowed the country’s schools to reopen after an extended spring break."  However, "[...] authorities allowed parents to keep their children at home even though the government has steered clear of closures and restrictions on public movement amid the country’s expanding coronavirus outbreak. [...]. As voluntary actions do not fall under the new C1 regulation, I've decided to keep the level on a general 0.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200517225810/https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/politics/2020/04/21/the-latest-the-coronavirus-cancels-oktoberfest-in-germany/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201105125231/https://apnews.com/article/3e53f7e4d840375c70f62847f968ad43
notes_H7: “A new stage starts in Belarus today with mass vaccinations (Sputnik V) against COVID-19. Medical staff and teachers, will be the first to get vaccinated (tachers later on, however, see below). Vaccination will be entirely voluntary,” Belarus Health Minister Dmitry Pinevich was quoted as saying in a statement issued by his ministry and Russian health authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104125657/https://apnews.com/article/belarus-coronavirus-pandemic-latin-america-auto-racing-glance-russia-fcddcc286f8295421c0ff301c242dad0    "Now we continue vaccinating healthcare workers. We expect the next batch to arrive in the near future. Teachers will be next in line for a COVID-19 vaccine. In the first quarter of this year, we are set to release the Sputnik V vaccine under the Belarusian brand, together with Russian colleagues at the Belarus-based Belmedpreparaty pharmaceutical company,”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120121234/https://eng.belta.by/society/view/minister-pneumonia-cases-keep-declining-in-belarus-136636-2021/    Unable to find evidence regarding funding so have recorded government funded for now, as vaccine is voluntary and only available to certain groups, suggesting that it couldn't be purchased privately (individually funded)

name: Belize
notes_H1: "The Ministry of Health advises the public to be guided by facts. To stay informed and updated on the evolving COVID-19 situation, follow the Facebook pages of the Ministry of Health, the Office of the Director of Health Services, and the Government Press Office.  The Ministry of Health will continue to provide timely updates as our response changes to this evolving situation."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200430161753/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1016-ministry-of-health-advisory-no-5--covid-19
notes_H2: "At this time COVID-19 testing is only being done people who have been identified through Ministry of Health contact mapping or present themselves with COVID-19 symptoms" - as of 1st Sept 2020
notes_C7: "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Tourists visiting Belize can move about freely, however it is recommended that they remain within the Tourism Safe Corridor.  The Safe Corridor includes Gold Standard certified accommodations, tour operators, tourism transportation providers, restaurants, tourism sites and attractions, and gift shops.  These Gold Standard and certified entities have all been trained and have implemented enhanced health and safety measures."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312165455/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Statutory Instrument 65 states from 1st May:  "every person in a public place, public space, or public office or building shall wear a face mask or other face (mouth) covering;"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200830131649/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-No-65-of-2020-Belize-Constitution-1.pdf?fbclid=IwAR1NmEevhEGOZmhhy2t3FTQEY-FbCOwCm3gdn2-6cOtjd-9DzYbN2ho2BFM    https://web.archive.org/web/20200830131055/https://www.sanpedrosun.com/politics-and-government/2020/06/30/state-of-emergency-expires-certain-restrictions-remain/  "Peyrefitte added that the only time face masks can be excluded is when someone is at home, driving in their vehicle, persons participating in church services would not be required to wear masks but are asked to practice social distancing. Also a mask is not needed when eating at a restaurant, while exercising, and participating in sporting events, to name a few. In the case of face masks, failure to use them in public places can end in an arrest and charge."
notes_E2: "liquidity support through postponements of social security and tax payments for companies and self-employed"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200723165805/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Downgraded to 1G because the cut off point changes from 10 people to a specific percentage of original capacity (50%).    “Churches, social events, and private parties that would include guests outside of the immediate family who are living together are limited to no more 50% of building capacity.”  Source: U.S. Embassy in Belize  https://web.archive.org/web/20210421210944/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: The stay at home order has been enhanced due to the increase in cases as per the US Embassy in Belize. People will be fined for being in public spaces, unless to visit select places.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210210012855/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: No longer require mandatory self-quarantine for any Belizean, permanent resident,  holder of a valid work permit, Qualified Retired Person,  the foreign homeowner or long stay non-national who enters  Belize through the airport due to repeal of Amendment 20, section 1 on October 19, 2020  Latest press release  http://web.archive.org/web/20201022043048/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-No-149-of-2020-Quarantine-rev.pdf  Regulations that this press release refers to:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022043541/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-136-2020-Quarantine.pdf
notes_C2: The Government of Belize has announced that the nationwide State of Emergency ended on Friday 4 September. Regulations remain in force to prevent, control, contain and suppress the spread of coronavirus. Restaurants can open for delivery, take away or drive through only. Spas, beauty salons and barbershops are allowed to operate with appointment only subject to social distance protocols.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200913115634/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belize/coronavirus
notes_C4: Recorded as 0 because the restrictions on gatherings are based on the capacity of indoor spaces (up to 50% of the capacity).     “Churches, social events, and private parties that would include guests outside of the immediate family who are living together are limited to no more 50% of building capacity.”  Source: U.S. Embassy in Belize  https://web.archive.org/web/20210421210944/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: No policy changes. Comprehensive contact tracing still in place.    “Contact tracing is a control measure used by the Ministry of Health to prevent further spread of COVID-19. It slows the spread by: a) Letting people know they may have been exposed to COVID-19 and should monitor their health for signs and symptoms of COVID-19; b) Helping people who may have been exposed to COVID-19 get tested; c) Asking persons to self-isolate if they have COVID-19 or self-quarantine if they are a close contact of someone with COVID-19”  Source: Government of Belize Press Office  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315222742/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/MOH-FAQs-on-COVID-19.docx.pdf
notes_E1: There are two income subsidy schemes in place: “COVID-19 Unemployment Relief Program” (albeit closed to further application) and the “Micro Small and Medium Enterprise (MSME) Support Program”. There is also a social assistance programme: the “Belize COVID-19 Cash transfer program”.     Source: Government of Belize COVID-19 website  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117010348/https://www.covid19.bz/covid-support-programs/     Source: Government of Belize Press Office   https://web.archive.org/web/20210422122418/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/URP-Phase-Two-FAQs.pdf     Source: Government of Belize Press Office   https://web.archive.org/web/20210422122447/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/MSME-Support-Program-FAQs.pdf     Source: Government of Belize Press Office   https://web.archive.org/web/20210422122516/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Dec-15-Frequently-Asked-Questions-The-Belize-COVID19-Cash-Transfer-Program.pdf
notes_H8: As early as March 18,  Ix-Chel Poot, the Executive Director of the National Council of Ageing (statutory government body) stated the following on national TV:  "One of the first things that we want families to take seriously is that if you have been ill or been contact with some who has been ill is to practice social distancing. As we can see with the experience internationally the coronavirus is deadly for people sixty plus. We are looking at practicing social distancing. You can keep in contact with your older persons via phone, text. Or putting in place the measures in your home to maintain good hygiene. Even keeping up with the hand washing and the disinfecting. And if the older person in your home has an underlying health condition to ensure that his health condition is under control, diabetes, hypertension and that they have the medication that is necessary on hand. We are also stressing that if the older person in you care shows any signs or symptoms to contact the Ministry of Health hotline because there is no time to see what it will develop in that older person.”    Moreover, the National Council for Aging started a registration drive to identify every elder in need, partly so that they can receive additional support such as food assistance (in order to not put them at risk because they have to go buy groceries).    https://web.archive.org/web/20200319163249/https://edition.channel5belize.com/archives/200087  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205180000/https://www.facebook.com/plustvbelize/videos/252374795888128/
notes_C1: Starting on March 20, the PM and leader of opposition announced that all schools to be closed for 14 days leading into the Easter Break. Measures announced on March 17 following first meeting of the COVID-19 National Oversight Committee.    See Belize national press office for more information:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200527181132/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/government-announces-new-measures-in-response-to-covid-19/
notes_H7: AstraZeneca vaccine is available in Belize according to the US Embassy to all 3 groups (Key workers, Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly), Elderly groups)   https://web.archive.org/web/20210408220510/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: Downgraded to 0 because the only requirement is the use of masks and social distancing.    “Is public transportation operating? Yes. All passengers are required to wear a facemask and observe social distancing.”  Source: U.S. Embassy in Belize  https://web.archive.org/web/20210421210944/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Bermuda
notes_H1: The Government of Bermuda began press releases to the general public on January 22, 2020. The Government has also released videos and resource materials.  Archived Source: /web/20200402155519/https://www.gov.bm/articles/current-threat-coronavirus-bermuda-residents-low
notes_H2: The testing schedule is regularly updated. It no longer appears to be restricted to symptomatic patients.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130003747/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-get-tested
notes_C7: No restrictions on internal movement    https://web.archive.org/web/20200916170209/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Masks must be worn indoors, but outdoors only when physical distancing cannot be maintained.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201017211320/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-phase4-guidance
notes_E2: No documentation suggests that utilities disconnection protection remains in place. Debt relief appears to have been reduced to 0.
notes_C3: The maximum permitted number of people in any group will be reduced further to ten. http://web.archive.org/web/20201215001740/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministerial-statement-covid-19-%E2%80%93-need-further-action
notes_C6: Curfew in place, 12.00-05.00.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210322233345/https://www.google.com/search?q=bermuda+curfew+covid&rlz=1CAXGER_enGB863&oq=bermuda+curfew+covid&aqs=chrome..69i57j0j0i457j0l7.6563j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8
notes_C8: Residents /Visitors are required to quarantine at home or in their accommodation until they receive a negative arrival test.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028234041/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-travellers   http://web.archive.org/web/20201028235035/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: Policy: Remote working will continue to be required. However, retail stores (including pet stores) and restaurants are open to curb-side, take-out, and delivery service only. Grocery stores and gas stations must operate with no more than 20% capacity and must abide by an alphabet system further describe in the cited source.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212216/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions
notes_C4: March 28: Gatherings limited to 10 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401074836/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions
notes_H3: Policy: The contact tracing backlog was resolved. The policy thereby remains that once a person is identified as being exposed or has a positive covid -19 test they will be contacted by a contact tracer.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426221140/https://www.gov.bm/quarantine-contact-tracing
notes_E1: The Ministry of Finance has renewed the unemployment benefit support for individual workers, and payments up to a maximum of $500 per week. (Average monthly income in Bermuda: approx. $1600).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401080135/https://bernews.com/2021/03/applications-can-be-filed-unemployment-benefit/
notes_H8: See link for COVID-19 - Care Home Guidance Version 2 - November 2020  http://web.archive.org/web/20201215014432/https://www.gov.bm/sites/default/files/Care%20Home%20Guidance%20201106.pdf
notes_C1: Ministry of Education: "Easter Break 2021 will commence on Monday, March 29, instead of Thursday, April 1. Students will return to schools as normal on Monday, April 12." (aka. 4 day school closure).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401073224/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministry-education-public-schools-covid-19-update-23-march-2020
notes_H7: A,B,C: key workers, over 65s, identified vulnerable groups. Pfizer.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322223920/https://bernews.com/2021/03/29-of-population-had-one-dose-18-had-two/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322223940/https://www.gov.bm/covid-19-vaccine-allocation-strategy
notes_C5: On 15 April 2021: “Ministry of Transport confirmed that bus service resumed … and urged people ...to only utilise the Bermuda bus service if necessary...Buses are currently following the Sunday schedule ...We stress the importance of sanitizing your hands, keeping your mask on for the duration of your journey, and adhering to the physical distancing symbols on the seats.” See Bermuda news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419143011/https://bernews.com/2021/04/transport-ministry-bus-service-has-resumed/

name: Bolivia
notes_H1: Governmental line to give people information over corona.  "The National Government presented today the number of the toll free line 800-10-1104 for the attention and consultations of the population about the coronavirus."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729150003/https://www.minsalud.gob.bo/3974-gobierno-habilita-linea-gratuita-800-10-1104-para-consultas-sobre-el-coronavirus
notes_H2: PCR tests widely available but antigen testing still unavailable. Regulation of COVID-19 testing subject to Servicio Departamental de Salud (SEDES)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215173137/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: No restrictions on intercity and interstate movements.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210110112457/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Required in all public places   https://web.archive.org/web/20201218104825/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: No additional allocation of debt/contract relief   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Cultural, sporting, social and religious activities, electoral and recreational processes that generate crowds are permitted subject to biosecurity measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184300/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#C
notes_C6: Curfew not in place.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210110112457/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: After conducting an evaluation of the epidemiological situation in the country's border area, the Government decided to extend the closure of borders with Brazil from today until April 16, due to the threat of a new variant of COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412190325/https://www.minsalud.gob.bo/5443-bolivia-amplia-cierre-de-fronteras-con-brasil-y-determina-medidas-y-restricciones-frente-a-la-covid-19  Flight restrictions from Europe have been lifted. Passengers arriving from all countries require a PCR test taken up to 72 hours before flying and is required for everybody over 5-years of age to enter Bolivia. On arrival you must quarantine for 10 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412190557/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bolivia/coronavirus
notes_C2: Restrictions on working hours have been lifted and commercial activities are permitted to operate on a continuous basis.   Departmental and municipal governments will determine commercial activity and other services not governed by the national decree and may add restrictions as needed by local conditions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184300/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#C
notes_C4: Suspension of restrictions    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207174911/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A "family basket" of 400 Bolivians in cash that will be provided to those who are on welfare and a family bonus of 500 Bolivians for families with children in kinder garden and elementary school. Both policies will reach 7 million Bolivian citizens.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200731162440/https://www1.abi.bo/abi_/?i=447684
