notes_H1: ‘Manthabiseng National Convention Centre has been identified as designated National Command Centre for Coronavirus (COVID-19). All the information about COVID-19 will be coordinated and accessed from this centre so that the public can be only provided with credible information. Meanwhile, a budget of M60 million targeting information dissemination and human resource emprovement amongst others has also been proposed in this regard and it emerged during this meeting  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506104855/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-government-identifies-national-command-centre-for-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506103816/https://www.gov.ls/about-coronavirus-covid-19/
notes_H2: Any health personnel who has been exposed to a confirmed case of Covid-19 shall be subjected to testing and self-isolation https://web.archive.org/web/20200615181342/https://www.gov.ls/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/PUBLIC-HEALTH-COVID-19-REGULATIONS-PDF.pdf A person allowed to enter the country during the period of lockdown shall be subject to screening at the designated point of entry, screening shall be done on people who travelled to affected countries.
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on interzonal or intercity travel within Lesotho. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1    See also US embassy information for more clarity: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315120010/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/
notes_H6: Not sure why this might be coded as 1G. according to the UK FCO website for Lesotho, anyone leaving their place of residence in Lesotho must wear a mask or face covering. This includes in public and private vehicles, walking in the street, and in shops and public offices. See https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus. Also, from the IMF policy response website, see: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 (web archive unavailable, accessed 21 September 2020)
notes_E2: No debt relief noted on government sites or IMF. Government funding focuses on health and prevention.  Government looking for private sector to help with relief.  "The IMF reports that the Governments has funded their current COVID response from the existing health care budget, and has been focused on  health care and prevention. The  Government has also called for private sector support, and Banking Sector in the country has contributed M2 million towards the National Response to Coronavirus (COVID-19). As of the 4th of April there are no fiscal policy measures. However, the Central Bank of Lesotho (CBL) announced it will (1) increase of the NIR target floor from US$630 million to US$660 million, and (ii) reduce the CBL rate by 100 basis points from 6.25 per cent to 5.25 per cent  per annum. "  https://web.archive.org/web/20201023140517/https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1s46Oz_NtkyrowAracg9FTPYRdkP8GHRzQqM7w6Qa_2k/edit?ts=5e836726
notes_C3: All public events cancelled. Exceptions made for church services, with a maximum of 50 people inside and 100 people outside and mask-wearing requirements.    See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).  See also NACOSEC twitter communications (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-071252/https://twitter.com/nacosec?lang=en).
notes_C6: Curfew from 8PM to 5AM.    See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).  See also NACOSEC twitter communications (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-071252/https://twitter.com/nacosec?lang=en).
notes_C8: Some land borders and Moshoeshoe I airport open. Open only for restricted groups: teachers and students crossing daily and registered entrepreneurs. Otherwise bans from arrivals still apply. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
notes_C2: Workplaces such as retail stores, grocery stores, cafes, salons, banks and communication companies open from 8AM until 6PM. Other businesses, private and NGO institutions permitted to operate with 50% capacity and staff under rotation. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
notes_C4: All social and family gatherings restricted.     See the prime minister's announcement of Lesotho moving to a more stringent "orange stage" on 6 January 2021 (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-070838/https://www.gov.ls/lesotho-moves-back-to-orange-colour/).  See also NACOSEC twitter communications (http://archive.today/2021.01.08-071252/https://twitter.com/nacosec?lang=en).
notes_H3: No change.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301095534/https://www.pih.org/article/local-health-systems-key-responding-global-covid-19-pandemic-and-beyond
notes_H8: Lesotho is under “Orange Level” restrictions. From midnight on 3 February, everyone must remain at their place of residence except when accessing or providing essential goods and services. A curfew is in place from 9pm to 5am.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212141240/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
notes_C1: Schools open on a rotational basis, adhering to Standard Risk-Based Guidelines. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
notes_H7: A  25 March 2021 - COVID-19 vaccine launch in Lesotho—health workers the 1st group vaccinated!  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329062311/https://www.afro.who.int/news/covid-19-vaccine-launch-lesotho-health-workers-1st-group-vaccinated  3 March 2021 - Lesotho received the 36,000 doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine via COVAX, a multilateral vaccine initiative backed by the World Health Organization (WHO), according to the agency and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329081512/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/africa/2021-03/04/c_139782368.htm
notes_C5: Public transport is open and operating at full capacity. No further changes in policy after announcement of adjusted blue stage regulations on 22 March. Coded as such according to the coding interpretation guidelines.     See the NACOSEC twitter announcement (National Covid-19 Secretariat):  https://archive.vn/Dkj3M

name: Lithuania
notes_H1: On 1 June, a nationwide campaign ‘Thank You, Lithuania’ to take place to show gratitude to the Lithuanian people for the successful efforts in overcoming the first wave of COVID-19 and to ask them to continue staying focused and hopeful, so as to be ready to confront any other challenges lying do it again.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200611135425/http://lrv.lt/en/news/thank-you-lithuania-campaign-in-honour-of-all-those-who-have-helped-to-overcome-first-wave-of-coronavirus    Moreover, the government is publishing extensive information about the virus and implemented measures via a special website, set-up only for topics of the pandemic:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125101901/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/
notes_H2: The Health Ministry said that all people experiencing cold-like symptoms associated with the coronavirus could now be tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200527113044/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1156515/when-to-get-tested-for-covid-19-new-rules-in-lithuania-explained
notes_C7: No restrictions on internal movement, however lockdown still in effect.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502212410/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lithuania/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502212410/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lithuania/coronavirus
notes_H6: From the 21st of February, wearing facemasks will not be mandatory in outdoor public spaces as long as people can remain at least 2 metres apart.
notes_E2: Variety of measures implemented.  Among others:    • To extend the deferral period for payments of residential loans (excluding interest) from 3 to 6 months in the form of a state guarantee for those who have lost their jobs.    • Make it possible to defer the contributions or pay them by installments for electricity and natural gas to AB Ignitis.    • Recommend that municipalities should offer a possibility to defer public utility payments and payments for heat energy or pay them by installments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107145102/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-1
notes_C3: From the 19th of April, cultural events will be permitted up to 150 spectators.  Non-cultural/commercial events that do not fulfil the inclusion criteria are not permitted.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205318/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205318/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_C6: No message to stay at home. Non-essential services and retail begun reopening on the 19th of April.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502212410/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lithuania/coronavirus
notes_C8: People returning / arriving from affected countries are subjects to 10-day isolation. Isolation does not apply to those who have a negative test for COVID-19 performed not earlier than 48 hours ago.    You can also be tested in Lithuania. In this case, isolation applies to you until a negative laboratory test is obtained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107143201/https://nvsc.lrv.lt/en/information-on-covid-19/for-arrivals-from-abroad
notes_C2: From the 26th of April, gyms and sports facilities may open if they provide 20 sq m per person.   Group exercise is permitted (5 people +1 instructor)  Pools and saunas may open, limited to one household use at a time.   Pools may open for school children.     Work from home recommendation is still in place for those who can.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205239/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/lithuania-enacts-lockdown-exit-plan-7708  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205318/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_C4: Lithuania’s government on Wednesday declared a three-week lockdown starting on Nov.7 (extended end of November), to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus which has accelerated in recent weeks in the Baltic nation.    Public groups of more than 5 people will be banned and no more than 10 people will be allowed at marriages or funerals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201114114424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-lithuania/update-1-lithuania-to-enter-three-week-covid-lockdown-on-saturday-idINL8N2HQ525    See also for official communication:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202092539/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-25-november-2020
notes_H3: On 23rd of February 2021  NVSC stated that over the past week its tracers on average reached 90% of people tested positive for COVID-19 within 24 hours to interview them about route of infection and contacts.(17)    From 29th of March 2021, the designated dashboard provides an interactive map of COVID-19 outbreaks (two or more related cases), based on tracing conducted by epidemiologists at the National Center for Public Health: https://nvsc.lrv.lt/lt/naujienos/sukurtas-interaktyvus-covid-19-protrukiu-zemelapis    http://web.archive.org/web/20210413095845/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/lithuania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Chapter
notes_E1: When an emergency situation or quarantine is declared, remote work is not always possible, so in complicated situations employers may announce downtime or partial downtime, and the State is ready to contribute to the payment of wages to employees.    When an enterprise declares inactivity due to an emergency or quarantine, the worker shall receive at least the minimum monthly salary and shall not be required to arrive to work. Currently, the minimum monthly salary makes EUR 607 gross or EUR 437 net.    An allowance of a fixed amount will be paid from the Guarantee Fund to self-employed individuals who have paid social security contributions for at least 3 months during the last year period prior to the declaration of the emergency or quarantine.    State support in cases of downtimes and partial downtimes. The employee allowance shall be not less than the minimum monthly salary.    • Sickness benefits for carers of children and persons with disabilities during quarantine in educational establishments or in social care and employment centres.    • To pay EUR 257/month to self-employed residents who have paid social security contributions when quarantine prevents them from carrying out their activities.
notes_H8: There will be no visiting of patients in health care establishments, except when visiting terminally ill patients, children under 14 years of age and patients in maternity wards at the permission of the manager of that establishment or his authorised person;  There will be no visits to residential social care establishments, foster families, group and community homes, except when visiting residents in terminal condition or when a visit is related to the performance of duties;  social care services will be provided in residential social care establishments and in person’s home in accordance with the conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for public health safety, hygiene and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020
notes_C1: Restrictions remain in place (until 31st January)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124173336/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_H7: A, B:     The first doses of the vaccine will be given for the medical staff working in the COVID-19 wards, emergency departments, and those at high risk for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107161149/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/lithuanian-healthcare-workers-start-getting-the-covid-19-vaccine
notes_C5: Lithuania’s government on Wednesday declared a three-week lockdown starting on Nov.7 (extended end of November), to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus which has accelerated in recent weeks in the Baltic nation.    "Passengers travelling by public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) will be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter between each other."    No other measures to be found on the official websites of the government which is why I keep the level at 0    https://web.archive.org/web/20201202092539/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-25-november-2020

name: Luxembourg
notes_H1: Opening of a dedicated Site for information relating to COVID and the states response. Mentioned initially in a facebook post on the 28th of February. Site seems to have gone online on 5th of February. www.gouvernement.lu/coronavirus was the initial site, moving to covid19.lu on the 23rd of March.      https://www.infocrise.lu/fr/web/guest/accueil/-/asset_publisher/uJAlpeXURbmf/content/toutes-les-informations-officielles-et-utiles-regroupe-sur-covid19-lu?inheritRedirect=false&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.infocrise.lu%2Ffr%2Fweb%2Fguest%2Faccueil%3Fp_p_id%3D101_INSTANCE_uJAlpeXURbmf%26p_p_lifecycle%3D0%26p_p_state%3Dnormal%26p_p_mode%3Dview%26p_p_col_id%3Dcolumn-1%26p_p_col_count%3D1%23article_78291#p_101_INSTANCE_uJAlpeXURbmf
notes_H2: Tests available for those exhibiting symptoms as well as for people without symptoms (as part of the Large Scale Testing program).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405112232/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/faq.html
notes_C7: Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No    Link - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126075125/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: - in all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport.  - for any gathering of people that brings together more than 4 people at the same time, either in a closed area or in the open air.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210105163404/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html
notes_E2: With regard to direct taxes, the modalities of the advance tax payments and payment deadlines will be adapted for corporations and self-employed persons. More specifically, legal persons and natural persons carrying out an activity generating trade and business income, agriculture and forestry income, or income from independent professional services, who are experiencing liquidity problems due to the Covid-19 pandemic, can apply for a cancellation of the two first quarterly advance tax payments of the year 2020 (due in March and June 2020). Covered by this measure are (corporate) income and municipal business taxes.    In addition, these same persons may request, for taxes due after 29 February 2020, a payment extension of four months. On this deferral, no interest on late payment will be due and it covers (corporate) income, municipal business, and net wealth taxes.  https://mfin.gouvernement.lu/en/actualites.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B03-mars%2B17-mesures-fiscales-covid19.html
notes_C3: Re-opening of sports, culture & cults under strict sanitary conditions. Bars and restaurants   remain closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210119032645/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/toolbox/nouvelles-mesures/affiche/11-01-2021/10206-DISA-Cov19-Mesures-Jan21-A4-EN.pdf
notes_C6: Curfew in effect from Oct. 30: "between 11 P.M. and 6 A.M., movements of people in the public space are prohibited". According to coding interpretation guideline, record curfew as a level 2.  Sources:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013231/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013947/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1604513.html
notes_C8: Policy: There is leniency for entry and exit for certain travellers and a ban on others, hence this is coded as a Ban. See below.  Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the European Union, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes.     Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 31 March 2021 (inclusive).    Additionally, "there is an obligation to present a negative COVID-19 test result (not older than 72 hours) before boarding any flight to Luxembourg."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183329/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html
notes_C2: No policy change. Businesses are allowed to open but must comply with sanitary measures and limits on store capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183059/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/shops.html
notes_C4: indoors and outdoors  › 5-10 pers: mask + distance 2m  › 11 -100 pers: mask + distance 2m + seating place    https://web.archive.org/web/20210119032645/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/toolbox/nouvelles-mesures/affiche/11-01-2021/10206-DISA-Cov19-Mesures-Jan21-A4-EN.pdf
notes_H3: First case of COVID on March 1st has been reported and the a team of sanitary inspectors have "retracer son entourage", traced whom he has been in contact with. https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/en/communications-officielles.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B03-mars%2B01-premier-cas-corona.html
notes_E1: No policy change.     More details here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130210640/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/dam-assets/dossiers/Neistart-Letzebuerg-Tableau-Mesures.pdf
notes_H8: Curfew also applies to the elderly.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315212440/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/transports-publics.html
notes_C1: Schools are open but sanitary measures apply. Masks are required for all adults and for students from cycle 2, protective and sanitary measures must be observed, and recreation breaks or circulation of pupils must be staggered.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405111126/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-fr.html
notes_H7: Vaccines available to adults 55 and older, starting with the oldest, as well as people that may be at increased risk due to a pre-existing health condition.     Vaccines: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407132345/https://covid19.public.lu/en/news-covid19/communiques/2021/04/07-launch-phase-5.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405114032/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html
notes_C5: Public transport in Luxembourg is open with sanitary measures in place such as wearing a mask at all times and keeping a distance from other users.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201212185644/https://transports.public.lu/fr/actualites/2020/03-mars-covid-19-transports-modifications-mesures-coronavirus.html

name: Latvia
notes_H1: 2 websites are dedicated to Covid-19: the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and covid19.org.lv, both of which provide sufficient information on various aspects of the pandemic.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200608214453/https://spkc.gov.lv/en/for-general-public/covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20200617213719/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/en
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/latvia/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5%20Testing&Type=Section
notes_H6: - From 24 October mouth and nose covering should be worn in any public place.  - Mouth and nose covering should be used during indoor cultural events. The covering can not be removed if you are sitting in a fixed, personalized seat at a cultural event.   - A homemade mask should be made of at least three layers of suitable material (cotton, nylon, etc.) and have ties to secure it behind the ears or behind the head  - May not be used for children under 13 years of age and people who cannot use it for medical reasons, such as functional impairment    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
notes_E2: There some measures for rent payments from public entities. Otherwise creditors might approach lenders on a case by case basis to negotiate debt moratoriums, but no specific programme is in place.   /web/20210501143322/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ekonomika/atbalsts-uznemejiem-un-darbiniekiem
notes_C3: In view of the epidemiological assessments of the growing risks of spread of the COVID-19 virus, a national state of emergency will be declared in Latvia, to be in effect between 9 November and 6 December.    All in-person public events (such as theatre and music performances) are cancelled and banned. No more than 10 people, and members of no more than two households may participate in private meetings. No more than 50 people may participate in public gatherings, rallies and political demonstrations. Members of more than two households may attend to a funeral, up to a total of 10 people (not including the individuals conducting the funerary proceedings).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113081120/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/state-emergency-be-declared-latvia-9-november
notes_C6: No specific measures implemented. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. The clarifications in the security measures for the holiday season approved by the Cabinet of Ministers do not restrict freedom of movement. Public transport will continue to run and people are encouraged to take the opportunity to spend time outdoors in nature.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111214926/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/during-holiday-season-period-silence-must-be-observed-reducing-contact-and-refraining  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew
notes_C8: From 11th of February to 25th of February, entry into Latvia is only permitted for urgent and important reasons. These include work, learning and study purposes, as well as for humanitarian reasons - to reunite a family, to receive medical services, to accompany a minor, to return to one’s place of residence, or to go to a funeral.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214175907/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/article/emergency-situation-extended-until-6-april-requirements-site-trade-and-border-crossings-are-strengthened
notes_C2: From the 8th of February, stores and market pavilions must provide an area of 25 square meters per visitor and information on the maximum number of visitors must be displayed in a visible place at the entrance.  Additionally, the entire assortment of goods may be sold on site in stores where at least 70% of the product range is groceries. Similarly, in stores where at least 70% of the product range is hygiene products, also all other products may be sold on site.Bookstores will also be allowed to sell the full range of goods, i.e. goods allowed so far, stationery, and books.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210214175907/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/article/emergency-situation-extended-until-6-april-requirements-site-trade-and-border-crossings-are-strengthened
notes_C4: From 24 October, private event venues may have a maximum of 10 people indoors and 100 people outdoors . If a private event is held in a public place, such as a restaurant, rented sauna, club, etc., then guests must be provided with fixed, personalized seating, 2 meters distance (except for persons from one household), as well as the event can take place until 24.00;    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026220648/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/nosaka-stingrakus-pulcesanas-un-citus-drosibas-pasakumus
notes_H3: There is a voluntary contact tracing app available, however its not mandatory to use.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201014154613/https://www.baltictimes.com/around_40_000_people_have_downloaded_latvia_s_covid-19_contact_tracing_app/
notes_E1: While Covid-19 restrictions continue, the government has decided on support measures to companies suffering from Covid-19. The government has approved the following support measures:    "Self-employed persons who apply the general tax payment regime, persons who receive royalties, who have not registered as performers of economic activities, and sole proprietorships whose economic activity has been suspended as a result of the restrictions, or whose income from economic activity has decreased by at least 20% in comparison to this year’s August, September and October, will be eligible for support in the amount of 75% of the average income from economic activity or royalties during Q3 this year; but not exceeding EUR 1,000."    "Self-employed persons who pay the micro-enterprise tax will be eligible for 50% of monthly average income for Q3 this year. Payers of patent payments will be eligible for support of EUR 330."    "Employees working at companies affected by Covid-19 will be eligible for idle-time payment. This support will be at least EUR 330, but not more than EUR 1,000 a month. In addition to idle-time payment, the employee can receive an extra EUR 50 for each dependent child under 24."    "The regulations state that support as compensation for idle time will be paid to the employee at the amount of 70% of the reported monthly average gross salary from 1 August to 30 October this year or of the reported monthly average gross salary for those months after 1 August when the employee actually worked. An employee of a micro-enterprise taxpayer will be eligible for idle-time payment of 50% of the monthly average gross salary at the micro-enterprise for Q3 2020."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201118091001/https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=293a20d7-ee9e-4c68-8962-4dca8247c181
notes_H8: Authorities in Latvia have extended the nation's COVID-19-related state of emergency until April 6 amid increasing infection rates in the country. No curfew in place.   Link: https://archive.ph/XTHUs
notes_C1: Ministry of Health  Similarly, in order to reduce the spread of the virus and it would be time for epidemiologists to observe fluctuations in the number of infections, the government decided that pupils in grades 7-12 would learn remotely.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/uz-laiku-jaierobezo-cilveku-kustiba-arpus-katra-sociala-burbula
notes_H7: On April 29th 2021, the government announced that a broader group of people, who have registered before on the webpage manavakcina.lv could have a priority access to the vaccination. On May 3rd 2021 all population will be able to get a vaccine.  /web/20210501151554/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/aktualites/jau-sodien-pirmajiem-40-222-manavakcinalv-februari-registretajiem-iedzivotajiem-iespeja  /web/20210501151908/https://eng.lsm.lv/article/society/health/vaccination-for-everyone-planned-to-begin-in-may.a402356/
notes_C5: "Nose and mouth coverings must be used (a self-made or purchased mask, scarf, shawl, and other solutions are accepted). Hygiene measures must be observed." Those who have tested positive for Covid-19 must not use public transport. Neither should those who have been in contact with a Covid-19 positive citizen. https://web.archive.org/web/20200617214914/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

name: Macao
notes_H2: Nucleic acid tests are open for online reservation for cross-boundary travellers starting from 10am on 15 July.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201116151921/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20GONHgtC;jsessionid=1B46FD21318D0ECC755125E34F5001FD.app02?0
notes_H6: Bus, ferry, taxi passengers must wear facial masks. Visitors to casinos or other entertainment venues must wear facial masks. Source:     http://web.archive.org/web/20200928200710/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hans/global-search/page/4/?q=%E6%88%B4%E5%8F%A3%E7%BD%A9%E6%8C%87%E5%BC%95
notes_E2: The Government announces subsidy for a period of three months of all electricity and water tariffs for the housing units of Macao residents ; rebate of 70 percent of the personal income tax for the fiscal year 2018 paid by each Macao resident liable for such tax; waiver of waive property tax levied on all housing units of Macao residents for the year 2019. Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521223141/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20BMQ4RQa;jsessionid=D8FFCC6F49F88A8F26D204A136AEEE98.app03?0 ; https://web.archive.org/save/http://finance.eastmoney.com/a/202002141383532963.html
notes_C3: The Cultural Affairs Bureau will resume operation of its performance venues from 26 June (Friday) onwards.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201118134442/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20FVolMk4;jsessionid=DFAE36A2FAA3F4D35DF424019F8D34F3.app02?0
notes_C8: non-resident workers from Zhuhai eligible for exemption from 14-day Macao medical observation.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200520134950/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20EJuYISW;jsessionid=A369E9ABEE675477120F48351381622C.app02?0
notes_C2: public services resume as normal  https://web.archive.org/web/20201118121305/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20Bbsudzy?1
notes_H3: 'In response to the first case of new coronavirus infection in Australia, the SAR government has launched and deployed anti-epidemic work in an all-round way, taking necessary measures including implementing heat detection at ports and filling in entry declaration forms to fully respond to, prevent and control the epidemic.'  https://web.archive.org/web/20200403075243/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AV4AiJe;jsessionid=AE280AF2AFB28803D49190392A304F09.app03?0
notes_E1: Apart from the e-voucher, there is a 600-pataca medical voucher to every permanent resident, extra 1-month's relief to means-tested fragile families. Source:    http://web.archive.org/web/20200928182541/http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2020-06/24/content_5521649.htm  The Government would allocate an e-voucher – with a value of 3,000 patacas – to each resident. Such e-vouchers would have to be used within a three-month period and would be accepted only in certain restaurants, retail outlets and shopping centres.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521223141/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20BMQ4RQa;jsessionid=D8FFCC6F49F88A8F26D204A136AEEE98.app03?0.   [second round of income support was announced on 8 April, see below]
notes_C1: Primary school completely resumes. So far, all schools and universities in Macau have resumed, with social distancing and other public health precautions in place. Kindergarten, which is not part of the K-12, remains suspended.      https://web.archive.org/web/20200520135120/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20EKbDD24;jsessionid=A76EFED4B05FE6FC79888F499FE2EFCC.app01?0
notes_H7: Macau's second stage of vaccine roll-out started on 22 Feb 2021: all Macau residents are eligible to get a jab. The government calls all eligible people to book a slot.    https://archive.vn/2ZPEF  https://archive.vn/W2AER

name: Morocco
notes_H1: No change in policy. The Ministry of Health website (http://www.covidmaroc.ma/) has public information on the virus, safety tips, and statistics.    Bulletin example: https://web.archive.org/web/20210210180925/http://www.covidmaroc.ma/Documents/SITUATION_Epid%C3%A9mie_COVID-19/B%20u%20l%20l%20e%20t%20i%20n%20%C3%A9%20p%20i%20d%20%C3%A9%20m%20i%20o%20l%20o%20g%20i%20q%20u%20e%20N%209-06082020.pdf
notes_H2: If you are exhibiting signs or symptoms of COVID-19, please contact the Moroccan Ministry of Health’s hotline at +212 (0)8-0100-4747. Assistance is available in English, French or Arabic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201121090354/https://ma.usembassy.gov/25161/
notes_C7: A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Regional or local authorities may put into place (sometimes with little notice) travel or other restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  Individuals entering or departing from the Casablanca city limits must have a letter of permission issued by Moroccan authorities. In Casablanca, there is an evening curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Those who circulate within Casablanca during these hours must have proper authorization from local authorities.    Is a curfew in place? There is a curfew in Casablanca between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: The use of masks is mandatory.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201019012009/https://ma.usembassy.gov/25161/  Also see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201019005808/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/morocco/coronavirus
notes_E2: There is no evidence that the previous debt/contract relief was extended beyond the end of March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419160858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Morocco's Interior Ministry announced cancellation of all sporting, cultural, and artistic events in the country, until further notice from 14 March https://web.archive.org/web/20200601135438/https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2020/03/296129/morocco-bans-public-gatherings-of-over-50-people-cancels-all-events/
notes_C6: A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am. . In Casablanca, there is an evening curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Those who circulate within Casablanca during these hours must have proper authorization from local authorities.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Government reopens borders to 67 visa-exempt countries with some restrictions. Citizens of those countries cleared to travel to Morocco without a visa will be allowed entry, provided that they have an express invitation from a Morocco company or a confirmed hotel reservation.(MSN News, 14.09.2020).    All travellers planning to fly to Morocco must have valid negative Covid-19 test results issued no more than 48 hours before their flight.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200925052707/https://travelbans.org/africa/morocco/
notes_C2: On December 21, the Government of Morocco announced additional restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  The measures will take effect on Wednesday, December 23 and will remain in place for three weeks. The new measures include the following:  A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am;  A daily closing time for restaurants, cafes, shops, and supermarkets of 8:00 pm;  The closure of all restaurants and cafes in Agadir, Casablanca, Marrakech, and Tangier; and  A ban on all public and private gatherings and parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: On December 21, the Government of Morocco announced additional restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  The measures will take effect on Wednesday, December 23 and will remain in place for three weeks. The new measures include the following:  A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am;  A daily closing time for restaurants, cafes, shops, and supermarkets of 8:00 pm;  The closure of all restaurants and cafes in Agadir, Casablanca, Marrakech, and Tangier; and  A ban on all public and private gatherings and parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: Downgrading indicator as contact tracing apps are voluntary.    Downloading and using the “Wiqaytna” application is voluntary and is part of the nationwide awareness campaign, “Stay vigilant, protect each other,” which encourages citizens to continue to implement precautionary measures against the virus.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419163138/https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2020/06/305111/over-1-million-moroccans-download-wiqaytna-covid-19-tracking-app/
notes_E1: There is no evidence that the previous income support was extended beyond the end of March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419160858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H8: All age groups are required to stay at home in cities and districts that are under curfew. Now the curfew is nationwide. A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am. Thus, that requires elderly people to stay at home as well in these hours by default.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Schools are fully open with precautionary measures in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201121082517/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H7: A,B,C: Sinopharm and AstraZeneca  Which vaccines are available in Morocco? Sinopharm (China) and AstraZeneca (UK)  For information on getting vaccinated in Morocco, please contact the COVID-19 Vaccination Hotline, “Allo Liqah,”at 08-00-00-01-47 (French and Arabic) or visit their website at https://liqahcorona.ma/fr.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402235135/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    The COVID-19 virus vaccination campaign targets citizens over the age of 17, according to a two-shot vaccination schedule. This target population is estimated at 25,000,000. Priority will be given to certain targets, in particular front-line personnel, in this case, health professionals, public authorities, security forces and education personnel. national level, as well as to the elderly and those vulnerable to the virus, before extending it to the rest of the population.    https://liqahcorona.ma/fr/page-je-minforme-sur-le-vaccin#209 (this website is not being archived)
notes_C5: 23 October: Tighter curbs announced for Greater Casablanca, which includes the Casablanca and Mohammadia prefectures and Naouceur and Mediouna provinces, as well as the Berrechid and Benslimane provinces. Measures include the prohibition of all forms of night movement between 9pm and 6am; the closing of community grounds and parks; closing restaurants, cafes, stores and large shopping centres at 8pm; the shutdown of public transportation buses and tramways at 9pm; closing local markets at 3pm; and promoting teleworking when possible.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201029142017/https://www.meed.com/tunisia-pushes-finance-bill-to-cope-with-covid-19

name: Monaco
notes_H1: From 9 am tomorrow, Friday 6 March, the COVID-19 Call Centre, a telephone information service, will take over, staffed by a dedicated team from the Department of Health Affairs (DASA), first aiders from the Monaco Red Cross and a medical supervisor.    Monegasque nationals, residents and employees can contact the centre to discuss any questions they may have about COVID-19 by calling 92 05 55 00. The line will be open every day from 9 am to 6 pm. The centre can also be emailed at the following address: covid19@gouv.mc .    The Prince’s Government would like to remind readers that in the event of any doubt, particularly if you have visited an area where the virus is circulating and have significant symptoms consistent with the disease (fever, cough, breathing difficulties, etc.) you should contact the emergency services directly on 18 or 112.    To avoid infecting others, people with symptoms are asked not to visit their normal doctor.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201203123750/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/CORONAVIRUS-Prince-s-Government-to-expand-COVID-19-telephone-information-service
notes_H2: PCR test is available to anyone: "If I am not in one of these 4 cases, but still want to do a PCR test, I can go to a laboratory in town. My test will be reimbursed with or without a prescription". Also, "It is recommended to do an antigen test in the following cases: If you want to be tested, without being identified as a high or low risk contact case, If you have had symptoms for less than 4 days."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115163618/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-tests-diagnostics/
notes_C7: Curfew in place from 8pm to 6am, but no restrictions on internal movement otherwise.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409141322/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/sorties/
notes_H6: Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210126122206/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_E2: No measures in place.
notes_C3: Public gatherings are limited to six people, but places of worship are allowed to remain open with a limit of 1 person per 6 square meters.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C6: Curfew in place from 8pm to 6am, with exceptions for work, health and family reasons.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C8: Travelers are required to quarantine unless they are able to show proof of a negative PCR test taken at most 72 hours prior to arrival. In the event of a positive PCR, or if the person refuses to be tested, the quarantine will be maintained.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409142722/https://covid19.mc/en/i-come-from-abroad/
notes_C2: Working from home is compulsory in the private and public sector until the 18th of April, but public services, hotels, banks, businesses, and public establishments remain open with restrictions in place. Employees are required to go to work if their employer does not wish to conduct work remotely.    "Teleworking is compulsory as soon as it is practicable. For the private sector, work must be conducted remotely when the nature of the employee's activity is compatible with his remote exercise and the employer can make the technical and material resources necessary for such an exercise available to him. For the public sector, remote work must be used for the entire weekly working time of the civil servant or agent of the State, with his agreement, provided that the nature of his activity is compatible with its exercise remotely and that it has the technical and material resources necessary for such an exercise."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409143359/https://covid19.mc/en/working-from-home/
notes_C4: Due to the worldwide COVID-19 epidemic, Monaco has imposed severe restrictions on public life: A curfew has been in effect since Tuesday (17 March). People are only allowed to leave their homes for justified purposes, while restaurants, museums, and non-essential shops are closed throughout the country. Persons entering the country from risk areas must undergo a 14-day domestic quarantine.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201216070845/https://global-monitoring.com/gm/page/events/epidemic-0002086.Eg778z0AGwE9.html?lang=en
notes_H3: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126123014/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/jai-ete-en-contact-avec-une-personne-positive-a-la-covid-19-que-faire/
notes_E1: Employees who have been laid off and who usually receive a gross base salary of less than or equal to EUR 2,075.16 for 169 hours per month are entitled to their full net salary. Employees earning a gross base salary of between EUR 2,075.17 and EUR 2,571.43, for 169 hours per month, will be entitled to the safeguard clause at a rate of EUR 1,800.00. In the case of higher salaries, a cap has been set at 4.5 times the minimum wage.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409144615/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/travail/
notes_H8: No policy updates. Measures introduced on November 1st 2020 will remain in place until March 19 at least.   A curfew remains in place (7pm-6am).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316061327/https://covid19.mc/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C1: " Alesi    On 7 September 2020, Minister of State H.E. Mr Pierre Dartout visited Lycée Albert I upon the return of Year 13 (Terminale) pupils, who will sit the newly reformed General Baccalaureate examinations next June.    H.E. the Minister of State was accompanied by Mr Patrice Cellario, Minister of the Interior, and Ms Isabelle Bonnal, Director of Education, Youth and Sport.    During the early afternoon, H.E. the Minister of State, Mgr David, Archbishop of Monaco, Mr Patrice Cellario and Ms Isabelle Bonnal were also keen to meet students and staff at the François d’Assise-Nicolas Barré primary school.    After witnessing the return of the five-year-old (Grande Section) nursery pupils, H.E. the Minister of State chatted to Year 2 (CP) and Year 5 (CM1) pupils and teaching staff.    During his discussions at the Principality’s schools, H.E. the Minister of State asked pupils how they felt about returning to school this year. They told him that they were happy to be able to get back to their lessons and to be with their friends again.    In the course of his visits, H.E. the Minister of State also welcomed the rigorous compliance with health guidelines on the part of all pupils and staff.    This September marks the beginning of a new school year for the 518 teachers and 5,774 pupils enrolled in Monaco’s schools."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201226070954/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/2020-2021-school-year-begins
notes_H7: Vaccines are available to Monegasques and residents over 45 as well as those over 18 with risk factors for co-morbidity (according to a list by the French High Authority of Health) on a voluntary basis.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210501194131/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/
notes_C5: The Monegasque Bus Company (CAM) is resuming normal service for all buses, including the Bateau Bus (water bus). The only exceptions to this are the night services, N1 and N2, which will remain closed.     The following health measures apply:    The wearing of masks is mandatory on public transport  Tickets can be purchased on board, on condition that you pay the exact amount  Tickets are also available from the 12 automatic ticket machines located throughout the Principality, and the shop at 22/24 Rue du Gabian is open from 8.30 am to 4.30 pm Monday to Friday  The following procedures continue to apply:    Buses will be disinfected twice a day  Dispensers of hydro-alcoholic gel have been installed in every bus  Buses will stop at every stop (to avoid the need for people to press the buttons)  Passenger information showing the direction in which you should walk when boarding, leaving and while on the bus, is displayed on the floor and doors of the bus  It is forbidden to get off the bus  at the front    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

name: Moldova
notes_H1: Public Information campaign appears organised with posters giving specific advice and instructions. https://web.archive.org/web/20200727231717/https://msmps.gov.md/minister/comunicare/covid-19/
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is available at both public and private medical laboratories.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426235106/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: During the current State of Emergency until May 31, 2021, all city parks, forests, playgrounds, and recreation spaces are closed. Face-masks are mandatory in all public spaces, including outdoors. Night clubs and other such venues remain closed. All restaurants, bars, and cafes must close at 8:00 pm. Groups of more than three people are prohibited in public areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426235106/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Face-masks are mandatory in all public spaces, including outdoors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426235106/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: Banks are allowed to instigate payment holidays until June 30. Income tax payments have been suspended. https://www.ebrd.com/where-we-are/moldova/overview.html;https://www.ebrd.com/where-we-are/moldova/overview.html
notes_C3: Due to an increase in the epidemiologic situation, restrictions are in place 01 March through 15 March, inclusively.  This includes:  Thus, the education will be held online in the primary education institutions, gymnasiums, lyceums, extra-school institutions and vocational schools and higher schools, private and public institutions. The school Olympiads will no longer be able to be held with the physical presence of people.      At the same time, the presence of spectators in the work of the theatre and concert institutions, as well as community centres is banned and the public transport will be ceased on Saturday and Sunday in the Chisinau city. The Chisinau municipality’s national extraordinary public health commission will establish a limited regime of movement of the public transport in the area of the Chisinau city.     The public institutions and the private ones will ensure a special working regime, through attracting of the strictly needed staff to work and the distance work will be instructed for the other employees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020043/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-establishes-special-activity-regime  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013930/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/social  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013505/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: Moldova has asked people who may had contact an infected person to self-isolate at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426235106/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Effective March 5, 2021, anyone entering Moldova must present a negative COVID-19 test taken within the previous 72 hours or they will be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210322184956/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: On April 30th, the previous national state of emergency was declared unconstitutional and has been lifted. This state of emergency was meant to last from 1 April until 30 May 2021. This included a curfew between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m. in Chisinau and Balti cities, and banning people’s presence in parks, forests, playgrounds, and sport or leisure areas in these cities. Curfews are no longer in place in Chisinau and Balti. In designated "red code" areas where infection rates are high, individuals are allowed to leave their homes only for essential purposes.     The National Public Health Commission also convened a meeting. CNESP members have mandated the territorial commissions to take the decision to establish a state of emergency in public health at local level in case the incidence of cases exceeds 100 infections per 100 thousand citizens.    Under existing directives, public institutions and private businesses are limited to operating with no more than 30 percent of their staff working on-site, with the remainder working remotely. Most businesses in Moldova are permitted to operate provided they adhere to strict health and safety measures, though all public offices close at 16:00 daily, and bars and restaurants must close from 20:00-07:00. Markets are permitted to operate between the hours of 07:00-15:00; shopping malls must close by 18:00. Concert halls and nightclubs remain closed until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504064411/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504062617/https://www.moldova.org/en/there-will-be-snap-elections-constitutional-court-cancelled-the-state-of-emergency-the-president-announced-a-ballot-date/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143119/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/01/21002456  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405150436/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/02/21002488  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405144922/https://www.moldova.org/en/state-of-emergency-in-moldova-controlling-coronavirus-infections-or-parliaments-dissolution/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405142342/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Groups of more than three people are prohibited in public areas. Public parks are open, but people should not congregate in groups larger than three.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: Moldova has asked people who may had contact an infected person to self-isolate at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426235106/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E1: "The government will also assist businesses that have suspended their activities (fully or partially) by refunding personal income taxes and social security contributions up to 100%. Those that had to stop their operations due to decision of authorities will receive a subsidy amounting to 100% of their income tax, social security and health contributions, and other compulsory state payments. Persons who have worked for at least nine months at one enterprise and have lost their jobs will be paid from 60 to 80% of their final salary. Banks were also incentivised to delay payment deadlines and/or the amounts of due payments on loans until 30 June."https://www.oecd.org/coronavirus/policy-responses/covid-19-crisis-response-in-eu-eastern-partner-countries/
notes_H8: The elderly are prioritized for vaccines and persons over 63 years of age must remain in their accommodations except for essential purposes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504064411/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17
notes_C1: The Public Health Extraordinary Commission of the Chisinau municipality has ruled that, starting from 19 April 2021, the children from the 1-4 forms, 5th, 9th and 12th forms would return to education in classrooms for classes with physical presence.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210420093757/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/15/21002822
notes_H7: Currently Moldova has started providing various vaccines to A, C groups: some medical workers, teachers, and persons older than 65 years.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210426235106/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: Public transport is operating at 50 percent capacity. Facemasks are mandatory in enclosed public spaces and on public transport.   All passengers in public transportation, including bus, train and taxis, must wear a mask. When getting on or off a bus or taxi, passengers should use an alcohol- based hand sanitizer or should wash with soap and water. Hand sanitizer is available on public buses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504064411/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504063036/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Madagascar
notes_H1: No policy change
notes_H2: COVID-19 Testing  •	Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Madagascar? Yes  •	If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  •	Polyclinique Ilafy and Hospital ManarapenitraAndenatepenaka offer PCR tests for COVID-19.  •	InstitutPasteur offers serological tests for COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405080216/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Movement Restrictions:  •	Is a curfew in place? Yes, in Analamanga, Atsinana, SAVA, BOENY, and Nosy Be there is a curfew from 9 PM to 4 AM.  •	Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Domestic flights in and out of Nosy Be and Mahajanga are suspended.  Analamanga, Atsinana, SAVA, BOENY, and Nosy Be are closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419164815/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: It is mandatory to wear a face mask in all public places, including in shops, parks and streets.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405080014/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_E2: Private sector supported through tax relief and suspension of government fees, but no similar policy applied to households.    See IMF's Policy Response Tracker (https://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#M).
notes_C3: Gatherings of more than 200 people are not permitted.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405080014/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_C6: On 3 April 2021, the Government of Madagascar declared a national Health State of Emergency, for an initial period of 15 days. A curfew from 9pm to 4am is in place in the regions of Analamanga (including the capital Antananarivo), Antsinana, Boeny, Nosy Be and Sava.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419164438/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_C8: All Foreign visitation is restricted to the island of Nosy Be, foreign citizens are not permitted elsewhere in Madagascar    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232310/http://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites/decret/997-decret-n-2020-1270-du-03-octobre-2020-prolongeant-la-duree-de-l-etat-d-urgence-sanitaire-sur-tout-le-territoire-de-la-republique.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232333/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232330/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232339/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/390636/madagascar-authorities-announce-end-of-state-of-health-emergency-october-18-update-19
notes_C2: On 3 April 2021, the Government of Madagascar declared a national Health State of Emergency, for an initial period of 15 days. Business opening hours and public transport operations are subject to change at short notice, and some venues remain closed or operate with limited capacity. A curfew from 9pm to 4am is in place in the regions of Analamanga (including the capital Antananarivo), Antsinana, Boeny, Nosy Be and Sava.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419164438/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_C4: Gatherings of more than 100 people are not permitted. https://web.archive.org/web/20210419164438/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_H3: In place with volunteers due to past plague outbreaks https://web.archive.org/web/20210405085741/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/how-contact-tracers-could-help-control-covid-19
notes_E1: No change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419164631/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H8: Local curfews eased.  "Curfews introduced in multiple areas of Madagascar to control the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) were lifted on Monday, October 5, following a fall in the rate of new infections in recent weeks. Curfew restrictions had initially been introduced nationwide under the country's state of health emergency in March before being partially eased in June, with the 22:00 to 04:00 curfew remaining in place in designated virus hotspots. The lifting of the curfew means that targeted restrictions have been eased in areas with higher COVID-19 transmission rates, including the Analamanga, Alaotra Mangoro, Diana, Sava, and Vakinankaratra regions.    Authorities have also announced the easing of public gathering restrictions from Monday, permitting groups of up to 200 to gather for religious, cultural, and sporting events. Schools, entertainment venues, and sports facilities have also been authorized to resume normal operations with appropriate hygiene and distancing measures in place. However, the use of face masks remains compulsory in public places."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210301124624/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/386456/madagascar-covid-19-curfew-lifted-as-state-of-health-emergency-extended-until-october-18-update-18
notes_C1: Whilst UNESCO states that school are fully open: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419163708/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse  According to the BBC on 15 April 2021, however, Madagascar has postponed the reopening of schools previously planned for Monday next week, citing an increase in coronavirus cases. The country's cabinet said schools would remain closes until further notice. Some schools have been converted into Covid-19 treatment centres, Madagascar-Tribune has reported. https://web.archive.org/web/20210419170132/https://www.bbc.com/news/topics/c1038wnx0llt/madagascar
notes_C5: "Public transportation will resume services from Wednesday, August 26."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200830181552/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/371926/madagascar-authorities-ease-measures-and-extend-national-state-of-health-emergency-through-september-7-update-16

name: Mexico
notes_H1: #QuedateEnCasa: https://web.archive.org/web/20201112133725/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/ Since 24th March: https://web.archive.org/web/20200920220127/https://mexico.as.com/mexico/2020/03/25/actualidad/1585105801_984693.html
notes_H2: The epidemiological surveillance of COVID-19 will change model from the instrumentation of the new operational definition, so that it is sentinel in the 475 units currently active for SISVEFLU (which will change its name to Epidemiological Surveillance System of Viral Respiratory Disease, SISVER) and where not only will COVID-19 be monitored, but also influenza and other respiratory viruses.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200414061918/https://www.gob.mx/cms/uploads/attachment/file/545445/AE_Enfermedad_COVID-19_SARS-CoV-2_2020.04.06.pdf
notes_C7: Restrictions on internal movement to be upheld according to "traffic light system" per state   /web/20200611070223/https://www.milenio.com/politica/coronavirus-mexico-10-junio-noticias-covid-19
notes_H6: National Government recommends use of facial covering in asymptomatic people when it is not possible to maintain a safe distance from other people (public transport)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411061502/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/prevencion/  "Several states and municipalities have imposed curfews and movement restrictions on non-essential activities and have required citizens to wear masks when outside the home."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210417161111/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: 3 month loan extensions are available:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223132720/https://www.gob.mx/covid19medidaseconomicas/acciones-y-programas/creditos-infonavit
notes_C3: In "orange" areas cinemas, theatres, cultural (up to 500 people) and religious events are allowed with a 25% capacity. "Yellow" areas add massive events, nightclubs and bars and increase the permitted capacity to 50%. "Green" areas have no restrictions. Currently, there are no "red" areas.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210413183359/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_C6: "Is a curfew in place? [Yes]  Curfews are not universal.  Restrictions vary based on state and/or city.  Please see the “Local Resources” section for curfew-specific information below."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312165454/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: "The Mexican government encourages people to continue respecting social distancing measures, washing their hands, and coughing or sneezing in the inner part of the elbow to prevent the spread of COVID-19.  A variety of prevention measures can be found at https://coronavirus.gob.mx  For U.S. citizens who have participated in higher risk activities or think that they may have been exposed before or during a trip, the CDC encourages people to take the following extra precautions to protect others for 14 days after arrival:  Stay home as much as possible.  Avoid staying around people at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19.  Consider getting tested for COVID-19.  In the United States, quarantine requirements and recommendations may vary by state.  Therefore, travelers should review an individual state’s entry requirements before traveling."      http://web.archive.org/web/20200927195013/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: highest alert level is Orange which has these restrictions:  In addition to essential economic activities, companies of non-essential economic activities will be allowed to work with 30% of the personnel for their operation, always taking into account the maximum care measures for people with a greater risk of presenting a serious picture of COVID-19, open public spaces will be opened with a reduced capacity (number of people).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226000705/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_C4: No specific restrictions on gatherings in levels green, yellow, or orange. There are capacity restrictions on public spaces within levels yellow and orange.     https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: According to the report, 555 persons were contacted. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210118023002/https://covid19.cdmx.gob.mx/storage/app/media/Reportes%20CSP/CS_4_ENERO_compressed.pdf
notes_E1: Government-provided low-interest loans are available:  Credits to support family micro-businesses and self-employed workers in the face of the effects caused by COVID-19  Financing of 25 thousand pesos per business or person, to be paid in three years, including three months of grace.  In other words, the beneficiaries will pay 824 pesos in 33 installments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223132600/https://www.gob.mx/covid19medidaseconomicas/acciones-y-programas/apoyos-financieros-a-microempresas-y-trabajadores-independientes
notes_H8: On March 15, the National Government gave a list of 13 recommendations for elderly people. Recommendations involved keeping social distancing, avoiding physical contact, washing hand frequently, trusting official sources, etc. Interestingly, one recommendation was to avoid facial covering if there are no symptoms of the disease. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213224027/https://www.infobae.com/america/mexico/2020/03/16/estas-son-las-medidas-de-prevencion-para-cuidar-a-los-adultos-mayores-y-evitar-contagios-de-coronavirus/
notes_C1: Between 15 Feb and 28 Feb there are 2 regions under Red alert, 21 under Orange alert, 8 under Yellow alert and 1 under Green alert. School activities are allowed under Green alert only.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217220733/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_H7: A,B,C:  On April 6th 2021, National Government updated their report on the national strategy for COVID vaccination which is organised in 5 stages. Stage 3 (general population aged 50-59) was scheduled to start in April but due to delays in the supply of vaccines it has been postponed to start May 2021.   Stage 1: Front line health workers (Dec 2020-Feb 2021)  Stage 2: Rest of health workers and elderly population (aged 60 and over) (Feb 2021-May 2021)  Stage 3: General population aged 50-59 (May 2021-June 2021)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503160048/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/28Abr2021_13h00_PNVx_COVID_19.pdf
notes_C5: Is public transportation operating? [Yes]  Some states and municipalities have implemented additional transportation restrictions  https://archive.vn/6kDtz

name: Mali
notes_H1: In addition, social, sporting, cultural and political groupings of more than 50 people such as weddings, baptisms, funerals were banned.  Public, private and denominational schools, including madarsas will be closed for three weeks  https://web.archive.org/web/20200408211603/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/mali-suspends-flights-from-covid-19-hit-countries-/1769908
notes_H2: As noted on the Us embassy official web  page the test centers are available for the general public at specific locations. the second archive link which is posted by the state health minster shows that they are actively working to reduce the spread of virus by investigating cases and systematic screening programs (attached file is in french language on page 9 section 5 subsection 5.2 *used google translator)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502095809/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210502165901/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/mali_sitrep_covid-19_n151_du_25_avril_2021.pdf
notes_C7: THere is no information on internal movement after the curfew being lifted.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-mali-lifts-nationwide-curfew-may-10
notes_H6: As of 9th May 2020, Mali's government made mask wearing compulsory in public places.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200903122847/http://north-africa.com/2020/05/mali-ends-curfew-orders-mandatory-wearing-of-facemasks/
notes_E2: The three-month exemption (starting from May) would have expired in August and there is no indication that this was renewed. See https://web.archive.org/web/20201109002858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Correct link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210321190255/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/435086/mali-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-remain-mostly-unchanged-as-of-jan-26-update-8
notes_C6: "Is a curfew in place? No". However, general restrictions apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308234507/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: The Government of Mali has implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to go into effect with little or no advanced notice.  Incoming air travellers are required to:  •	Wear a mask.  •	Complete a form with contact information, travel history and health symptoms.   •	Present a negative COVID-19 test dated no more than seven days prior to arrival in Mali.  •	Any passenger who arrives without a negative COVID-19 test result or with a COVID-19 test result dated more than seven days before arrival will have their travel documents retained by airport officials and will be subjected to testing. Travelers must self-quarantine at home or at a hotel at their expense until the test result is available.  Anyone suspected of having COVID-19, despite presenting a negative COVID-19 test result, will be subject to testing.  If test results are positive, that person’s travel documents will be retained, and the traveler will be put into isolation at a government of Mali facility.  The travel documents will be returned once the patient is deemed free of COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/mali-declares-10-day-emergency-to-fight-covid-19/2082011#
notes_C4: "On 25 March 2020, the Government declared a state of health emergency and a curfew from 21h to 5h in the morning which came to complete a set of measures previously adopted including (...) the prohibition, until further notice, of social, sports, cultural and political groups of more than 50 people"    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427090758/https://reliefweb.int/report/mali/mali-coronavirus-covid-19-situation-report-no-1-reporting-period-25-march-08-april-2020
notes_H3: http://malijet.com/a_la_une_du_mali/241897-covid-19-bonne-nouvelle-baisse-du-nombre-de-nouvelles-contaminat.html
notes_E1: It does not seem like the measures were extended up until now. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20201109002858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H8: Lockdown ended on 28/12  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.africanews.com/2020/12/19/mali-goes-into-lockdown-to-fight-the-covid-19-pandemic//
notes_C1: Schools reopening on 26/01/2021. Restrictions such as masks and social distancing apply.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210321190255/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/435086/mali-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-remain-mostly-unchanged-as-of-jan-26-update-8 *** https://web.archive.org/web/20210321190237/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H7: Mali's government says it has chosen to use the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in its plan to initially immunise 4.2 million people. Health minister Fanta Siby said that the vaccination would first target medical staff, the elderly and those with co-morbidities. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406040809/https://www.africanews.com/2021/01/22/mali-picks-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine-to-begin-vaccination-april//

name: Malta
notes_H1: on 9th March 2020, Maltese public health authorities set up a helpline, various web sites and an elevated coordinated public campaign.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217074800/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/March/09/PR200435en.aspx
notes_H2: Swabs are generally available, even to asymptomatic or people wishing to swab on their wish.    https://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2020-03-24/local-news/Two-new-swabbing-hubs-to-open-in-Malta-tomorrow-6736221236
notes_C7: On 11th March 2021, the Maltese Government restricted travel to Gozo to only essential travel or people having a residence on the island.      Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210311061115/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2021/March/10/pr210501.aspx
notes_H6: Mask is mandatory as soon as a person leaves home.    source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217080855/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/October/16/pr202014.aspx
notes_E2: From 13th March 2020, Government introduced, and maintained various narrow debt relief to households, from tax deferments to loan moratoria. This is in place up to at least 2021.    source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217074334/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/March/14/pr200489.aspx  http://web.archive.org/web/20201217074531/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/moratorium-on-loan-repayments-to-extend-into-2021.839084
notes_C3: Government reintroduces public event ban    http://web.archive.org/web/20201216100018/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/July/31/pr201473.aspx
notes_C6: Stay at home requirements are removed completely.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217083045/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/June/01/pr201038.aspx
notes_C8: Although the border closure is now lifted, travel to several countries remain banned throughout. The list of countries that travel is restricted to is very fluid and changes across time.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217072559/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/travel-ban-to-be-lifted-for-regions-in-italy-france-spain-hard-hit-by.801810
