notes_C4: Religious gatherings and all gatherings in general must have no more than 50 people under the strictest Covid-19 compliance certified and regulated by the local Council.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125105334/https://theworldnews.net/mw-news/chakwera-address-jan-17-covid-19-demands-change-of-priorities-and-scaling-down-of-campaign-promises
notes_H3: The Ministry of Health continues to carry out contact tracing and provides daily case reports with details about the regions where they have been identified and how many cases are under investigation. The March 10, UN COVID-19 Update, reports that "Contact tracing for 979 persons and 10,780 tests supported by USAID ONSE" has been provided to support contact tracing efforts in Malawi.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322031514/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3617373071651515    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322032410/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UN%20Malawi%20COVID-19%20Update%20Situation%20Update%20No.%2037%20%28at%2010%20March%202021%29.pdf
notes_E1: No indication this was extended to January. According to the IMF, "an Emergency Cash Transfer Program of about $50 million (0.5 percent of GDP), mostly financed by development partners, is being implemented during May-November." See: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 [web archive unavailable, accessed 11 January 2021]
notes_H8: No specific measures for protection of the elderly and a curfew is no longer in place.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210502113108/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Malawi has ended school closure restrictions. As of 22nd February 2021, all schools have re-opened in the country.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210221225116/https://www.facebook.com/malawimoh/posts/3617373071651515
notes_H7: A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  On April 6, the government announced that the vaccine is now available to everyone 18 years old and above. "I would like to inform the general public that we are now entering the second phase of COVID-19 vaccination whereby apart from those targeted in the first phase i.e. the health workers and other social workers, those aged 60 years and above and those with underlying conditions, the vaccination has been extended to everyone aged 18 years and above. My special appeal goes to those who by nature of their occupation interact with a lot of people on daily basis such as those working in banks, shops, vendors and those in the transport sector to come and get the vaccine. I would like to request everyone aged 18 years and above to utilize this opportunity to get vaccinated so that they are protected from COVID-19 severe disease, risk of hospitalization or death due to COVID-19. The vaccination exercise continues in all the Government and CHAM health facilities."    April 6, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412000519/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3752144994840988    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411234712/https://www.nyasatimes.com/ministry-of-health-overwhelmed-with-turn-up-for-covid-19-vaccine/
notes_C5: Public transport is operating in Malawi but transport options are extremely limited. Those that operate are small privately owned minibuses, covered motorbike taxis, and bicycle taxis.  Minibuses are expected to limit passengers and require mask usage and some social distancing.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210501151042/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Malaysia
notes_H1: Director-General of Health's press statement regarding the novel coronavirus; preparatory steps taken to deal with potential spreading of the disease [https://web.archive.org/web/20200403225553/https://kpkesihatan.com/2020/01/16/kenyataan-akhbar-kpk-16-januari-2020-kesiapsiagaan-dan-respons-kkm-dalam-menghadapi-potensi-penularan-novel-coronavirus-wuhan-china/]
notes_H2: To access the new service, patients will have to pre-register and book an appointment online https://web.archive.org/web/20200505120742/https://www.zdnet.com/article/malaysia-to-get-quicker-access-to-covid-19-tests-results/ “A private laboratory consortium in Malaysia is rolling out a nationwide COVID-19 collection and testing programme that aims to conduct more than 5,000 tests a day, with a 24-hour turnaround time. Touted to be the country's largest such collection and testing scheme, it is set to begin as a drive-through service in Klang.”
notes_C7: 'On 11 January, the Malaysian government announced increased and varying restrictions, depending on which state you are in, to enter force at 12:01am, Wednesday 13 January.  Inter-state travel is not permitted across Malaysia. [Inter-district travel is not permitted in Kuala Lumpur, Johor, Labuan, Melaka, Penang, Putrajaya, Sabah, and Selangor. Roadblocks will operate at state boundaries; in addition in these states journeys will be limited to 10km radius].  Internal flights from Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) and Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah Airport (also known as Subang Airport) are operating as usual, but services could be reduced without notice.'    https://archive.vn/oB3e6
notes_H6: From Saturday (Aug 1), face masks are mandatory in public spaces. Under the Prevention and Control of Infectious Diseases Act, those who do not comply with the new rule will face a fine of up to RM1,000 (S$324).  http://web.archive.org/web/20201001193712/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysia-implements-mandatory-mask-wearing-in-crowded-places-from-aug-1   The Malaysian Ministry of Defense instituted a mandatory mask requirement effective August 1, 2020 in crowded areas and on public transportation. The National Security Council released an infographic on August 5, 2020 identifying 14 categories of spaces where masks are required including mosques and prayer halls, houses of worship, public transportation, school buses and vans, zoos, sports and recreation areas (when not participating), clinics and hospitals, public and farmers markets, cinemas and venues with live entertainment, all retail outlets including restaurants, hairdressers and beauticians, spas and wellness centers, and family entertainment outlets.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201001195503/https://my.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: All banks will provide an automatic deferment of all loan/financing repayments for a period of 6 months, with effect from 1 April 2020.  This applies to performing loans that have not been in arrears for more than 90 days as at 1 April 2020. Interest will continue to accrue unless otherwise informed by the bank. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200430210908/https://www.bnm.gov.my/covid19/indiv.php; https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2020/03/24/bank-negara-announces-automatic-six-month-moratorium-on-all-bank-loans-exce/1849820]
notes_C3: 'On 11 January 2021, Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that Movement Control Order restrictions would be re-introduced to the states of Malacca, Johor, Penang, Selangor, Sabah and the federal territories of Kuala Lumpur, Putrajaya, and Labuan between 13 until 26 January 2021. [In these states,] social gatherings and events, including weddings, seminars, and sports, are banned. ... Five person limit at mosques and other places of worship.'    https://archive.vn/pNb3q
notes_C6: No policy change: Malaysian states remain under either the conditional movement control order or the recovery movement control order.  Zones under MCOs, CMCOs, or EMCOs may have curfews in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426070629/https://my.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information
notes_C8: Travel Restrictions most foreigners remain banned from entering Malaysia; exemptions are in place for resident diplomats, foreign spouses and dependents of Malaysian citizens, long-term pass holders, and expatriate employees working in essential industries and their dependents, among others.     Arriving expatriate employees must present an approval letter from authorities. Travelers must test for COVID-19 upon arrival. Those testing positive will undergo treatment at medical facilities, while those testing negative will quarantine for 14 days at designated locations.     Travelers must also download the MySejahtera contact tracing application. Foreigners may transit at Malaysian airports as long as they do not pass through immigration points.     Malaysian nationals remain banned from traveling abroad, with limited exceptions. Emergency repatriation of citizens may occur on a case-by-case basis.    Malaysia allows limited cross-border travel with Singapore for business and official purposes. Under the Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL) scheme, people can travel short-term from Singapore to Malaysia with an exemption from normal quarantine requirements for arrivals. The travelers must present approval letters from immigration authorities and a company or government agency in Malaysia, obtain visas if required, and test for COVID-19 within 72 hours before travel and upon arrival. Such travelers must comply with a controlled itinerary for the first 14 days and contact tracing measures. Additionally, in the Periodic Commuting Arrangement (PCA) scheme for long-term work visa holders, only people traveling to Johor State can quarantine at their residence or accommodations for seven days upon arrival, while those going to other Malaysian states must isolate at government-designated facilities for a week. Travelers can leave the quarantine sites upon testing negative for COVID-19. The PCA program allows the travelers to undertake multiple-entry visits through land border crossings at Woodlands or Tuas for 90-day stays once their applications are approved. Travelers are eligible for a home leave of two to four weeks after every minimum stay of 90 days in the country where they work.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221170524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409741/malaysia-covid-19-restrictions-adjusted-in-most-states-as-of-dec-7-update-18
notes_C2: Ramadan bazaars closed in certain areas with movement restrictions    A curfew is in place for all businesses, including shops and food outlets.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222554/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysia-to-impose-new-movement-restrictions-with-bazaars-schools-to-close-sources
notes_C4: Several areas of the country are currently under different stages of lockdown. For example, the Klang Valley area has been under a lockdown since mid-October that sees office employees having to work from home, while sporting matches including those of football have been prohibited, with training limited to only groups of 10.    https://archive.vn/vCzDk#selection-1455.0-1455.327
notes_H3: No policy change.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322190529/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysian-govt-backtracks-on-covid-19-fines-after-public-outrage
notes_E1: Malaysia on Monday [22 MAR 2021] announced it had established a $2.4 million compensation fund to provide cash assistance for any COVID-19 vaccine recipients who suffer severe reactions due to inoculations.  ...  Under the new fund, individuals requiring extended hospitalisation due to a vaccine reaction will be eligible for 50,000 ringgit ($12,171), or if this results in permanent disability or death 500,000 ringgit, Health Minister Adham Baba said.'    Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced a new economic stimulus package worth RM20 billion (US$4.8 billion) on Wednesday (Mar 17), one year after Malaysia first imposed a lockdown to curb the spread of COVID-19.      https://archive.vn/lrV0B  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419084225/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/malaysia-pm-muhyiddin-rm20-billion-economic-stimulus-covid-19-14428000
notes_H8: The Association of Aged Care Operators of Malaysia (AgeCOpe), medical societies, various Ministry of Health departments, the Selangor COVID Taskforce, the Ministry of Welfare, the Malaysian Ageing Research Institute and other interested parties who developed the Interim Recommendations for the COVID-19 Pandemic in Private, Public, and NGO Residential Aged Care Facilities.     The Interim Recommendation state that strictly ’no visitors should be allowed’ unless the resident is terminally ill, or under special circumstances agreed upon by the management team such as if the resident suffers dementia and exhibits severe behavioural difficulties if the family member does not attend. Contactless temperature, symptom screening, and travel and health declaration would be mandated for visitors who are actually allowed in.    During the first three weeks of the movement control order, the interim recommendations advised against any admission to the care home including hospital discharges and direct admissions from the community.     Care homes voluntarily stop taking in new residents.    Care staff encouraged to move in to care homes.    Ensuring care staff only work in one care home.    Extensive information available through this report:      Hasmuk, Kejal ., Sallehuddin, Hakimah., Tan, Maw Pin., Cheah, Wee Kooi.,   Ibrahim, Rahimah. & Chai, Sen Tyng (2020) "The Long Term Care COVID-19 Situation in  Malaysia", available through https://myageing.upm.edu.my/upload/dokumen/20200603185524Malaysia-LTC-COVID-situation-report-30-May-1.pdf    The archived version:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210104204424/https://myageing.upm.edu.my/upload/dokumen/20200603185524Malaysia-LTC-COVID-situation-report-30-May-1.pdf    Other useful website: https://archive.vn/shRuw  http://web.archive.org/web/20210104204652/https://msgm.com.my/covid-19/
notes_C1: SJK (C) Pin Hwa 1 in Shah Alam will be closed until April 22 after two more pupils tested positive for Covid-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419061335/https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2021/04/18/covid-19-primary-school-in-shah-alam-closed-until-april-22-after-two-more-pupils-test-positive
notes_H7: Malaysia is set to begin its second phase of COVID-19 vaccinations on Monday April 19th, expanding the program to 9.4 million seniors and individuals with chronic diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419090455/https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Coronavirus/COVID-vaccines/Malaysia-weighs-mandatory-COVID-vaccines-as-shots-enter-Phase-2
notes_C5: No policy change: Malaysian states remain under either the conditional movement control order or the recovery movement control order.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426070629/https://my.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Namibia
notes_H1: In State of Emergency declaration: "Public awareness messages and campaigns should be intensified using all media avenues and platforms to reach every community member in all regions" https://web.archive.org/web/20200318152700/https://allafrica.com/stories/202003171066.html
notes_H2: All persons meeting the standard case definition for COVID-19 must be subject to testing.     No change to previous policy as announced in the "Public Health and Covid-19 General Regulations" (https://web.archive.org/web/20201130134825/https://sistemas.mre.gov.br/kitweb/datafiles/Windhoek/pt-br/file/namibia%20-%20govt%20notice%20233%20-%20mohss%20-%20public%20health%20covid-19%20regulations%20-%2023%20set%2020.pdf) on 23 September 2020.
notes_C7: Movement Restrictions:  •	Is a curfew in place? Yes  •	A nationwide curfew is in place between 10:00 pm and 4:00 am daily.  •	Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308085921/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: The correct wearing of face masks is mandatory in all public settings. No change since the announcement of previous government regulations from 13 January.    See the 23rd Covid-19 Public Briefing (https://web.archive.org/web/20210116183005/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Proposed+Ammendments+to+Current+Regulation+13.01.2021.pdf/5a9f41f2-cd24-4ffb-891b-9b053740e7af).
notes_E2: No debit relief for households. https://web.archive.org/web/20201115194555/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: No measures in place to cancel public events, but restrictions to the number of persons allowed apply. A maximum of 200 persons are allowed and all gatherings are encouraged to be outdoors. Registers of attendees at such gatherings and events must be maintained.     See "Update by Dr Kalumbi Shangula, Minister of Health and Social Services on COVID-19 in Namibia" (https://web.archive.org/web/20210103082747/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Daily+Update+15.12.2020.pdf/ee7fa02d-edf1-48b4-b6fb-7079b54f6025), which emphasises the importance of observing COVID-19 prevention measures. Previous COVID-19 measures were announced on 30 November 2020 (https://web.archive.org/web/20210103080555/https://namibiatourism.com.na/uploads/file_uploads/30.11.2020_Statement%20by%20H.E.%20President%20Dr%20Hage%20Geingob%20on%20the%20occasion%20of%20the%2020th%20Public%20Briefing%20on%20the%20National%20Response%20Measures_COVID-19.pdf).
notes_C6: Curfew in place from 10PM to 4AM. No change of policy in 25 February amendment of Public Health Regulations, effective until 31 March.     See the government gazette announcing the amendment:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322185305/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/AMENDMENT+OF+PUBLIC+HEALTH+COVID-19.pdf/e5842462-8d59-4c6e-86df-fe7fec89921f
notes_C8: Arriving international tourists do not have to quarantine if they present a negative COVID-19 PCR test result that is not older than 7 days.  However, non-Namibian travelers (except US) arriving with a negative result that is older than 7 days will be placed in quarantine and tested for COVID-19 on the same day at their own cost.  If the results of this test come out negative, they will be released from quarantine.  If positive, they will be isolated at their own cost, according to Namibia’s isolation protocols.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221215811/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: According to the REPUBLIC OF NAMIBIA website. 9. (1) Heads of the institutions are encouraged to allow vulnerable employees to work from home, subject to suitable arrangements between the employer and employee.(2) Heads of the institutions are encouraged to provide masks to their employees.(3) Heads of the institutions must ensure that their employees at all times adhere to the measures to combat, prevent and suppress the spread of COVID-19  https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/775250/%237255-Proc+N28%285%29.pdf/d3242236-19d6-48f4-8691-ff393360e9da       /web/20201018195410/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-10/06/c_139422633.htm
notes_C4: Gatherings reduced from the previous limit of 200 persons to 50 persons indoors and 100 persons outdoors. It is a requirement that conveners and organisers of such gatherings keep registers of attendees at each gathering, record body temperatures of attendees in such registers and provide facilities for guests to wash their hands with soap or to sanitise their hands. Physical distancing of no less than 1.5 metres between persons must be maintained at all times.    See "Statement by His Excellency Dr Hage G. Geibgob on the Occasion of the 21st Covid-19 Public Briefing on the National Response and Preparedness" (https://web.archive.org/web/20210103031033/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/Statement+by+President+Hage+G.+Geingob%2C+21st+COVID19+Update+16+December+2020.pdf/f9e5acbc-a5a1-40ea-a43e-b902d326d97c) which amended Public Health COVID-19 Regulations effective from 23:59 Wednesday 16 December 2020.
notes_H3: Contact tracing begins as Namibia records its first case. See: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.iol.co.za/news/africa/namibia-confirms-two-covid-19-cases-44882925. Also: https://web.archive.org/save/https://allafrica.com/stories/202003220035.html
notes_E1: Adjustment. Income support is a one time payment in April.   April 1, 2020 A one-time emergency income grant of N$750 to employees who have lost their jobs due to the pandemic and its fallout, limited to a maximum of N$562 million in total. Only Namibian citizens between the ages of 18 and 60 years old who do not receive any other social grants qualify for this grant. Payments will be by the Government in collaboration with the Social Security Commission.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201115200350/https://www.ey.com/en_gl/tax-alerts/namibia-announces-economic-stimulus-and-relief-package-to-mitigate-impact-of-covid-19
notes_H8: Vulnerable persons, i.e., persons above 60 years of age, persons with co-morbidities,  expectant women, and children below the age of 10 years, are advised to stay at home,  except for attending to essential requirements and for health purposes.    All non-Namibian travelers must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test result that is not older than 7 days (168) hours at Port of Entry. They will not be required to be quarantined or to be subjected to another test including when exiting Namibia. The period of 168 hours is reckoned from the time the sample was taken. Namibian citizen may enter Namibia with or without any result. In the absence of any result, they will be subjected to a 7-days quarantine and testing at own cost.    See "AMENDMENTS OF PUBLIC HEALTH COVID 19 GENERAL REGULATIONS: PUBLIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH ACT, 2015: DR KALUMBI SHANGULA, MP, MINISTER OF HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES. 23RD COVID-19 PUBLIC BRIEFING" (https://web.archive.org/web/20210116183005/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Proposed+Ammendments+to+Current+Regulation+13.01.2021.pdf/5a9f41f2-cd24-4ffb-891b-9b053740e7af), with announced measures set to take effect at 23:59 on January 13th, 2021.
notes_C1: According to BBC News Posted at 5:12 on 5 Jan the Namibian government has announced new dates for the reopening of schools. Pupils were scheduled to resume face to face learning on 11 January but will now reopen on 26 January.  Education Minister Anna Nghipondoka said teachers will be expected in schools on 14 January as opposed to 6 January.  Ms Nghipondoka said the new dates were proposed in consultation with the presidency, the office of the prime minister, the ministry of health, the Namibia National Teachers' Union, the national advisory committee on education and other stakeholders. The minister said the government had given guidelines to teachers to prepare in advance and prevent the spread of coronavirus. Parents are expected to buy face masks for their children and provide them with information on how to wear them.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129164457/https://www.bbc.com/news/topics/clm1wxp5pret/namibia
notes_H7: The target populations include frontline health care workers, Community Health Workers, persons who are between 18 to 59 years, persons in close settings and those operating cross-border transportation, employees at Points of Entry, Police Officers,  Journalists, members of the diplomatic corps, Mining and fishery sector employees,  religious and traditional leaders, people with disability, minorities and refugees.     This is in accordance to Phase 1 of Namibia's vaccination plan and the vaccine administered is the Sinopharm SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine.    See the Minister of Health's statement on 16 March "On the Occasion of the First Consignment of the Covid-19 Vaccine":   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322193104/http://www.namibia-botschaft.de/images/stories/Aktuelles/Government/Consignement_of_Covid-19_Vaccines_MoHSS_160321.pdf
notes_C5: Public transport is in operation but subject to COVID-19 prevention measures. Coded as such according to the coding interpretation guide. No change of policy in 25 February amendment of Public Health Regulations, effective until 31 March.     See the government gazette announcing the amendment:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322185305/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/AMENDMENT+OF+PUBLIC+HEALTH+COVID-19.pdf/e5842462-8d59-4c6e-86df-fe7fec89921f

name: Niger
notes_H1: There is a campaign for the measures to help curb the virus. This is video from the website of the Ministry of Health on COVID-19. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201115201433/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ogx3nXb_voM&feature=youtu.be
notes_H2: The testing is available at a cost according to the US embassy in Niger's website;    The Center for Medical Research and Health (CERMES) started conducting tests on Saturday, August 1, 2020. It takes about 24 to 48 hours for results to be issued.  You can call between 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. to make an appointment.  The contact information is listed below.  Once a certificate of the test result is issued, it will be valid for 72 hours.  Location: Google Maps    Centre de Recherches Médicales et Sanitaires  BP 10887 – Niamey YN034 Niger  Phone: 20752040 / 20752045 / 88526448 / 80090111    Cost    Rapid Test: 7,500 FCFA  PCR Test: 30,000 FCFA    Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: There are no restrictions according to the website of the US embassy in Niger. Please see:    https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Required in some public spaces; source: /web/20210222175218/https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/face-covering-policies-covid?stackMode=absolute&time=2021-02-22&country=®ion=World
notes_E2: An updated crisis response plan has been presented to donors with an estimated cost of 18.4 percent of GDP, divided into an immediate health response and broader economic and social mitigation. Key elements are already being implemented, such as food distribution, two months of free utilities to the vulnerable households and temporary tax relief for hard-hit sectors.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118160006/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Recommended cancellation; source: /web/20210222172313/https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/public-events-covid?stackMode=absolute&time=2021-02-19®ion=World
notes_C6: There are no curfews nor confinements. There is requirement to use masks and practice social distancing. Please see:    https://web.archive.org/web/20201021222926/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: All travellers entering Niger from countries suffering from the COVID-19 must self-quarantine in their homes or in another adequate location for a period of 14 days.    A rapid COVID-19 test and a nasal swab may be taken from passengers upon arrival and passengers will be encouraged to self-quarantine at a precise address.  Niger will fine airlines for boarding passengers who do not have a valid certificate of a negative test result taken within the previous 72 hours.    All people testing positive for COVID-19 at the airports will be led automatically to a governmental quarantine site.  Foreign nationals who refuse a COVID-19 test at the airport will be denied entry into Niger and turned back to the airlines.  Nigerien nationals who refuse a test at the airport will have their passports seized by the Nigerien police.  The Center for Medical Research and Health (CERMES) started conducting tests on Saturday, August 1, 2020. It takes about 24 to 48 hours for results to be issued.  You can call between 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. to make an appointment.  The contact information is listed below.  Once a certificate of the test result is issued, it will be valid for 72 hours.    Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20201101155814/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201011201056/https://coronavirus.ne/quarantaine/#
notes_C2: According to the UK government's website on travel to Niger, some hotels are open with social distancing measures in place.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115203759/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/niger/coronavirus  Restaurants, shops and bars are open with social distancing measures in place.
notes_C4: Restrictions based on the size of public gatherings as follows:  gatherings between 10-100 people; source: /web/20210222172632/https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/public-gathering-rules-covid?stackMode=absolute&time=2021-02-22®ion=World
notes_H3: No evidence that contract tracing is occurring.  No mention.     https://coronavirus.ne/test-covid-19/
notes_C1: According to UNESCO schools in Niger are fully open.  Source:

name: Nigeria
notes_H1: From 31 Jan, with the CDC issuing second Public Health Advisory, it started taking shape of a coordinated information campaign. Here, guidelines for healthcare workers were provided and a toll free number was provided along with general awareness info for the public. https://web.archive.org/web/20200412203307/https://ncdc.gov.ng/news/219/31st-january-2020%257C-public-health-advisory-to-nigerians-on-novel-coronavirus-%2528%25232%2529    Subsequently, NCDC also launched a WhatsApp APL, a free to use service to provide a central source of accurate, verified and current information on COVID-19 in Nigeria.; https://statehouse.gov.ng/news/covid-19-what-president-buhari-has-done-and-is-doingby-presidency/ (not archivable)
notes_H2: As of July, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) defined 13 categories of cases which should be prioritized for testing. People who are not in one of these categories are considered low-risk and should therefore remain in self-isolation for 14 days, and inform the State Response Team if they develop any symptoms prior to testing.     Source:  NCDC "Strategies to Improve Surveillance for COVID-19: Guidance for States", pp. 2-4  https://web.archive.org/web/20200726071942/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/media/files/SurveillanceStrategies.pdf
notes_C7: According to the US Embassy in Nigeria, there are no internal restrictions to movement. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315005808/https://ng.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Masks are required in all public places. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210315005735/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_E2: On the contrary, the Nigerian government decided that regulated fuel prices be reduced, and an automatic fuel price formula introduced to ensure fuel subsidies are eliminated. Electricity tariff was increased.     Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108130923/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: "Limit government meetings to virtual as much as possible while maintaining restrictions on physical meetings including official trips, oversight visits and board meetings until further notice  Lifting of restrictions on outdoor communal sports and opening of recreational parks for supervised exercise  Mandatory use of non-medical facemasks in public spaces with access to government and commercial premises to be denied for persons not wearing facemasks. ‘No mask, no entry. No mask, no service.’  Maintaining the prohibition of gathering of more than twenty (20) persons outside of a workplace"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200821231028/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_C6: Curfew: Imposition of overnight curfew nationwide from 8pm to 6am.  General movement:  May go out for work, to buy necessary foods and for exercise; Persons above age of 65 years and those with underlying chronic illness e.g. diabetes, high blood pressure are advised to remain at home    https://web.archive.org/web/20200525230111/http://statehouse.gov.ng/covid19/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/IMPLEMENTATION-GUIDELINES-FOR-EASING-LOCKDOWN-Phase-1-May-4-to-May-17-2020.pdf    Please also see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108141902/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/04/27/nigeria-buhari-to-unwind-covid-19-lockdown-in-key-states/?gb=true
notes_C8: ON ARRIVAL IN NIGERIA  Passengers who have arrived in Nigeria must self-isolate for 14 days and remain in the city/state where the point of entry is located (i.e. Lagos or Abuja) throughout the duration of self-isolation  Passengers must provide their correct address and phone number before exiting the airport. They must comply with self-isolation/quarantine guidelines and ensure that they can be reached during the period  Passengers not resident in Lagos or Abuja must arrange for accommodation at their own cost (please note that the Federal Government will not be responsible for providing accommodation nor transportation to the place of abode)  Passengers will be cleared through the Nigeria Immigration System’s Migrants Identification Data Analysis System (MIDAS) and their passports retained until after successful completion of the 14 days self-isolation (this why correct contact information must be provided)  All passengers will be tested within 72 hours of arrival based on appointment at a sample collection centre located in Lagos or Abuja for a repeat COVID-19 PCR test  Persons who are unable to remain in Lagos or Abuja throughout the period of self-quarantine may return to their states of residence ONLY after:       (a) They have had their samples collected and are NEGATIVE for COVID-19, and    (b) They have provided public health officials with their full and correct address and phone number where they can be reached    Persons who have completed the 14 days of self-isolation/quarantine will undergo an exit interview. Their details will be forwarded to the Nigeria Immigration Service for release of their passports. Alternative arrangements can be made to collect passports via special delivery e.g. DHL  At the seaports, ships arriving are subjected to mandatory health screening and clearance by the Port Health Services. This particularly applies to ships that have been at sea for less than 14 days and/or that have crew members who are ill.    Source:http://web.archive.org/web/20200821231028/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_C2: "...Federal and State government offices to operate normal working hours, but only essential staff from GL.12 and above can resume work  Limit government meetings to virtual as much as possible while maintaining restrictions on physical meetings including official trips, oversight visits and board meetings until further notice...    ADVICE FOR BUSINESSES  The NCDC has published a guideline for employers and businesses in Nigeria however, the agency is working with various industries to develop sector-specific guidelines as the financial sector and manufacturing industry is fully open while the informal sector will have a phased opening."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200821231028/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_C4: On 29 July the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 announced the extension of Phase Two of the eased lockdown, therefore the prohibition of gatherings of more than 20 people outside of a workplace remain in place.    Source:  The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control website  https://web.archive.org/web/20200812053903/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/
notes_H3: Nigeria records first case of COVID 19: NCDC digital tool for surveillance, SORMAS, is being used to manage contact tracing and related activities to quickly control the spread of the disease. Contact tracing is ongoing to identify everyone who has come in contact with the confirmed case. https://web.archive.org/web/20200412212133/https://ncdc.gov.ng/news/item/232/?t=frequently-asked-questions-on-coronavirus---29%252F02%252F20 https://web.archive.org/web/20200412213346/https://ncdc.gov.ng/reports/246/2020-february-week-7
notes_E1: According to the IMF;  The social register was increased by 1 million households to 3.6 million to help cushion the effect of the lockdown. A broader economic stimulus plan that includes the N500 billion COVID-19 intervention fund was introduced to support the real sector.     At the time of this reporting, it was not expressly determined if the support is still ongoing.     Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108130923/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H8: Movement Restrictions    Is a curfew in place? Yes  The Government of Nigeria continues to have a 12:00 a.m. to 4:00 a.m. daily curfew in place.  We urge U.S. citizens to check as individual states may have more restrictive curfews.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426183729/https://ng.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Country-Specific Information    Nigeria is experiencing a reduction in COVID-19 cases.  Basic services (i.e., grocery stores, gas stations, transportation etc.) are available in Nigeria, and schools have resumed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426183729/https://ng.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: Nigeria is currently registering people electronically for vaccination to ensure efficient and orderly scheduling of the date and time to receive the vaccine, Mr. Shuaib tells Africa Renewal. This is the first time Nigeria will pre-register people for vaccination.    All persons 18 years and above can register for the vaccination through an e-registration portal. The country relies on the media to promote this e-registration under an electronic immunization data management scheme.     The vaccination is then carried out in phases, according to predetermined classifications, Mr. Shuaib says. Frontline health workers are prioritized for the jab so they can safely care for others.    The primary health care agency uses its electronic database to track those who have received the first dose in order to know when they are due for their second dose.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426191848/https://www.un.org/africarenewal/magazine/april-2021/nigeria-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-kicks-africas-most-populous-country
notes_C5: Transportation Options    Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Passengers must wear face masks when taking public transportation and public transportation is limited to 50% capacity.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426183729/https://ng.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Nicaragua
notes_H1: Upgraded due to (1) the launch of vaccination campaign, and (2) the existence of a public campaign by the MINSA.     (1) http://www.minsa.gob.ni/index.php/111-noticias2021/6228-nicaragua-es-un-pais-donde-nos-cuidamos-y-se-hacen-los-mas-grandes-esfuerzos-para-garantizar-salud      (2) https://web.archive.org/web/20210418054857/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H2: Test are made available to those with symptoms. https://web.archive.org/web/20200519004757/https://www.el19digital.com/articulos/ver/titulo:100454-nicaragua-seguira-tomando-medidas-frente-a-la-posible-expansion-del-coronavirus-por-el-mundo
notes_H6: Downgraded since the data does not provide clear distinction between recommendation and obligation. Also, data is from 12 December 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210415131023/https://masks4all.co/what-countries-require-masks-in-public/
notes_E2: Downgraded to 0 because a reduction of credit payments should have terminated on 31 March 2021.    “On June 19, 2020, the Superintendence of Banks and Other Financial Institutions issued a temporary financial regulation reducing the minimum monthly payment for credit cards from 3 to 2 percent of the total debt, including interests. This measure will be in force until March 31, 2021.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418054857/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C8: International visitors must present a negative COVID-19 certificate in order to enter the country. There is no evidence of a requirement to quarantine on arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201013194602/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nicaragua/entry-requirements
notes_H3: According to the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO), the trace of the virus has been completely lost within the country. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200604201905/https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2020/06/03/la-ops-califico-la-situacion-del-coronavirus-en-nicaragua-como-muy-preocupante-y-dificil-de-controlar/
notes_H8: October 9 - The Ministry of Health of Nicaragua (MINSA) launched a National Campaign to continue protecting us against Covid-19.  "Whenever we are gathered as a family when coughing or sneezing, we should cover the nose and mouth with the inner corner of the elbow and wash hands immediately with soap and water. In the case of our older adults or a member of the family with diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular diseases, chronic respiratory problems or immunodeficiency, we must guarantee that they take their medicines and maintain protective measures to avoid complications with respiratory diseases (...) The elderly need to avoid contact with people who have respiratory diseases symptoms, leave the home only if necessary, avoid places with crowds of people and, if they do, keep a distance of 1.5 meters and the use of a mask is recommended (...)"  Note: Selected a 2 (instead of 3) because it seems to be more adequate taking into consideration the country's reality and the press release mentions that the elderly should "avoid places with crowds of people and, if they do, keep a distance of 1.5 meters and the use of a mask is recommended" - meaning they have the possibility to do so.  Source: www.minsa.gob.ni/index.php/component/content/article/110-noticias-2020/5682-gobierno-de-nicaragua-fortalece-campana-de-proteccion-contra-el-covid-19 (unable to archive)
notes_C1: Schools are fully open.    Source: https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse (unable to archive)
notes_H7: Group B: Clinically vulnerable groups  “Since March 2, the good Sandinista Government through the Ministry of Health (Minsa) has carried out the voluntary vaccination process against covid-19 in public and private hospitals for patients undergoing hemodialysis and dialysis.”    [Impossible to archive]  http://www.minsa.gob.ni/index.php/111-noticias2021/6215-mas-pacientes-completan-esquema-de-vacunacion-voluntaria-en-hospital-san-juan-de-dios-en-esteli

name: Netherlands
notes_H1: The Dutch government provides a list of different advice on their website, including on:  Tackling new coronavirus in the Netherlands  Frequently asked questions about coronavirus and health  Frequently asked questions about staying at home and physical contac  Frequently asked questions about coronavirus and childcare  Frequently asked questions about the education sector  Frequently asked questions about work  Frequently asked questions for travellers  Frequently asked questions about travel, aviation and public transport    Given the clear health advice contained within, upgraded to 2G on review.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200306114951/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19
notes_H2: On June 1 2020, several measures were relaxed in the Netherlands. From 1 June, anyone with mild symptoms that may point to coronavirus will be able to phone a national hotline and make an appointment to be tested by the municipal health service (GGD). Loss of smell or taste have been added to the list of symptoms that may point to a coronavirus infection.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200610123042/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/05/28/press-conference-of-27-may-current-roadmap-of-measures-against-coronavirus
notes_C7: The Netherlands entered its strictest lockdown yet from 15 December until at least Tuesday 19 January.     Cannot see explicit ban on domestic movement but strong recommendation to stay at home      https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people
notes_H6: The cities of Amsterdam and Rotterdam have announced that they will no longer require face masks in certain parts of the city, a policy that had started on 5 August and was meant to go until the end of August as an 'experiment.'  Both cities said they will wait until the results of the experiment whether to see if they reintroduce face masks.     https://www.dutchnews.nl/news/2020/08/amsterdam-and-rotterdam-stop-requiring-face-masks-in-busy-places/
notes_E2: ***Recoded from 2 to 1    No evidence found to support presence of broad debt or contract relief for households. Previously, only two updates were done between 9/28/2020 and 1/30/2021, sources below.     "There will also be a guarantee fund to provide better and faster support to people with problematic debts. This involves 30 million euros. The fund makes it easier for municipalities and other parties to use remediation credits. With this, creditors can be partially paid in one go, the residual debt is waived and the client only has one creditor left. This creates more control over the financial situation. Major public creditors such as UWV, SVB and the Tax Authorities will also make the possibility of deferment of payment more transparent to people with problematic debts. Since this spring, the CJIB has already had the option of an 'emergency stop', the temporary halt of recovery. The condition is that the person in question reports to the municipal debt counseling service."   ***This has been recoded from 2 to 1 as this is a very limited measure and no additional measures can be found.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200928144349/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/actueel/nieuws/2020/09/28/extra-geld-voor-versterken-gemeentelijke-aanpak-schulden-en-armoede    Old source from January 2021 referred to unemployment, not debt relief: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123175030/https://business.gov.nl/corona/overview/the-coronavirus-and-your-company/
notes_C3: During a national press conference, Prime Minister Mark Rutte and Minister of Health Hugo de Jonge announced new national measures that come into effect on Tuesday 29 September at 18.00 and will be in force for at least the next 3 weeks.  The new measures include:  - No more than 4 people can form a group in buildings other than someone's home (where the limit is 3).   - The number of people in one room is limited to 30 people. Outdoors the limit is 40 people. Exceptions are in place for certain events such as religious events or sports events. However, there are no exceptions mentioned for other types of public events and this in effect bans most public events both indoors and outdoors. Therefore, upgraded to 2G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201008115110/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/09/28/additional-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-coronavirus
notes_C6: Curfew has been lifted. However there is still a recommendation to work from home, stay home, and limit interactions with others.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210430111400/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2021/04/20/step-1-shops-and-outdoor-seating-at-restaurants-and-cafes-will-partially-reopen-evening-curfew-lifted
notes_C8: The Netherlands will begin banning the arrival of flights from several countries among the most affected by the Covid-19 coronavirus outbreak. The decision will affect flights from China, Hong Kong, Iran, Italy and South Korea, said Infrastructure Minister Cora van Nieuwenhuizen on Friday after a meeting with Cabinet members.    The restriction was set to begin at 6 p.m. on Friday, the 13th March, less than three hours after the announcement was made. All countries involved were notified beforehand, a spokesperson for the Ministry of Infrastructure told NL Times. The rules will remain in place through March 26, but it could be adjusted on any given day with countries being added or removed from the list as necessary.    https://archive.vn/FO8Fz
notes_C2: "People performing contact-based professions, such as hairdressers and masseurs, will be able to practise again from 3 March 2021. Customers must make a reservation and must be asked if they have any symptoms that could point to COVID-19. It is also important to wear a face mask and, where possible, to stay 1.5 metres apart.    The relaxation of this measure will also apply to driving instructors. From 3 March, people will be able to take driving lessons again, and the practical driving test will be available to anyone. The government is exploring ways to enable driving students to safely take the theory test at the earliest possible opportunity.    The basic hygiene measures will of course continue to apply, and you must stay at home if you have symptoms of COVID-19.    Sex workers may not practise their profession at this time."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224181133/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/02/23/more-breathing-space-in-lockdown-but-caution-remains
notes_C4: "The most significant new measure is that the government strongly and urgently advises people to limit the number of guests they receive at home to a maximum of six (excluding children under 13). This includes both indoors and in outdoor spaces like gardens. Guests should also be asked whether they have any symptoms and if so, they should not attend. It goes without saying that people should always stay 1.5 metres away from each other."      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200822163949/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2020/08/18/let-s-keep-coronavirus-out
notes_H3: Insufficient evidence for comprehensive tracing on government websites
notes_E1: Since 1 Oct 2020 the govt policy "NOW3" is in force: over the course of 3 times 3 months, until July 2021, people receive income support of 80%, 70% and 60% respectively.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201026183550/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-financiele-regelingen/overzicht-financiele-regelingen/now
notes_H8: "From 22.00 on Wednesday 4 November up to and including Wednesday 18 November, the following measures will apply:    - You may receive no more than 2 people a day in your home.  - The maximum group size outdoors and indoors (except in your home) is 2 people from different households.  - There is no maximum number of people for a household.    - Stay at home as much as possible, including during the festive season.  - Avoid non-essential travel.  - Work from home, unless it is absolutely necessary that you go to work.  - Everyone aged 13 and over must wear a face mask in indoor public spaces and on public transport."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210109134432/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2020/11/03/temporary-tightening-of-partial-lockdown
notes_C1: Most school levels are now open    https://web.archive.org/web/20210506144551/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/coronavirus-measures-in-brief
notes_H7: A- key workers- healthcare workers: BioNTech/Pfizer or AstraZeneca  B-Vulnerable groups -Nursing home residents and residents of care homes for people with intellectual disabilities: BioNTech/Pfizer -People living in small-scale residential homes and residential care homes for people with intellectual disabilities: BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna  C- Elderly groups People aged 90 and over who live at home and are mobile: BioNTech/Pfizer -People aged 65 and over who live at home and are mobile (from oldest to youngest):BioNTech/Pfizer -People aged between 60 and 65 (from oldest to youngest): Astrazeneca People aged 60 and over (and healthcare workers) on the Wadden Islands : BioNTech/Pfizer  ***Updated to add working links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210226152203/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/dutch-vaccination-programme/order-of-vaccination-against-coronavirus/order-of-vaccination-for-people-who-do-not-work-in-healthcare  http://web.archive.org/web/20210226152300/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/dutch-vaccination-programme/order-of-vaccination-against-coronavirus/health-and-care-workers
notes_C5: ***Recoded from 2 to 1; while it is recommended that public transport is used for essential travel only, that is a recommendation only and transport remains open to general public with face masks required.     The Netherlands entered its strictest lockdown yet from 15 December until at least Tuesday 19 January.     Public transport is for essential travel only.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

name: Norway
notes_H1: Dedicated webpage by the Norwegian Institute of Public Health on Coronavirus disease (earliest archived page found on 31 January 2020).  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200131115642/https://fhi.no/en/id/infectious-diseases/coronavirus/
notes_H2: According to  the news published on 25th May in The Local News, Health Agency of Norway "Norway's health agency has abandoned plans to test broadly for coronavirus after judging that the spread of infection in the country is now so low that doing so would be pointlessInstead, tests will be reserved for those who have symptoms of coronavirus, those who work in healthcare or elderly care homes, and those in risk groups.The institute made an exception for elderly care homes, where it has decided staff and patients can be tested whether they exhibit symptoms or not."  Note: Previous dates can be reviewed again .  Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20200610111255/https://www.thelocal.no/20200525/infection-rates-in-norway-too-low-to-justify-broad-testing
notes_C7: Avoid non-essential domestic travel. Work-related travel that is deemed essential and travel to and from second homes that can be completed without coming into contact with others are exempt.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113153459/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/new-nationwide-measures/id2783806/
notes_H6: New national restrictions take place from March 25, "Use face masks anywhere when not possible to maintain a two-metre social distance"     https://archive.is/kMukP; https://www.thelocal.no/20210323/norway-considering-new-covid-19-easter-restrictions/
notes_C3: A maximum of 10 people can attend events    https://web.archive.org/web/20210430113551/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-16-april-2021/id2826828/    The same policy is now implemented in Oslo    https://web.archive.org/web/20210430114044/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/status-om-handteringen-av-korona/27-april-byradet-med-plan-for-gradvis-gjenapning-av-oslo
notes_C6: November 5th: The Government is introducing new national infection control measures.   “My message to the Norwegian people is: Stay at home as much as possible".  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113153042/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/stay-at-home-have-as-little-social-contact-as-possible/id2783763/
notes_C8: "Effective Jan. 29, all international travelers, with the exception of Norwegian citizens and legal residents, will be barred from entry. Nevertheless, certain exemptions will be in place for health workers arriving from Sweden and Finland, freight transporters, and aircraft crews, as well as for close family members of Norway residents. Journalists and other personnel on assignment for foreign media institutions, and foreigners who work within critical social functions will also still be allowed entry."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210127223054/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/435676/norway-authorities-to-close-borders-to-most-non-norwegian-residents-from-jan-29-due-to-new-strain-of-covid-19-update-31
notes_C2: "Authorities in Norway will tighten restrictions imposed to combat the spread of COVID-19 in the capital Oslo from March 2 due to rising infection numbers in the city. All nonessential businesses and services must close, and catering establishments may only offer take-away services. Furthermore, all events are banned with limited exceptions such as weddings and funerals, which may have a maximum of five participants.    Elsewhere in Norway, most nonessential businesses and services are open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures; however, limitations on the size of private gatherings remain in effect. Individuals are advised to limit their social contacts and avoid all nonessential travel. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Additional municipalities with higher rates of infection may also vary the restrictions imposed in their jurisdiction."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135837/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/449236/norway-authorities-to-tighten-covid-19-restrictions-in-oslo-from-march-2-update-34
notes_C4: A maximum of 10 persons can gather    https://web.archive.org/web/20210430113551/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-16-april-2021/id2826828/    The same policy is now implemented in Oslo    https://web.archive.org/web/20210430114044/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/status-om-handteringen-av-korona/27-april-byradet-med-plan-for-gradvis-gjenapning-av-oslo
notes_H3: "The Norwegian Government introduced a contract tracing app in month of April which I think is tracing comprehensively. But it can reviewed again. I did not change the status April but from dates allocated to me.  the Norwegian Institute of Public Health has launched a contact tracing solution to improve the effectiveness of the manual contact tracing technique. The app works by registering the identity of other nearby phones using Bluetooth and collecting movements of the phone using geolocation data in a central server. Unlike solutions from other countries, the Norwegian Smittestopp solution collects data to research the spread of the disease and the effect of actions by health authorities in addition to tracing infections. While the effectiveness of contact tracing apps is contested, it is especially important to ensure that those implemented preserve the privacy of their users, thus safeguarding against many other issues."  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200525122554/https://medium.com/@jointstatementnorway/joint-statement-on-contact-tracing-for-norway-331ee49fc6f6
notes_E1: "Employees will retain 100 % of their pay up to 6G (G = the National Insurance basic amount. 1G is NOK 99 858 per May 1 2019) from day 3 up to and including day 20 of the layoff period. The changes are effective from 20 March, but further details will not be formally in place until next week. Employees will receive any money they are owed once the technical solutions are available and NAV has processed their applications. Employees who have been laid off and are still receiving pay from their employers will be transferred to the new system from 20 March inclusive."   "The rate of unemployment benefit for people who are laid off and for those who lose their jobs has been raised to 80 % of their income (this is the income calculated by NAV as a basis for paying benefits) for an income of up to 3G and 62.4 % of income between 3G and 6G. This also enters into force on 20 March."   http://web.archive.org/web/20200716193228/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/changes-to-the-rules-for-temporary-layoffs-and-unemployment-benefits/id2694346/
notes_H8: Nursing home visitors in Oslo are now allwoed, but must follow saftey procedures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210506142540/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/korona-1/byradet-fortsetter-en-gradvis-og-kontrollert-gjenapning-av-oslo-1    https://web.archive.org/web/20210506143509/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/english/coronavirus/advice-and-rules-in-the-city-of-oslo/
notes_C1: Non essential shops in Oslo were permitted to open as of 6th May    https://web.archive.org/web/20210506142540/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/korona-1/byradet-fortsetter-en-gradvis-og-kontrollert-gjenapning-av-oslo-1
notes_H7: A- Key workers (healthcare workers)  B- 18-64 At Risk groups  C- Elderly groups- Above 65    No information on the type of vaccine given was found. But it should be noted that Norway suspended the use of the Astrazeneca vaccine    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318112315/https://www.fhi.no/en/publ/posters/vaksineringsscenario/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318112508/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-56357760
notes_C5: Coded as 1 to reflect alterations due to covid:     To help maintain enough space, we allow fewer passengers on board our vehicles. Most seats are available, except for the seats behind the driver on buses and trams. There is a limited number of spaces for standing passengers. Please keep recommended distance to others: At least one metre face-to-face.    If the recommended distance cannot be maintained, please disembark and wait for the next departure or use an alternative route.    You have the right to travel as long as you comply with the existing rules for passenger capacity. That means our travel guarantee no longer applies if the means of travel does not have space for you on board.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126113419/https://ruter.no/en/news/travel-advice-for-public-transport/

name: Nepal
notes_H1: Situation Report #1: Information, Education and Communication materials developed and disseminated in close coordination; https://drive.google.com/file/d/1mp0zAbQvNgy9kr1hgjqPZlQhtqMJFoil/view (not archivable)
notes_H2: Nepal, which has poor health infrastructure, says it has testing facilities for 23,000 samples, but on an average fewer than 15,000 tests are conducted daily.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418203536/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-nepal/nepal-to-provide-free-covid-19-tests-and-treatment-as-cases-surge-idINKBN27Q0QA
notes_C7: Internal movement of people from one place to other restricted in second lockdown, from April 29.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210430145905/https://kathmandupost.com/money/2021/04/28/explained-nepal-s-lockdown-2-0-new-covid-curbs-on-travel  Domestic flights are being operated on schedule.  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/4/29/nepal-starts-15-day-covid-lockdown-as-infections-spike
notes_H6: The government of Nepal has announced that members of the public found outdoors without a mask can be and have been arrested and fined. This seems like a nationwide measure. See: https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/ (web archive unavailable, accessed 17th September 2020)
notes_E2: Social assistance will be strengthened by providing those most vulnerable with daily food rations, subsidizing utility bills for low-usage customers, extending tax-filing deadlines, and taking measures to partially compensate those in the formal sector for lost wages in the event of job loss.  Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200716182728/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Public events are required to be conducted virtually from   and if physical attendance is necessary then less than 25 people can attend an event following all public health measures.  Page 3, point 7  60yrs are recommended not to come out of home and if necessary to follow strict public health guidelines.  Page 12, point 22(f) This is the government short-term policy document, so this could not be archived ( http://rajpatra.dop.gov.np/welcome/book/?ref=24447&fbclid=IwAR1kOU6Eciuqlg07bp5GXHBlyVh1kwLdr3tiKR4DSNb3iEg6eLnhrxkXvbI) This page could not be archived.
notes_C6: Shopping essential items are allowed only in fixed time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503171003/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/471666/nepal-officials-to-impose-tighter-restrictions-in-kathmandu-valley-april-29-through-may-5-update-40
notes_C8: https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C2: All the workplace prohibited to be opened except the essential ones from April 29.  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/4/29/nepal-starts-15-day-covid-lockdown-as-infections-spike
notes_C4: Gathering of more than 25 people restricted from April 29.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503171003/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/471666/nepal-officials-to-impose-tighter-restrictions-in-kathmandu-valley-april-29-through-may-5-update-40
notes_H3: The city has formed five teams for contact tracing for Kathmandu’s 32 wards. Each team should consist of three members—a lab technician, a public health officer and a paramedic—as per the Health Ministry’s guidelines. But there are only two people in a team due to the lack of personnel.  Contact tracing is key, but a lack of human resource is making it ineffective.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022094445/https://kathmandupost.com/health/2020/08/14/contact-tracing-is-key-but-a-lack-of-human-resource-is-making-it-ineffective
notes_H8: People aged 60 years are recommended not to go out from home and if necessary, they need to follow public health guidelines strictly.  Page 12, point 22(f).  This is a short term government policy document released on 19 April 2021 and is to be practiced until 14 May 2021.http://rajpatra.dop.gov.np/welcome/book/?ref=24447&fbclid=IwAR1kOU6Eciuqlg07bp5GXHBlyVh1kwLdr3tiKR4DSNb3iEg6eLnhrxkXvbI
notes_C1: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420125318/https://www.aninews.in/news/world/asia/nepal-to-close-all-schools-in-urban-areas-till-may-14-in-wake-of-rising-covid-19-cases20210419133107/    "Kathmandu [Nepal], April 19 (ANI): An emergency ministerial meeting of Nepal Cabinet on Monday decided to close all the educational institutions of urban areas till May 14 in the wake of rising COVID-19 cases.  The information about the closure of schools in urban areas was shared by a sitting minister.  "Meeting has decided to close the schools and colleges till end of Baisakh (May 14). Along with the educational institutions other services which brings on more people at one place also has been asked to close," Prabhu Shah, a sitting Minister in cabinet of Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli told ANI over phone."
notes_H7: A and C  Covishield to health workers and elderly  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503170126if_/https://thehimalayantimes.com/photo-gallery/in-pictures-covid-19-vaccination-drive-begins-for-elderly-in-nepal
notes_C5: Public vehicles are not allowed to run from April 29.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210430145905/https://kathmandupost.com/money/2021/04/28/explained-nepal-s-lockdown-2-0-new-covid-curbs-on-travel

name: New Zealand
notes_H1: The NZL Ministry of Health first started tweeting about Coronavirus on Jan 22 (Source 1) and since then has posted frequent updates. On Feb 6th, the Ministry established a hotline specifically for queries related to COVID(Source 2)   Source 1: https://web.archive.org/web/20200615132824/https://twitter.com/minhealthnz/status/1219741776891674624  Source 2: https://web.archive.org/web/20200210092653/https://twitter.com/minhealthnz/status/1225278782845702145
notes_H2: 20/01/2021 - 29/01/2021 : The New Zealand Govt. Ministry of Health website states that anyone with symptoms should get tested for COVID-19 and that a COVID-19 test is free of charge, unless for the purposes of entering another country.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210129070049/https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-health-advice-public/assessment-and-testing-covid-19
notes_C7: 7 March 2021  Auckland moves to Alert Level 2 at 6am. The rest of New Zealand moves to Alert Level 1.      "You can travel to other regions that are at Alert Level 2 or lower"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315225815/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-system/alert-level-2/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315224754/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-system/history-of-the-covid-19-alert-system/
notes_H6: 20/01/2021 - 29/01/2021:  New Zealand has a national Four Level COVID Alert System.  Between 20/01/2021 and 29/01/2021 all of New Zealand has maintained a Level One alert level.  This is the lowest (least restrictive) alert level.    The use of masks or face coverings is mandatory for: people travelling on public transport services in, into and out of the Auckland region; the drivers of small passenger service vehicles in Auckland, such as taxis and app-based ride services; and  people travelling on passenger flights throughout New Zealand.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210129043621/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-system/current-alert-level/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129071130/https://covid19.govt.nz/health-and-wellbeing/protect-yourself-and-others/wear-a-face-covering/

notes_E1: 20/01/2021 to 29/01/2021: According to the New Zealand Government's 'Work and Income' website, applications for the COVID-19 Income Relief Payment closed on 14 November 2020.  However, for those already receiving the payment, it is planned to continue till 4th Feb 2021.  According to the New Zealand Government's 'Stats' website,  median weekly earnings in the June 2020 quarter were $1,189 for full-time workers. The current rate for the COVID Income Relief Payment is a maximum of $490 per week.      There is also a COVID-19 Leave Support Scheme in place.  This is a 2 week payment for individuals who are working but have been required to self-isolate.  This is paid at a higher $585.80 per week maximum rate; but only for a 2 week period.  This rate remains less than 50% of the New Zealand median wage.   Therefore have coded as 1 <50% lost income.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210129060126/https://www.workandincome.govt.nz/covid-19/income-relief-payment/payment-rates.html   https://web.archive.org/web/20210129060240/https://www.workandincome.govt.nz/covid-19/income-relief-payment/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126124339/https://www.stats.govt.nz/information-releases/labour-market-statistics-income-june-2020-quarter
notes_H8: 20/01/2021 - 29/01/2021:  New Zealand has a national Four Level COVID Alert System.  Between 20/01/2021 and 29/01/2021 all of New Zealand has maintained a Level One alert level.  This is the lowest (least restrictive) alert level.    "During Alert Level 1, visits will be allowed. Providers may continue to take some extra precautions to reduce the risk to the residents and staff. Contact the provider to discuss your visit.  Formal visiting hours may remain in place.   Remember to follow the Alert Level 1 guidelines. This includes:  washing and drying your hands; coughing into your elbow; not touching your face; keeping a record of where you’ve been."  These recommended precautions are not specific to Aged Care facilities and therefore have coded 0 - No Measures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210129072536/https://covid19.govt.nz/everyday-life/parents-caregivers-and-whanau/visiting-an-aged-residential-care-facility/    Additionally there is no mention of measures to protect elderly people when at Alert Level 1 within the current 'COVID-19 Public Health Response (Alert Level Requirements) Order 2020' which is made by the Minister of Health under section 11 of the COVID-19 Public Health Response Act 2020 in accordance with section 9 of that Act.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201112190625/http://www.legislation.govt.nz/regulation/public/2020/0231/latest/whole.html
notes_C1: 7 March 2021  Auckland moves to Alert Level 2 at 6am. The rest of New Zealand moves to Alert Level 1.    Early learning services, schools and tertiary education facilities are open to all ages. There are some restrictions if a confirmed or probable case of COVID-19 is found related to an educational facility    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315225815/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-system/alert-level-2/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315224754/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-system/history-of-the-covid-19-alert-system/
notes_H7: According to the vaccine timeline, A are being vaccinated but people living in high-risk areas are also being vaccinated. Since the latter includes people living and working in care homes, they belong to B and C. However, all people from B and C are not being vaccinated just yet.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329220854/https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-getting-vaccine/covid-19-when-you-can-get-vaccine    The vaccine type seems to be Pfizer/BioNTech as the other vaccines are still in agreement-in-principle stage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329221058/https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-types-vaccines
notes_C5: New Zealand has reduced its alert level to '2', which only requires "Appropriate physical distancing and other risk mitigating measures in place on public transport and aircraft as agreed by relevant agencies."    "New Zealand moved to Alert Level 2 at 11:59pm on Wednesday 13 May."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200517163106/https://covid19.govt.nz/    Guidance for each alert level can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200429110819/https://covid19.govt.nz/assets/resources/tables/COVID-19-alert-levels-detailed.pdf

notes_H2: Oman: Drive-through COVID-19 PCR test facilities open tomorrow  Apart from the drive-through facility, there are testing facilities inside the airports for arriving passengers, that necessarily needs one to pre-book via the Tarassud app for a fee of RO 25. If the tests results are negative, passengers staying less than 7 days will continue their stay in the Sultanate normally and follow the guidelines of the Ministry of Health. Passengers staying more than 7 days are required to wear a wristband and follow a 14-day quarantine irrespective of the test results.   /web/20210126012227/https://gulfnews.com/photos/news/covid-19-delays-completion-date-for-spains-sagrada-familia-1.1600346415368?slide=7
notes_C7: ‘Extending closure of all commercial activities, while allowing movement of individuals and vehicles in all governorates of the Sultanate, between 8pm and 5am, starting from Thursday 8 April till the morning of the first day of Ramadhan (April 13). Nighttime ban throughout Ramadhan on all commercial activities, movement of individuals and vehicles from 9pm till 4am. Total ban of all gatherings (…). Ban on all group activities – social, sports, cultural or any other collective activities during the month of Ramadhan. Entry to the Sultanate will be restricted only to Omani citizens and residency with effect from 12pm of 8 April 2021.’   https://web.archive.org/web/20210411213104/https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-22DQwt3XebfmSzgT7coHObVjbsReotFw8gr6M514zU/edit?usp=sharing

notes_E2: In implementation and in accordance with the recommendations of the Supreme Committee in charge of following up the developments of the spread of the Coronavirus (Covid 19), the municipality decided to exempt fines related to non-registration of lease contracts (residential / commercial) with it, and also exempt shop owners from fees for registering municipal licenses, fines and everything that entails, as well as Exemption of restaurant and café owners from the municipality tax that was previously imposed on them.    Loan Repayment – The Directive also requires banks and financial institutions to accept requests for the deferment of loan repayments, particularly with regards to small and medium enterprises (SMEs). This requirement is set to become effective immediately and remain so for the next six (6) months. The only pre-condition is that any such deferment should not adversely impact the loan’s risk classification.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022214905/https://www.cms-lawnow.com/ealerts/2020/03/the-central-bank-of-omans-response-to-covid-19?cc_lang=en  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022214016/https://bawabaa.org/news/342494

notes_C2: Effective April 4, 2021, the reduction of ‘attendance of employees and other public legal persons required to attend in workplaces in the unites of the state’s administrative apparatus to 50 %’. The movement ban from 8pm to 5am , effective from March 28, 2021 until April 8, 2021, requires the closure of all commercial activities and ban on movement of individuals and vehicles in all governorates of the Sultanate. Exempted are healthcare personnel, emergency utility vehicles, private hospitals, pharmacies, airport traffic, trucks weighing 3 tons or above, work in factories, petrol stations, oilfields, press and media workers. https://web.archive.org/web/20210405140649if_/https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-22DQwt3XebfmSzgT7coHObVjbsReotFw8gr6M514zU/edit
