name: Thailand
notes_H1: https://thailand.prd.go.th/main.php?filename=index
notes_H2: Testing is expanded to asymptomatic people in vulnerable groups, and to some random testing of the general population. However, it is still not generally available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200511213623/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-thailand/thailand-to-expand-coronavirus-testing-as-new-cases-dwindle-idUKKBN22J0HG
notes_C7: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus
notes_H6: 23rd Jan 2021: Regulation Issued under Section 9 of the Emergency Decree on Public Administration in Emergency Situations B.E. 2548 (2005) (No. 17) effective since 7th Jan 2021 and appears to be current states in part that  "1. Intensifying the Enforcement of Disease Prevention Measures: Competent officials,  communicable disease control officers and responsible persons of places, activities or businesses  shall ensure that customers, travellers and the general public strictly comply with disease  prevention measures, by maintaining social distancing, wearing cloth masks or surgical masks,  washing hands, checking body temperature, ..."  No further detail is provided as to where and when specifically masks wearing is required. This is a nation wide regulation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210123115637/https://www.mfa.go.th/en/content-category/press-release-and-information-2?p=2  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123111659/https://image.mfa.go.th/mfa/0/mkKfL2iULZ/0904-64/%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A1_64/13-01-63/%E0%B8%82%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B3%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%94_%2817%29_Eng.pdf    The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration released a statement on 21 January 2021 "Bangkok asks everyone for cooperation to wear face masks". In part it states "Mrs. Silpa Suayrawee Saengsoon, Permanent Secretary of Bangkok, revealed that due to information from many agencies that Wearing a face mask can help prevent the spread of COVID-19. The best and most economical Nowadays, people are keen to wear surgical masks in public or crowded places such as establishments, shops, bus stops. Including people traveling by the pathways In the morning and evening, which is an urgent time where many commuters have to travel to work or return to their accommodation. " https://web.archive.org/web/20210123120324/http://www.bangkok.go.th/main/page.php?3-=&type=detail&id=114334
notes_E2: https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/covid-19-thailand-migrant-workers-left-out-unemployment-12637164
notes_C3: 23/01/2021 - Bangkok restriction on gatherings coded on on 21st of December was announced as being in place for a fortnight.  Additionally this appears to have been for the Bangkok Metropolitan area only.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210104062002/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=10520&filename=index     While not specifically mentioning public events, The  Bangkok Communicable Disease Committee Meeting No. 3/2021, relaxed restriction measures on 22nd Jan 2021. "For today's meeting, the meeting agreed to provide relief. 13 types of establishments can be opened from tomorrow (22 Jan '64) onwards as follows: 1. Arcade game venues 2. Gaming cafes and Internet cafes 3. Elderly care facilities 4. All types of race fields except the field Horse boxing 5. Property catering Banquet Location Including any other places that are similar. 6. Field amulets Amulet Center 7. Beauty Salon (Non-medical clinic) place for tattooing or piercing the skin or any part of the body 8. Exercise place, fitness 9...."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123082710/http://www.bangkok.go.th/main/page.php?3-=&type=detail&id=114335    No other evidence of canceling public events could be found except for political gatherings. The Thailand Government Public Relations Department published a release on 19th Jan 2021 stating: "Government Spokesperson Anucha Burapachaisri, in light of the recent political gathering, disclosed that with the Emergency Decree and Communicable Diseases Act being enforced to control the spread of COVID-19, the Government would like to seek cooperation from the public to refrain from attending any mass gathering. While the Government has been putting utmost effort to implement various economic stimulus measures to relief the plight of people as a result of the current phase of outbreak, the least that it would want to happen is an increased number of infected patients, especially from any political gathering."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210123102347/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?offset=20&cid=2&filename=index    Because it appears that there is a nation wide ban on political gatherings and it is stated that this is due to COVID-19, have coded G2 from 19th Jan.
notes_C6: https://ddc.moph.go.th/viralpneumonia/eng/situation.php
notes_C8: Phase 6 of the reopening began on August 1 allowing entry to certain non-Thai visitors, including: medical tourists, filming crews, Thailand Elite card members, foreigners who have work permits, foreigners married to Thai nationals and foreigners studying at educational institutions. The mandatory 14-day quarantine does not apply to diplomats, but they must get tested at the airport.  All tourists should have a negative test result within 72 hours of their arrival, go through a second test once they land, and stay in a compulsory quarantine of 14 days on arrival. If any visitors test positive, they should be quarantined for 14 days in a state hospital.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080024/https:/www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha approved loosening restrictions from the first week of February to allow businesses and schools to reopen.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080024/https:/www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C4: Restrictions on all public gatherings  https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus
notes_H3: 23rd Jan 2021: No recent evidence could be found to suggest that Thailand has a comprehensive contact tracing system in place. The Thai government does use contract tracing Apps MorChana and ThaiChana .    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123121330/https://www.xn--b3czh8ayeuf.com/faq.html      A recent Thai PBS News article covered the APP: "A closer look at Thailand’s (non-mandatory) contact tracing apps"https://web.archive.org/web/20210109053728/https://www.thaipbsworld.com/a-closer-look-at-thailands-non-mandatory-contact-tracing-apps/
notes_E1: The Thai Government Public Relations Department released a statement 20th Jan 2021 "State Welfare cardholders have received additional funding aimed at helping them weather the economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The additional funding of 500 baht applies from January to March. Cardholders making below 30,000 baht a year will receive a cash subsidy of 800 baht a month, up from 300, while those earning over 30,000 baht but not exceeding 100,000 baht annually will see their 200-baht monthly financial aid raised to 700 baht. The state welfare cardholders registered for the subsidies will begin receiving them this week."         The Thai Government Public Relations Department released a separate statement 20th Jan 2021 "The Ministry of Finance has assured that online registrations will be available for the extension of the “Co-pay” campaign and the newly introduced Rao Chana, 2-month stipend campaign. Deputy Government Spokesperson Traisuree Taisaranakul said the government will soon extend coverage for the “Co-pay” general purchases subsidy program for an additional 1 million people. The Rao Chana campaign meanwhile offers eligible applicants a stipend of 3,500 baht per month for 2 months. According to Traisuree, registrations for the “Co-pay” campaign open on Wednesday, January 20th, while registrations for Rao Chana campaign are scheduled for some time between late-January and early-February. "    In statement one - The funding amounts per total earning amounts to not account for more than 50% of earnings.    While not a lot of detail could be found - The terminology "state welfare card holders" in the first release and then "eligible applicants' appears to suggest that not all workers are eligible.  Therefore changed to 1 Formal only or informal only.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210123095511/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?offset=0&cid=2&filename=index
notes_H8: Bangkok reopens elderly day care centres, meaning the previous coding of 1G (for national guidelines for LTCF) comes into effect once again.  https://www.bangkokpost.com/thailand/general/2054835/curbs-lifted-for-13-types-of-businesses (reopening news story that mentions daycare for the elderly, not archived due to Waybackmachine exception)
notes_C1: The use of buildings and premises in schools or educational institutions for teaching and training is not allowed. University study online in all provinces and the new school term, which is scheduled to begin next month, may be deferred to June owing to the worsening COVID-19 situation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426164827/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=11001&filename=index
notes_C5: Public transport available, providing people social distance and wear masks   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308164400/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus

name: Tajikistan
notes_H1: Diplomat argues that Tajikistan’s government has not proven itself to be an accurate source of information on the pandemic. The government perpetually reproduces the narrative that it is strong, able to face any challenge, and the pandemic has been no different. An RFE/RL investigation last summer concluded that Tajikistan’s official coronavirus statistics didn’t match reality and reporting on the reality has become increasingly difficult. Tajik authorities blocked a critical news website, Akhbor, in April 2020. Also, Tajik authorities changed the country’s Criminal Code to punish reporting “disinformation” on the virus. Moreover, on January 26 Tajikistan President announced that the country does not have COVID-19 cases and the country completely defeated the COVID-19. The President urged citizens to follow hygiene rules.   Links: https://archive.vn/GuRLt https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/An4AE
notes_H2: It appears that COVID-19 tests are available at a cost, but there is no formal testing policy.    'COVID-19 PCR tests, the type of test required for international air travel from Tajikistan, are available in Dushanbe. Diamed clinic (44-601-90-16) provides next-day results at a cost of 167 TJS (approximately $15), paid by the patient.'    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426214533/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. See:  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Quote from article 1:  "Public places and services  Public places and services in Tajikistan were allowed to re-open in mid-June. Local regulations, including wearing of face masks, should be observed at all times." notes_E2: No evidence for current policies (April 2021) on debt relief for households. The below source is dated September 2020.  ___________________________    Quote (1):  The Government is providing VAT exemptions on essential imports, lump-sum assistance equivalent to minimum wage to vulnerable households and other socially disadvantaged groups. Health workers are to receive supplemental pay, while tariff increases on electricity, water, and communal services have been postponed until end of 2020. Government is providing free medical care to citizens placed under medical care and COVID-19 patients, as well as sick leave and compensation benefits. Government is providing grain, seed and fuel to farms to boost food security, and time-bound tax holidays and relief to targeted industries and small businesses until September 1, 2020. Anti-COVID measures also include financial support to SMEs and subsidizing food for population. Recently, Tajikistan was granted a debt relief around USD50 million under G20 DSSI initiative. These funds were also included to anti-COVID envelop under supplementary budget currently being discussed in the Parliament."    Link (1):  http://archive.today/2021.04.12-143712/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Oxford/Astrazeneca  As per announcement, the country have received several doses of vaccines as per the news, "Dushanbe, Tajikistan, 09 March 2021 Today Tajikistan received via the COVAX Facility, 192,000 doses of the AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 vaccine. name: Turkmenistan
notes_H1: Evidence of public information campaign (as noted by previous coders) include:  Postal service advising on personal hygiene, mask-wearing and social distancing.  http://archive.today/2021.03.14-103155/https://turkmenpost.gov.tm/  The Government of Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Health has established a COVID-19 hotline (tel. +993 12 73 9535) where citizens may receive information about the virus, including prevention and treatment, in both Russian and Turkmen languages.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210309190430/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

notes_E2: As per update, relief is provided specifically to businesses only in terms of loan repayments rather than to broad category of sectors/groups    Quote: " Key Policy Responses as of April 1, 2021  FISCAL  State budget spending is being revised, including to increase health spending for preventing an outbreak of COVID-19 and to provide support to businesses (possibly through tax relief, bank loans, and assistance in providing raw materials) affected by the containment measures."  Quote: "MONETARY AND MACRO-FINANCIAL  The authorities provided temporary suspension of loan repayments to businesses affected by the COVID containment measures."    Archived article  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426031915/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  __________________________________________________________    Quote: "The authorities provided temporary suspension of loan repayments to businesses affected by the COVID containment measures.   MONETARY AND MACRO-FINANCIAL  • The authorities provided temporary suspension of loan repayments to businesses affected by the COVID containment measures."    Archived Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426030941/https://www.unescap.org/sites/default/d8files/2021-03/Turkmenistan_COVID%20Country%20profile%20230321.pdf
notes_C3: The government continues to cancel public events.  It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still denies the existence of the COVID-19 in the country.    "[W]hile there is no official ban on public gatherings, authorities in Ashgabat have deactivated ATMs in shopping centers and semi-enclosed market areas, including the Terkinsky bazaar, to prevent crowds from congregating. All persons are required to observe social distancing of at least 1 meter (3 feet) and wear protective face coverings in public."    "Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public."    "Mosques and places of pilgrimage are closed and large gatherings are restricted."    https://archive.vn/bUERh    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus
notes_C6: No official policy found and no recommendations found on confining to home. However, many public facilities closed or are only functioning in a limited capacity.   https://archive.vn/TGNhe
notes_C8: "All commercial passenger flights in and out of Turkmenistan are suspended. See Return to the UK. Mandatory quarantine is in place for all arrivals from abroad for up to 14 days. See Entry requirements."  web.archive.org/web/20200706225920/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/staying-during-coronavirus    All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and?land borders?are?closed?to passenger traffic. International?flight restrictions are expected to continue at least through?October 1, 2020.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200909112702/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    At present, entry to Turkmenistan is prohibited except for Turkmen nationals and accredited diplomats, permanently registered foreigners and some employees of international companies and organizations  https://web.archive.org/web/20200816123428/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan
notes_C2: Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210309190442/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus
notes_C4: According to an update of the US Embassy in Turkmenistan on 8 Sep 2020, it seems the Turkmenistan government has imposed measures to restrict large gatherings. But the cap on the number of people is not clear. According to the archived webpage, such measures were not in place on 13 Aug 2020, and then showed up at latest on 8 Sep 2020. Such measures remain in place.    "Mosques and places of pilgrimage are closed and large gatherings are restricted."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200909112702/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201016191509/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Schools are open. However, the government is leading an information campaign on sanitary measures due to COVID-19 among school learners. Consequently, school operations result in significant differences as compared to usual, non-Covid-19 operations.    Link: https://archive.vn/bdh45
notes_H7: Quote (1):  "Turkmenistan was the first country in the CCA to register for the Russian vaccines Sputnik V and EpiVacCorona. Any Turkmen citizen who has the age of 18 and above can register for the vaccine. Polyclinics in Ashgabat and in the regions stated that citizens started signing up for the vaccine."    Link (1):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210417191228/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#T  __________________    Quote (2):  "Foreign track cyclists arriving in Turkmenistan will be vaccinated against unspecified “infectious diseases” with the Russian-made Sputnik V vaccine, which Turkmenistan has approved the registration of."    Link (2):  http://archive.today/2021.04.18-063755/https://cyclingtips.com/2021/01/covid-free-turkmenistan-to-vaccinate-riders-against-virus-it-wont-acknowledge/  ________________________    Quote (3):  "As of 4 April 2021, a total of 41,993 vaccine doses have been administered."    Link (3):  http://archive.today/2021.04.18-064725/https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/tm
notes_C5: Quote from link 1:  "Is public transportation operating? Yes"    Web archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.03.14-093605/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  ______________________________

name: Timor-Leste
notes_H1: The Ministry of Transport and Communication launched a hotline for citizens to solves doubts and provides assistance on COVID-19-related matters.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200530110247/http://www.tatoli.tl/2020/03/23/governu-kria-lina-telefonika-numeru-119-asesu-informasaun-kona-ba-covid-19/
notes_H2: Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Timor-Leste? Yes. At the time of this update, Timorese citizens and foreign nationals who are referred by a doctor for COVID-19 testing can obtain testing at the National Hospital, free of charge. Those seeking to test or experiencing COVID-19-like symptoms should call 119. COVID-19 testing is also available for a fee through the National Hospital for those needing COVID-free certification for international travel. Test results in English can be obtained directly from the National Health Laboratory or can be sent via email. Timor-Leste’s COVID-19 testing conditions are current as of the time of this update. Fees and services are subject to change; therefore, please confirm pricing when scheduling an appointment.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210305175204/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FMinisteriodaSaudeTL
notes_C7: Is a curfew in place? No  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes  The government has restricted travel to and from the municipalities of Bobonaro and Cova-Lima with the other Timor-Leste municipalities through March 3, 2021, with limited exceptions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210222182612/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Mandatory mask in public and private places of collective use.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210305172230/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2021/Covid/GovPRCom2Mar2021PtEn.pdf
notes_E2: No info. Assumed that policy is over.
notes_C3: All social, cultural, sporting and religious events that involve gatherings of people are prohibited.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210329155759/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/timor-leste/coronavirus
notes_C6: Are there restrictions on intracity or intrastate travel? Yes  SOE restrictions impose a general stay-at-home order for those not receiving or assisting in the delivery of essential goods and services in Dili, Baucau, Viqueque, Ermera, Covalima, and Ainaro Municipalities.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419184940/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Government of Timor-Leste (GOTL) announced it had temporarily closed its airports, ports, and land borders.  During this temporary border closure, the following exceptions will apply:    - Transit of diplomatic or consular personnel, members of international organizations and bilateral cooperation agencies, and workers in the petroleum sector;  - Operation of medical evacuation; and,  - International transportation of goods.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104154759/http://www.tatoli.tl/en/2020/12/24/tl-government-decides-to-close-the-borders-until-january-2021/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104153050/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: Nonessential businesses remain suspended nationwide. Essential businesses, such as food establishments, medical services, banks, and fuel stations, can continue operating with safe-distancing protocols and other measures in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419190036/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/467246/timor-leste-authorities-enforcing-exit-restrictions-in-multiple-municipalities-through-may-2-due-to-covid-19-update-24
notes_C4: All social, cultural, sporting and religious events that involve gatherings of people are prohibited.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210329155759/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/timor-leste/coronavirus  https://archive.ph/xO25z
notes_H3: Protocols for case detection and contact tracing have been updated based on the new revised  surveillance guidelines. Surveillance teams and rapid responders at national and municipality level have been trained and are on standby to detect and respond to COVID-19 alerts in the country.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200530153458/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/searo/timor-leste/03-03-2020-tls-sitrep-15-ncov-eng.pdf?sfvrsn=e7702ec7_2
notes_E1: PREVIOUS CODING MIGHT BE INCORRECT.    The State institutions responsible for the Basic Basket (Cesta Básica) program, coordinated by the Coordinating Minister of Economic Affairs (MCAE), signed a joint order, on February 25th, 2021, for the extension of the Basic Basket program until March 31st, 2021. Thus, through the said order, this program’s distribution, of a universal character, will be extended until March 31st, allowing to reach the entire population of the entire territory, in accordance with the provisions of Decree-Law no. 48/2020, of October 7th, amended by Decree-Law no. 1/2021, of January 6th, on the creation of the Basic Basket program.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210305171313/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=27093&lang=en&n=1
notes_H8: The Council of Ministers met at the Government Palace, in Dili, and approved the Draft Government Decree, presented by the Prime Minister, Taur Matan Ruak, on the measures for implementing the state of emergency declaration, made by the President of the Republic Decree N.º 55/2020, of August 5th, to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. The state of emergency covers the entire national territory and will be in force between 00:00 September 5th, 2020 and 23:59 October 4th, 2020. The government urged people who are sick to stay away from the public.  Please see: https://archive.is/wip/upQCn
notes_C1: School temporarily closed in Covalima municipality.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210314083223/https://www.facebook.com/plugins/like.php?href=http://www.tatoli.tl/en/2021/03/01/ministry-of-education-temporarily-closes-the-schools-in-covalima-municipality/&layout=button_count&show_faces=false&width=105&action=like&colorscheme=light&height=21
notes_H7: Has the government of Timor-Leste approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes.  Timor-Leste uses the AstraZeneca vaccine, and its vaccination program commenced on April 7. The aim of the Timorese authorities is to start the vaccination programme, firstly for front line workers, on April 07, which marks World Health Day.  A- Key workers    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210410135422/https://covid19.gov.tl/en/first-vaccines-for-east-timor-arrive-in-dili-on-monday-lusa/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410135453/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: Is public transportation operating? Yes, in some areas. Public buses in the municipalities of Viqueque, Ermera, Covalima, Ainaro, and Baucau are not operating through 23:59 on May 2.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426202500/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Tonga
notes_H1: No official announcement of a coordinated campaign was found, however there is evidence of such a campaign including regular government announcements, a dedicated Covid-19 link on the government website, information leaflets on the government website (in Tongan).  Following the coding rules regarding an announcement of a campaign, H1 could be coded as "1G", however the observations noted above suggests it was more coordinated than "Public officials urge caution", hence the code of 2G.
notes_H2: First suspected case of Covid-19 in Tonga.  Article refers to testing, however at this time, Tonga did not have testing equipment and so the samples were sent abroad.      http://archive.today/2020.12.12-192144/https://matangitonga.to/2020/03/04/suspected-case-coronavirus-tonga
notes_C7: The easing of restrictions from 12th April include the reopening of "most" public services, schools and businesses.  There is no reference to restrictions on internal movement (other than curfew which is coded under C6) and so C7 is coded as "0" (no measures)    http://archive.today/2020.12.16-170315/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/331721/tonga-authorities-extend-restrictive-covid-19-measures-until-april-17-update-4
notes_E2: See earlier note for E2 on 6th May
notes_C3: Announcement on SoE restrictions    "Night clubs, clubs, bars and kava clubs may be opened for business on Fridays and Saturdays only; from 5:00am to 9:00pm.  Kava drinking sessions prior to church services are permitted on Sundays only.  Daily early morning church services and on Sundays are allowed.     Mass gatherings under the restrictions, which are limited to only 20 people indoors and 40 people outdoors, does not apply to religious services and educational institutions.  All gyms, sporting events and activities, celebration of birthdays, marriages and other recreational or related gatherings shall be permitted, but they shall not exceed the maximum number defined as Mass Gatherings: not exceeding 20 people indoors and 40 people outdoors.  Events such as bingos and contact sports are prohibited.  Funeral gatherings shall be restricted to 20 people indoors and 40 people outdoors."    http://archive.today/2020.12.15-200143/https://matangitonga.to/2020/05/02/tonga-relaxes-covid-19-restrictions-under-state-emergency    In this announcement, there is no general reference to public events other than specific examples such as church gatherings. However,  the limitations on gatherings (20 inside/40 outside) suggests that there are likely to be limits on the type of public event that would meet the policy requirements.  As such, it is coded as "1" recommended rather than "2" (required) or "0" (no measures)
notes_C6: Restoration of curfew (Midnight-5am).  See 21st December for policy announcement
notes_C8: "Tonga declares State of Emergency"  "Starting today, Friday 20 March, at 8:00 pm:   Foreign Nationals are banned from entering Tonga.   Tongan nationals must be quarantined for 14-days upon arrival."  "The State of Emergency applies to all the land and sea areas of Tonga starting today, March 20 to April 17, unless further renewed."  Link: http://archive.today/2020.12.12-162440/https://matangitonga.to/2020/03/20/tonga-declares-state-emergency  Note that there is a slight timing difference between the news article above and Travel Advisory No.6 issued on 23rd March (see link below) which suggests that the border closure policy was implemented from 23rd March  http://archive.today/2021.01.04-191750/https://www.gov.to/press-release/travel-advisory-no-6-for-travelers-arriving-in-or-intending-to-travel-to-tonga/
notes_C2: To date, the codes "2G" and "1G" have largely reflected restrictions placed on the opening of bars, night clubs and kava bars.  However, with the further easing of restrictions, such venues are permitted to open Mon-Sat between the hours of 5am - 11pm.  A code of "0" (no measures) was felt to reflect the new policy.    http://archive.today/2020.12.16-193122/https://matangitonga.to/2020/05/29/tongas-covid-19-restrictions-eased-further
notes_C4: "Tonga declares State of Emergency"  "Starting today, Friday 20 March, at 8:00 pm:   Public gatherings are restricted.   People are to practice social distancing.   Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are banned."  "The State of Emergency applies to all the land and sea areas of Tonga starting today, March 20 to April 17, unless further renewed."  "This extends to public gatherings, restricted to a maximum of 20 people inside a building or 40 people outside, and people are to practice social distancing. Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are also banned."  Link: http://archive.today/2020.12.12-162440/https://matangitonga.to/2020/03/20/tonga-declares-state-emergency
notes_H3: First suspected case of Covid-19.  Article refers to contact tracing.  "He said Health had started to track down people she might have had contact with here in Tonga, from passengers on the aircraft she arrived on from Sydney on Monday, and people close to her."    http://archive.today/2020.12.12-192144/https://matangitonga.to/2020/03/04/suspected-case-coronavirus-tonga
notes_C1: Article about hand-washing at one school in Tonga.  New wash basins had been installed in this and other primary schools in Tonga.  Coding changed to "1" based on the coding guidance for C1 which reflects that the school environment has significantly changed for students.  "She said some children wash their hands at every opportunity they can as it wasn’t always like this at school."  http://archive.today/2020.12.17-173852/https://matangitonga.to/2020/05/05/students-step-hand-hygiene-school
notes_H7: Groups -A   The National vaccine roll out began on Thursday 15 April starting with all front line workers.  Astrazeneca is the vaccine administered    https://web.archive.org/web/20210420225215/https://fj.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210420224625/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tonga/coronavirus
notes_C5: "The government is, however, easing some restrictions, and has stated that certain activities now deemed essential, such as most public services, schools, businesses, and trade operations, will be permitted to reopen. These operations are set to resume normally as of 13:00 on Sunday, April 12. "    It is assumed that the reopening of "most public services, schools, businesses and trade operations" will include public transport, hence the change of code to "0" (no measures)    http://archive.today/2020.12.16-170315/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/331721/tonga-authorities-extend-restrictive-covid-19-measures-until-april-17-update-4

name: Trinidad and Tobago
notes_H1: Government begins releasing daily 'Trinidad and Tobago COVID-19 (Novel Coronavirus) Updates'.   https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.news.gov.tt/content/trinidad-and-tobago-covid-19-novel-coronavirus-update-1#.XpRoalNKg1I
notes_H2: According to the Ministry of Health's guidelines, a PCR test will be conducted if a public health official decides so.    In accordance with the guidance provided by the WHO, not everyone with flu-like symptoms needs to be tested. If a person does not fit the criteria, testing will not be performed and factors such as clinical history, travel history and/or contact with a COVID-19 positive patient are considered.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200901013919/http://www.health.gov.tt/sitepages/default.aspx?id=305
notes_C7: Changed from 2-Required, to 0-No Measures, because restrictions were eased for movement between the islands of Trinidad and Tobago.    Prime Minister Dr the Hon Keith Rowley announced several adjustments to the Public Health Ordinance Regulations during a media conference held at the Diplomatic Centre, St Ann’s today (Saturday 10th October, 2020).  -Caribbean Airlines will operate six flights daily to Tobago.  **Previously, Air and Sea bridge Transportation to Tobago were limited to essentials.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201123214337/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-ministers-media-conference-saturday-10th-october-2020/
notes_H6: From 31 August, the Government amended the existing Public Health Ordinance to make the use of face masks in public mandatory. According to Section 6 (7) of the regulation: "No person shall, without reasonable excuse, be in a public space without wearing a face mask, face shield, or face covering in a manner which covers his mouth, nose and chin."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200901020028/http://www.looptt.com:8080/content/7-things-know-about-new-face-mask-legislation
notes_E2: Following Tamoi's note, there is no evidence of a debt/contract relief program in the country from 1 August onwards.
notes_C3: Public gatherings limited to 10 people. "On March 21, the GOTT announced restrictions on gatherings at public places." (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413124105/https://tt.usembassy.gov/information-on-government-of-trinidad-and-tobago-stay-at-home-order-public-health-ordinance/)
notes_C6: As of 26 October, 2020, clubs, theatres, gaming houses, and gyms have all reopened with maximum fifty per cent allowed capacity, indicating that there is no longer a recommendation to stay at home.      According to the Minister of Public Health T. Deyalsingh, in Public Health Regulations 25 October, 2020:  4. (1) For the purposes of controlling and preventing the spread of the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV), it shall be an offence, during the period specified in regulation 17, for any person to--  (7) A maximum of fifty per cent of the allowed capacity of a building is permitted in the following places:  (a) a club as defined in section 2 of the Registration of Clubs Act;  (b) a theatre licensed under the Theatres and Dancehalls Act;  (c) a theatre licensed under the Cinematograph Act;  (d) a common gaming house or betting office licensed under the Gambling and Betting Act; and  (e) a gym or fitness centre.  **Subregulation (7) above is all new since the Public Health Regulations 11 October, 2020**  17. These regulations shall have effect from 26th October, 2020 to 8th November 2020.    Public Health Regulations 25 October, 2020  https://web.archive.org/web/20201123201624/http://www.health.gov.tt/covid19/GuidelinesRegulations/PublicHealthRegulations/PublicHealthRegulations.pdf    For historical reference:  Public Health Regulations 11 October, 2020  http://web.archive.org/web/20201123202223/https://www.covid19.gov.tt/the-public-health-2019-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-no-29-regulations-2020/
notes_C8: "National Security Minister Stuart Young has announced the closure of all borders effective midnight on Sunday. He said no international flights would be allowed to enter the country. This will apply to both nationals and non nationals."  (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413134259/https://trinidadexpress.com/newsextra/t-t-s-borders-closed-to-all/article_5061e42c-6b8b-11ea-8328-3f8003c18b6f.html)
notes_C2: In line with phased reopening announced by government, Phase II began on May 21 and allowed additional industries beyond essential businesses to open.    Government graphic explaining closure stages  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528205540/https:/twitter.com/newsgovtt/status/1263153842201509891/photo/1    Story about manufacturing opening:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528210025/http://www.guardian.co.tt/news/slow-phase-2-reopening-for-some-businesses-6.2.1121329.a259194645
notes_C4: No evidence of a policy change, the number of people gathering should not exceed 10. This was coded as a level 4 not level 3 as the new and revised wording of level 4 permits a gathering up to and including 10 people.  source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102172147/http://www.health.gov.tt/covid19/GuidelinesRegulations/PublicHealthRegulations/PublicHealthRegulations.pdf
notes_H3: Prime Minister states "Our protocols have been operationalized for some time now. We had tested over fifty cases and this is the first one that tested positive. Contact tracing is taking place. Our professionals have been and are handling the situation and situations."    (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413122852/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-minister-dr-the-hon-keith-rowleys-parliament-statement-on-covid-19/)
notes_E1: A new public assistance program was announced on February 26th. It was coded on this day as it is unclear when it will begin.   “This agreement will support minimum income for those affected by the coronavirus in the immediate period and during the recovery. The agreement does not see Trinidad and Tobago taking on additional debt but instead redirects existing uncommitted loan resources to new and urgent high priority public investment areas that require financing during this critical period” stated Minister West.  The programme will see US$24.45 million deployed for the creation of COVID-19 management measures aimed at ensuring that basic needs are met for vulnerable persons.  It will directly benefit vulnerable populations in the form of:  (1) Protection using existing cash transfer programmes and  (2) Protection for the vulnerable population not on the rosters of transfer programmes, working in the informal sector."    source: https://archive.vn/CKS3w
notes_H8: 22 June  On 22 June the country moved into phase five, lifting the majority of the remaining restrictions in place. Beaches, rivers, parks and gymnasiums, bars, restaurants, and casinos have reopened. This indicates there is no longer a recommendation to stay at home.  UK FCO Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200706162609/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/trinidad-and-tobago/coronavirus  Ministry of Communications Trinidad and Tobago Facebook announcement: http://archive.vn/hukbD    Recommendations to protect the elderly and be mindful of them remain
notes_C1: Secondary schools re-opened on February 8th for Forms 4-6 students only using a hybrid system.  "Online classes for teaching to continue as far as possible  Students to report to school for the completion of Practicals, SBAs and Internal Assessments  Physical teaching classes to be held only where absolutely necessary"  source: https://archive.vn/txRx0
notes_H7: The Phase 1 rollout of the National COVID-19 Vaccination Programme begins on this date with those at the highest risk and highest exposure to the disease, i.e groups "A, C:" healthcare workers and persons aged 60 years and older with non-communicable diseases. All available doses are of the AstraZeneca vaccine.    https://archive.vn/QeuUl  https://archive.vn/WfgQl  https://archive.vn/2PnT6
notes_C5: On 15 August, the Government of Trinidad and Tobago announced new measures to contain the surge of COVID-19 cases. The new measures, which are in place from 17 August, require all public taxis and maxis have to operate at 50% capacity and public service also remains at 50% rotation.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200901005409/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-ministers-media-conference-saturday-15-august-2020/

name: Tunisia
notes_H1: Dedicated Public Health information Website gives out general advice for the public.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200608201759/https://covid-19.tn/blog/%d9%81%d9%8a%d8%b1%d9%88%d8%b3-%d9%83%d9%88%d8%b1%d9%88%d9%86%d8%a7-%d8%a7%d9%84%d8%ac%d8%af%d9%8a%d8%af-%d9%86%d8%b5%d8%a7%d8%a6%d8%ad-%d8%b9%d8%a7%d9%85%d8%a9/
notes_H2: "If you think you have COVID-19 symptoms, you should call 190 (emergency services SAMU). They will ask a series of questions to assess whether it is likely that you have COVID-19. If COVID-19 is suspected, then they will arrange for someone to come to your home or hotel to conduct a test and they will advise you to self-isolate. COVID-19 PCR tests are only offered free if you are displaying symptoms. You can also pay for a test, if required for travel purposes, at the Institut Pasteur."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200806161617/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tunisia/coronavirus
notes_C7: Movement between cities is permitted outside of curfew hours, except to areas where there is a high risk of infection, to be determined by the health authorities as the situation evolves.  https://archive.vn/ZdkTj
notes_H6: Public places have hygiene measures in place, including obligatory face masks, taking a temperature check and sanitizing hands upon entry.    https://archive.vn/ZdkTj    All over the country, mouth and nose protection is mandatory in public buildings, hotels and shops; in the greater Tunis area in all public spaces. This also applies when driving a car with a passenger or more.  https://archive.vn/GSDyO    Protective face coverings or masks are mandatory in public areas. Failure to wear one could result in a fine or imprisonment.  https://archive.vn/1Csmr  https://archive.vn/LFN7G
notes_E2: no change since last update   https://archive.is/KkSWz#T
notes_C3: Meetings with a cultural, political, sporting or scientific background (conferences, forums, seminars, etc.). are forbidden. All public and private events are prohibited. It is possible to visit places of worship during prayer times.     https://archive.vn/GSDyO  https://archive.vn/LFN7G  https://archive.vn/1Csmr
notes_C6: "Tunisia has tightened precautionary measures amid a rapid spread of COVID-19 across the country, according to a statement released by the government on Thursday.    The measures, taken after a meeting between Tunisian Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi and members of Tunisia's committee to confront COVID-19 and several ministers, included the extension of the night curfew, suspension of the collective prayer, a ban of gatherings and suspension of classes.    Mechichi authorized all 24 governors to announce a curfew in their provinces, from Monday to Friday between 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. local time and on Saturday and Sunday from 7 p.m. to 5 a.m."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201031131417/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-10/29/c_139476377.htm
notes_C8: Travelers from all countries into Tunisia must take a PCR test less than 72 hours before travel and carry dated evidence of a negative result. You are also required to self-isolate on arrival in Tunisia.  https://archive.vn/ZdkTj    Travelers over the age of 12 are required to present a negative PCR test that is no more than 72 hours old when entering the country. The Tunisian government reserves the right to carry out random tests on newcomers.  A mandatory seven-day hotel quarantine applies to those arriving from abroad. A second PCR test should be performed between the fifth and seventh day. The quarantine can only be left if this is also negative.  https://archive.vn/GSDyO
notes_C2: "Tunisian authorities will ban all gatherings and reduce working hours for employees in the public sector in order to stop the rapid spread of the coronavirus, Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi said on Saturday (October 3).    The decision? was taken amid strong fears that hospitals in the North African nation will be unable to cope with a high number of patients because of the shortage of intensive-care beds."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201031132808if_/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-tunisia/tunisia-to-ban-gatherings-cut-public-sector-work-hours-due-to-pandemic-idUSKBN26O0ZJ
notes_C4: All modes of public transport (taxis, buses, trains and others) are permitted to operate. There are restrictions on travel between regions. You should follow the advice of local authorities.    The Tunisian authorities have announced that wearing a face mask in public places is mandatory. This includes public transport, health and educational institutions, shopping centres, sports and cultural venues as well as places of worship. Failure to wear a mask may result in a fine or imprisonment.    On 23 January, the Tunisian authorities revised the national health measures to combat the speed of transmission of the virus.    There is a national curfew in all regions across the country, from 8pm to 5am. During the curfew you are only allowed to leave your residence in case of an emergency.  Cafes and restaurants are open at a reduced capacity. After 4pm they are only open for takeaway service.  Gatherings are banned.  Movement between cities is banned.  https://archive.vn/sn4Nq  https://archive.vn/DwEUI
notes_H3: Authorities require all travelers to download the E7mi tracking application upon arrival in the country.    https://archive.vn/e0sGS  https://archive.vn/LFN7G  https://archive.vn/1Csmr
notes_E1: A 2.5 billion TND emergency plan ($0.71 billion or 1.8 percent of GDP) was announced on March 21. From the social side, this also includes cash transfers for low income households, disabled and homeless people (450 TND million for three months). The plan also includes a support for those who will be on temporary unemployment because of the COVID19 shock (300 TND million).   Sources:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200608195445/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19   https://web.archive.org/web/20200608195532/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/tunisia-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
notes_H8: "Tunisia has tightened precautionary measures amid a rapid spread of COVID-19 across the country, according to a statement released by the government on Thursday.    The measures, taken after a meeting between Tunisian Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi and members of Tunisia's committee to confront COVID-19 and several ministers, included the extension of the night curfew, suspension of the collective prayer, a ban of gatherings and suspension of classes.    Mechichi authorized all 24 governors to announce a curfew in their provinces, from Monday to Friday between 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. local time and on Saturday and Sunday from 7 p.m. to 5 a.m."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201031131417/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-10/29/c_139476377.htm
notes_C1: Tunisia on Saturday announced the closure of all schools until April 30, as well as restrictions on movement, to slow the spread of coronavirus    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210420170750/https://www.reuters.com/article/healthcoronavirus-tunisia-idUSL8N2MA08E
notes_H7: The vaccine campaign against COVID 19 began on March 13, 2021.     The three group of A,B,C have been selected to receive the vaccine. Pfizer vaccine has been used in Tunisia.    https://archive.vn/bbk95  https://archive.vn/1VRRt  https://archive.vn/ApzIp
notes_C5: Public transportation are permitted and operates with 50% capacity to avoid crowding.     https://archive.vn/iH2v4  https://archive.vn/0vQI1

name: Turkey
notes_H1: Turkish Ministry of Health informs about Coronavirus in a series of videos; https://web.archive.org/web/20200211204229/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225755162737827841, https://web.archive.org/web/20200210073346/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225737365160939520, https://web.archive.org/web/20200211032634/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225759617629577218,  https://web.archive.org/web/20200210133127/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225696129578258432,  https://web.archive.org/web/20200313112513/https://twitter.com/saglikbakanligi/status/1225731397022879745
notes_H2: Coronavirus Scientific Advisory Board issues guidance on testing: "All patient samples conforming to the 2019-nCoV possible case definition should also be evaluated for 2019-nCoV (with a PCR test)."; https://hsgm.saglik.gov.tr/depo/haberler/ncov/2019-nCov_Hastal_Salk_alanlar_Rehberi.pdf (not archivable, https://web.archive.org/web/20200406142757/https://www.aa.com.tr/tr/koronavirus/turkiye-koronaviruse-karsi-tedbirlerini-aldi/1744654
notes_C7: According to President Erdogan's speech about Ramadan restrictions following decisions made to be applied in Ramadan:     Intercity travels will not be allowed during curfews, except in compulsory circumstances.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419090109/https://www.dw.com/tr/t%C3%BCrkiyede-14-nisanda-k%C4%B1smi-kapanma-ba%C5%9Fl%C4%B1yor/a-57188256
notes_H6: “As of 8 September the wearing of masks is mandatory at all times outside the home throughout Turkey. This includes, but is not limited to, all public places, including streets, side streets, parks, gardens, picnic areas, markets, sea side and public transportation including Metro, buses, taxis and ferries. Masks are also mandatory in all shops, restaurants, hairdressers and barber shops.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200909213906/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkey/coronavirus
notes_C3: “The Interior Ministry sent a circular on expanding virus restrictions from 14 to all of Turkey’s 81 provinces. As of Friday [September 4th], large gatherings such as outdoor weddings and other traditional celebrations will be toned down. The duration of a wedding ceremony in Turkey has been limited to an hour, with a ban on dancing and serving of food. People aged 65 and above and under 15, who are not first and second degree relatives of the bride and groom, will not be allowed to attend the wedding. At least one public officer will attend the wedding ceremony to monitor the measures.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200909231135/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/latest-on-coronavirus-outbreak/turkey-imposes-new-nationwide-virus-restrictions/1961415
notes_C6: As of 8 February, Turkish citizens and residents are subject to a weekend curfew beginning 9 p.m. on Friday, continuing through 5 a.m. on Monday.    Travel outside of the house is limited to individuals between the ages of 20 and 65, who are obtaining basic food items, between 10 a.m. and 5 p.m.    Additionally, there is a nightly curfew between 9 p.m. and 5 a.m.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214212732/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
notes_C8: Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flights. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days.   Link: https://archive.fo/2qeZb
notes_C2: On June 1, "Turkey has reopened restaurants and cafes in addition to many other public areas, as the government further eased coronavirus restrictions". Bars, hookah bars and nightclubs were required to remain closed.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200610025346/https://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/turkey-eases-lockdown-restaurants-reopen-flights-resume-70996794  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/06/turkey-reopens-public-places-coronavirus-lockdown-200601143056501.html (unable to archive)
notes_C4: As of 24 January, weddings and funerals were limited to 30 people.    Unable to find an update since then.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210214232708/https://apnews.com/article/international-news-turkey-coronavirus-pandemic-4316a18d7eae4b5724b7775b07360c1c
notes_H3: Ankara also ramped up use of contact tracing to map out the chain of interactions in COVID-19 cases. A staff composed of doctors and other professionals scan the information on confirmed patients in a call center and dispatch teams in protective gear to find the contacts of patients who are viewed as prospective patients themselves. Crews arrange a 14-day quarantine for those potential patients and treatment if they test positive.https://web.archive.org/web/20200422155344/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/turkey-ranks-7th-worldwide-with-600000-coronavirus-tests/news
notes_E1: In terms of economic support, the government doesn't give any support to those who lost their jobs. But those who normally work but because of the covid-19, the firms cannot pay them, for those people there were two options Cash payment support and short-time working allowance/work.     First is Cash payment support which is given to workers who are currently in unpaid time-off (due to covid-19, firms cannot fire the employers, so they are sending their workers to unpaid time-off). In one month its max pay time is 30 days and the daily wage is 47.70 TRY (The currency is changing rapidly in these weeks, so to avoid the wrong amount, I didn't write in USD form). This support is ending on 05/17/2021 if there won't be any extension.     The second way is a short-time working allowance/work. In this payment, the workers who are currently working (who are not in time-off or any other absence situation) and be approved by the Turkish Employment Agency are getting %60 of their daily gross earnings. This support ended on 03/31/2021 but within the new presidential decree, it extended to 06/30/2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210122131003/https://www.iskur.gov.tr/isveren/kisa-calisma-odenegi/genel-bilgiler/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210122191037/https://www.iskur.gov.tr/is-arayan/issizlik-sigortasi/nakdi-ucret-destegi/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210325135853/https://www.cnnturk.com/ekonomi/nakdi-ucret-destegi-ne-zaman-bitiyor-ucretsiz-izin-maas-destegi-ne-zaman-bitecek   http://web.archive.org/web/20210422214717/https://www.cumhuriyet.com.tr/haber/resmi-gazetede-yayimlanan-kararla-kisa-calisma-odenegi-3-ay-sureyle-uzatildi-1830299
notes_H8: Turkish citizens and residents aged 65 and older are restricted to their place of residence (allowed outside only between 10:00 and 13:00) and Intercity travel permits are required. Additionally, the use of all means of public mass transport in Istanbul has been banned for persons over 65 part of COVID-19 restrictions. On 28th of January, the vaccination of the citizens at the age of 75 and above was started with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm. On 11th of February started the vaccination of people over 70 years old. Those over the age of 65, including their spouses over 60, started to receive the vaccine on 12th of February.        Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news, https://web.archive.org/web/20210315180248/https://archive.fo/aKTPz and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315180555/https://archive.fo/QTiA9
notes_C1: Starting with 2nd of March, face-to-face education was initiated across the country in all pre-school education institutions, primary schools, 8th, and 12th grades.  Link: https://archive.fo/W87id
notes_H7: Vaccine: Sinovac    http://web.archive.org/web/20210323220648/https://covid19asi.saglik.gov.tr/TR-77707/asi-uygulanacak-grup-siralamasi.html
notes_C5: According to President Erdogan's speech about Ramadan restrictions following decisions made to be applied in Ramadan:     People over 65 and under 18 are prohibited from using public transportation in the city.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419090109/https://www.dw.com/tr/t%C3%BCrkiyede-14-nisanda-k%C4%B1smi-kapanma-ba%C5%9Fl%C4%B1yor/a-57188256

name: Tanzania
notes_H1: The Tanzanian government has not released aggregate numbers on COVID-19 cases or deaths since April 2020. The use of masks, social distancing, and other prevention strategies are largely absent throughout Tanzania.  https://archive.ph/eLxWW
notes_H2: "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Tanzania? Yes. Testing is available through Government of Tanzania laboratories.  The details of testing (including test type and performance characteristics) have not been made available nor independently verified.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? No. There are increasing reports of test results being significantly delayed and some clinics no longer offering pre-travel testing. Many people also receive inconclusive results and are asked to repeat the test after several days. Travelers have tested positive upon arrival in foreign destinations following negative COVID-19 tests in Tanzania prior to departure."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318004936/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: The Tanzanian government has not released aggregate numbers on COVID-19 cases or deaths since April 2020. The use of masks, social distancing, and other prevention strategies are largely absent throughout Tanzania.  https://archive.ph/eLxWW
notes_C3: According to the IMF website, effective June 1, 2020, the authorities allowed the opening of upper-secondary and tertiary schools and the resumption of sport activities and events. On June 29, 2020 all other educational institutions reopened. As a result, all the restrictions due to Covid-19 have been lifted by July 2020.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928023258/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C8: According to the US embassy website, all travelers whether foreigners or returning residents whose countries or airlines require them to provide negative testing for COVID-19 as a condition for traveling will be required to present a certificate on arrival. Travelers from other countries with symptoms and signs related to COVID-19 infection will undergo enhanced screening and may be tested on arrival.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928033423/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: According to the IMF website, effective June 1, 2020, the authorities allowed the opening of upper-secondary and tertiary schools and the resumption of sport activities and events. On June 29, 2020 all other educational institutions reopened. As a result, all the restrictions due to Covid-19 have been lifted by July 2020.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928023258/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H3: Tanzania is definitely denying any spread of the virus. A foreign citizen has resulted positive to the virus weeks after the country was declared covid-free. Despite him knowing of at least other 25 people getting COVID, there was no attempt by the govt to trace contacts.  http://archive.fo/zQhLc
notes_C1: No closures in place, as the government is still denying the presence of COVID-19.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222191241/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-55900680

name: Uganda
notes_H1: video prevention campaign: @MinofHealthUG   appeals to the general public to remain vigilant and look out for the symptoms of #Coronavirus. (https://twitter.com/MinofHealthUG/status/1223616070080245760)
notes_H2: A laboratory test carried out on medical prescription can identify the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection.  However, this test is of no use in the absence of symptoms. Your personal physician is in the best position to assess the value of the test in your case. If needed, contact your physician via telephone. The Ministry of Health's Testing Eligibility Tool recommends isolating and monitoring for those with general symptoms, while those with severe symptoms must get in contact with the Ministry of Health to arrange for a test and receive medical attention.    Travelers are expected to cover all costs associated with their COVID-19 test.  Average cost for testing is UGX 350,000. Delivery of test results may be via email, text message (i.e. a PDF send via WhatsApp) or physical copy.  Make sure to confirm a delivery method that suits your needs before selecting a company/lab to conduct the test.  It is recommended  to bring a printed copy of your test results with you to the airport; an electronic copy may not be accepted. A COVID RDT Antigen test can be done next to the airport in Entebbe at the Kazuri Medical clinic (+256 0702 199 000 / +256 0787 199 788, Plot 168 Kampala Road, Katabi, Entebbe). The antigen test takes 15 minutes and costs 50 USD, certified results are provided onsite.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208211534/https://www.health.go.ug/covid/faq/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208211617/https://www.health.go.ug/covid/project/testing-eligibility-tool/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195447/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
notes_C7: Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No. Movement by personal vehicles is now permitted in all districts, including those with an international border, but is still limited to 4 people per car (including the driver) and all must wear masks if there is more than one person in the vehicle.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195406/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/uganda/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195447/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
notes_H6: "Public transport is generally allowed at half-capacity and all passengers are required to wear masks.  When in public, wearing of masks is required and individuals are expected to maintain social distancing at all times."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316065245/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
notes_E2: There seems to be no new information concerning this placeholder.
notes_C3: According to the US Embassy in Uganda, gathering of about 200 people can go on with social distancing measures and wearing of masks. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201123004030/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
notes_C6: The curfew (2100h-0600h) remains in place. Motorcycle taxi (boda boda) drivers must cease their movements by 1800h.  web.archive.org/web/20210316065245/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
notes_C8: Entebbe International Airport opened on October 1.  The Government of Uganda requires that all departing passengers present a negative PCR COVID-19 test taken not more than 120 hours before departure. This requirement is mandatory for all departing passengers out of Uganda even if the destination country does not require it.  COVID-19 tests for departing passengers must be taken at an accredited laboratory or a COVID-19 sample collection point approved by the Ministry of Health.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210202184751/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
notes_C2: "Shopping arcades, hairdressers and salons will be open from 22 July. Shopping malls, supermarkets and pharmacies are open. Hotels and restaurants are open with social distancing measures in place and food delivery services (such as Jumia) remain operational outside of curfew hours." Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200820114638/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/uganda/staying-during-coronavirus "Museveni said business arcades must have temperature checks and traders must wear masks, ensure social distancing, and follow other safety guidelines" Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200820114007/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/businesses-to-reopen-as-uganda-eases-virus-lockdown/1918466
notes_C4: According to the US Embassy in Uganda, gathering of about 200 people can go on with social distancing measures. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201123004030/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
notes_H3: This report suggests that contact tracing has been taking place within Uganda. Additionally, the Ministry of Health reports on contacts and alerts in their regular updates on social media.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208213112/http://www.afenet.net/index.php/news/news/669-contact-tracing-during-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208210505/https://twitter.com/MinofHealthUG  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208213641/https://www.health.go.ug/
notes_H8: *** Changing from 1G, since C6 is coded as 2T.    Previous coding (description also does not seem to relate to the H8 indicator)  1G  Country-Specific Information: Uganda continues to experience COVID-19 outbreaks. For the most recent statistics, please visit the Government of Uganda, Ministry of Health’s webpage. Uganda lifted certain COVID-19 restrictions, including opening Entebbe International Airport on October 1 and all land borders, allowing schools to re-open on October 15 for the candidate classes, permitting places of worship to gather, and allowing open-air sport activities to resume without spectators. On November 9, the Ministry of Health issued further updates relaxing restrictions, including allowing gatherings of no more than 200 persons provided masks are worn and social distancing of 2 meters is followed. Cinemas, gyms, and massage parlors have been permitted to open while casinos and gaming centers are restricted to operating between the hours of 6:30am to 7:00pm. Bars and dance halls remain closed. The curfew (2100h-0600h) remains in place. Motorcycle taxi (boda boda) drivers must cease their movements by 1800h. On November 24, the Ministry of Health issued new guidelines regarding COVID-19 testing required for both inbound and outbound travel to Uganda including a requirement that tests be taken at an approved facility within 120 hours of departure. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210301135719/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
notes_C1: "Despite rising coronavirus infections across the country, schools in Uganda reopened on Thursday after a seven-month break.  The government has allowed schools to resume finalist and candidate classes for now, with no date announced yet for the return of other students.  Schools were ordered to ensure COVID-19 safety measures before reopening, including handwashing facilities, temperature guns, and availability of face masks.  Some institutions that failed to meet requirements will remain closed, according to the Education Ministry."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201202000345/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/uganda-reopens-schools-despite-virus-fears/2007193
notes_H7: A (health workers): AstraZeneca    "The first 864,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine that been secured courtesy of the COVAX facility, arrived in the country on the 5th of March 2021. COVAX allocated 3,552,000 doses to Uganda. The remaining doses are expected in the country by June 2021."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316070336/https://www.unicef.org/uganda/stories/uganda-launches-first-phase-covid-19-vaccination-exercise
notes_C5: Travel by public transport is allowed and boda-boda (motorcycle taxis) must stop operating by 18:00.  web.archive.org/save/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/459721/uganda-authorities-maintain-covid-19-related-restrictions-as-of-march-24-update-14

name: Ukraine
notes_H1: The Ukrainian Government has created a special information page with all relevant information in addition to daily briefings by the chief medical officer and government officials: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414005009/https://covid19.gov.ua/en
notes_H2: The Ministry of Health of Ukraine states "Diagnostic testing will only be carried out in cases that meet the epidemiological and clinical definition of the disease outlined in the WHO guidelines. The testing will be conducted by the Virology Reference Laboratory of the Public Health Center of Ukraine. It is impossible to buy a diagnostic test kit for independent use."     (However, the website of the US Embassy in Ukraine claims "Covid-19 tests are widely available at the expense of the individual.")    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411195738/https://covid19.gov.ua/en  https://web.archive.org/web/20210402235231/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Policy: Domestic flights are operating, although some carriers are operating a reduced schedule. Public transport in cities and bus and train travel between regions are also operating on a reduced scale.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419210201/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ukraine/coronavirus
notes_H6: Policy: Wearing masks is mandatory in public transportation and indoor public places.  Individuals and establishments can be fined for not complying.  Everyone should carry ID.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419212356/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: The Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine adopted Resolution No. 247 “On the Provision of Housing Subsidies”, which provided for simplification of the procedure for granting housing subsidies and introduced additional compensation for utility costs. This decision significantly strengthens the program of housing subsidies and social support for the least protected categories of citizens:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200817102229/https://cis-legislation.com/document.fwx?rgn=123781
notes_C3: From February 26, a red level of epidemic danger will be introduced in Ivano-Frankivsk region while restrictive measures will be intensified. At the red level, it is envisaged to introduce strict quarantine restrictions that were in force during the January lockdown. Including:  The activities of catering establishments will be prohibited (except for targeted delivery and takeaway service);  The work of shopping malls and other entertainment establishments – cinemas, theaters, etc. is prohibited.  Educational institutions will not work (except kindergartens and elementary schools);  Non-food markets and shops, gyms, swimming pools and fitness centers will be closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227181512/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-rishennya-komisiyi-teb-ta-ns-maye-ne-dopustiti-podalshogo-poshirennya-covid-19-v-ivano-frankivskij-oblasti  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227182431/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/tag/ohorona-zdorovya  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227180512/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: President Zelenskyy stated in an address "I strongly recommend that all people stay home, except for the need to buy food or pharmaceuticals." This is a development from three days earlier in which only those over 60 were advised to stay home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200407160742/https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/zvernennya-glavi-derzhavi-shodo-protidiyi-koronavirusu-60181
notes_C8: From 24 March 2021, all non-exempt foreign nationals must provide a proof of a negative PCR test, taken no more than 72 hours in advance of their arrival in Ukraine.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210329200604/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ukraine/entry-requirements
notes_C2: Adaptive quarantine measures remain in place until 30 April at the country level.    From 20 March to 09 April, Kyiv has introduced further restrictions (similar to the “red” level of quarantine), which include:    - Closure of cinemas, theaters, museums, and other cultural establishments  - Closure of shopping malls and stores except for grocery stores, pharmacies, pet stores, shops selling hygiene products and household chemicals  - No religious services, public and sport events  - Limitation of restaurant, cafes, and catering establishments’ operations to “takeaway” mode only  - Beauty salons will operate by appointment only  - Spring break starts early in schools, kindergartens will continue to operate as usual  - Public transportation will work as usual – but with max 50% of seat occupancy    https://web.archive.org/web/20210320185538/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-misceva-vlada-maye-vsi-povnovazhennya-dlya-posilennya-karantinnih-obmezhen  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320185733/https://covid19.gov.ua/karantynni-zakhody  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320185346/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/timeline?type=posts&tag=Healthcare  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320183515/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: The adaptive quarantine was extended till 30 June.  Coding 4T is proposed since public events are banned in red zones.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210503192825/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19
notes_H3: On 7 May the Parliament passed a law providing for large scale free obligatory testing of those who have symptoms, have been in contact with infected patients or are in at-risk groups (e.g. medical workers, police).     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200608203532/https://www.oecd.org/eurasia/competitiveness-programme/eastern-partners/COVID-19-CRISIS-IN-UKRAINE.pdf
notes_E1: The amount of payments for persons receiving the minimum unemployment benefit without taking into account wages and length of service has been raised from UAH 650 to UAH 1,000 for the quarantine period. The Decree applies from the beginning of the quarantine announcement, ie from March 12, and will be valid for 30 calendar days after the quarantine ends: https://web.archive.org/web/20200430222447/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/news/minimalnu-dopomogu-po-bezrobittyu-pidvishcheno-z-650-grn-do-1000-grn-minekonomiki
notes_H8: "Visits to care homes for older people and people with disabilities are prohibited (unless you are a family member)"    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104212108/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ukraine/coronavirus    "visits by outsiders (except for legal representatives, family members, relatives, subject to compliance with all anti-epidemic measures, not more than once a week) institutions and institutions of social protection, in which temporarily or permanently reside / stay elderly citizens, veterans war and labor, persons with disabilities, persons with persistent intellectual or mental disabilities, institutions and institutions providing social services to families / persons in difficult life circumstances, except institutions and institutions providing social services in an emergency (crisis) ;"    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216120435/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/npas/pro-vstanovlennya-karantinu-ta-zaprovadzhennya-obmezhuvalnih-protiepidemichnih-zahodiv-1236-091220
notes_C1: All schools closed in Kyiv from April 5 to at least April 16. Schools in red zones are also closed, while schools in orange and yellow zones can remain open with restrictions and sanitary measures in place.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126131951/https://covid19.gov.ua/osvita-ta-batkivstvo    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331215149/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/462181/ukraine-tighter-covid-19-related-restrictions-to-be-in-force-in-kyiv-april-5-16-update-22
notes_H7: A,B: In the first stage of vaccinations, those eligible for vaccines include people with an ultra-high risk of infection and severe course of the coronavirus disease of COVID-19, as well as those whose work is critically important in the context of a pandemic. Residents of boarding schools, nursing homes and staff of these institutions; participants of the Joint Forces Operation in eastern Ukraine will also be vaccinated.    Vaccines approved for use: Sinovac, AstraZeneca, Pfizer    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210320184350/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/moz-dozvoliv-do-vikoristannja-v-ukraini-sche-odnu-vakcinu-proti-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411224049/https://vaccination.covid19.gov.ua/
notes_C5: From April 5 to at least April 16, access to public transport in red zones is limited to key workers with special passenger passes only.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210104212108/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ukraine/coronavirus

name: Uruguay
notes_H1: Website with al relevant information on coronavirus and what the government is doing:  /web/20200430214429/https://www.gub.uy/sistema-nacional-emergencias/comunicacion/noticias/informacion-interes-actualizada-sobre-coronavirus-covid-19-uruguay
notes_H2: All symptomatic people and those who have been in contact with confirmed COVID-19 cases, symptomatic or not, shall be tested.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210417184355/https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-salud-publica/sites/ministerio-salud-publica/files/documentos/noticias/Comunicado%20a%20los%20laboratorios%20y%20Prestadores%20del%20SNIS-Indicaciones%20de%20testeo%2C%20aislamiento%20y%20cuarentena%2007-12-2020.pdf
notes_C7: No policy has been assessed in this matter.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210416184306/https://www.presidencia.gub.uy/comunicacion/comunicacionnoticias/medidas-gobierno-transporte-emergencia-sanitaria-covid19   http://web.archive.org/web/20210416184456/https://www.presidencia.gub.uy/comunicacion/comunicacionnoticias/medidas-gobierno-turismo-emergencia-sanitaria-covid19
notes_H6: Mandatory for users and staff to wear a face covering on public transport, along with other safety measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200831120003/https://www.impo.com.uy/bases/resoluciones-mtop/SN20200603001-20200
notes_E2: No changes in this policy. Uruguayan electricity provider UTE has extended "until May 31, 2021, the benefits to the activity sectors: Hotels, Restaurants, Gastronomy, Party Halls, Cultural Institutions and Travel Agencies. The discount applies to the entire fixed charge and power charge for customers with contracted power less than or equal to 40 kW and provides a proportional discount with respect to the consumption of the same month of the year 2019, prior to the effects of the pandemic, to the customers with power greater than 40 kW."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210417140608/https://www.presidencia.gub.uy/comunicacion/comunicacionnoticias/medidas-gobierno-economia-emergencia-sanitaria-covid19
notes_C3: "This Wednesday government authorities announced at a press conference the decision to apply sanctions, according to the powers granted by current regulations for pandemic contexts, such as fines, closures and criminal complaints to those who violate health provisions.
